urn:contentItem:5X18-47X1-DYT4-M49T-00000-00Jourova approves of conditioning EU subsidies - Polish TV2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJourova approves of conditioning EU subsidies - Polish TV

Jourova approves of conditioning EU subsidies - Polish TV

Warsaw, Sept 10 (CTK) - In the past, Czech EU commissioner Vera Jourova, recently appointed Vice-president for Values and Transparency in the new EC, called for the EU to condition its subsidies by the target countries' fulfillment of rule of law terms, Polish TVN 24 television station pointed out today.

The outgoing EC reproached the Polish government for perceived offences against democracy and the rule of law and initiated procedures that could possibly end in sanctions against Poland, TVN 24 said.

"Czech Vera Jourova is to be responsible for values and transparency and will also take care of the rule of law. Until now, that agenda was in the hands of Frans Timmermans. Jourova was responsible for justice, consumers and gender equality in the previous EC team. Following an EC debate about the union's future budget in April 2018, she reported that all commissioners agreed to introduce a mechanism that would tie EU subsidies to a country's respect to the rule of law," TVN 24 said.

"I think we should consider creating a stronger dependence between the rule of law and cohesion funds," the Polish television reported Jourova's words from a statement dated to November 2017.

TVN 24 claims Jourova posited that regional and cohesion policy will not be effective without being tied to the rule of law since it will only create corruption and fraud otherwise.

According to TVN 24, she continued to state that the rule of law is not exclusively a matter of specific countries because they must respect EU law and if one country's justice system is corrupt, it would mean corruption for the whole EU system.

The Polish television also pointed out that last September, the EC filed a lawsuit against Poland with the Court of Justice of the European Union.

Even though Poland managed to pass an amendment of its Supreme Court law in order to defuse the EU's criticism, Jourova told Czech media at the time that the EC will continue with the lawsuit.

The TVN 24 station also summarised the life and political path of Jourova, as well as her inclusion in Time magazine's list of the world's 100 most influential people of 2019 as "a leading voice in the call for the regulation of digital enterprise and big tech companies."

urn:contentItem:5X9C-02T1-JCMN-Y3GD-00000-00J.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs not joining Facebook Libra cryptocurrency2019-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJ.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs not joining Facebook Libra cryptocurrencyMariam Ahmed

Oct 18, 2019( Talking Biz News: http://www.talkingbiznews.com Delivered by Newstex) J.P. Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs have declined Facebook's invitation to join Libra[1]. The refusal comes amid worries that cryptocurrency could be used to violate money laundering and sanctions laws. The news was reported by AnnaMaria Andriotis, Peter Rudegair, and Liz Hoffman at The Wall Street Journal. [2]The tech giant planned on launching its Libra cryptocurrency by June 2020. The plans included including over two dozen cofounders and members of the Libra Association. However, these plans have been unraveling since the project was announced early this summer.As of now, Facebook has declined to comment.Lawmakers have had concerns about Facebook moving into the cryptocurrency world, especially after privacy snafus[3] like the Cambridge Analytica[4] scandal.Additionally, when Facebook cryptocurrency chief and former Paypal president David Marcus was questioned about the project[5] by the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, he promised that Facebook will not launch Libra until regulators' concerns were addressed.In July, Rep. Maxine Waters and other lawmakers sent a letter[6] to Facebook calling on the company to stop Libra implementation over 'serious concerns' about the project. These criticisms also come amid worries that Facebook and other big tech companies are monopolies without sufficient competition.Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is slated to testify before Congress about Libra on October 23. urn:contentItem:5X94-Y0H1-F03R-N0JC-00000-00JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs reportedly rejected any involvement in Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency because of fears it would be used by criminals (FB)2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJPMorgan and Goldman Sachs reportedly rejected any involvement in Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency because of fears it would be used by criminals (FB)Mary Meisenzahl

Oct 17, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) APJPMorgan[1] and Goldman Sachs[2] declined involvement in Libra[3] cryptocurrency due to fears it could be used for criminal acts, The Wall Street Journal reported.[4] Libra is Facebook's[5] move into cryptocurrency[6], which it announced in June. Many of Libra's backers have already dropped out, including Visa, Mastercard, and PayPal. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[7]. JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs declined Facebook's invitation to join Libra because of worries that cryptocurrency could be used to violate money laundering and sanctions laws, AnnaMaria Andriotis, Peter Rudegair, and Liz Hoffman at The Wall Street Journal reported.[8] Facebook hoped to launch Libra by June 2020 with over two dozen cofounders and members of the Libra Association, but these plans have been unraveling since the project was announced early this summer. Facebook did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment regarding J.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs' involvement.

Lawmakers have had concerns about Facebook moving into the cryptocurrency world, especially after privacy snafus[9] like the Cambridge Analytica[10] scandal. In July, Facebook cryptocurrency chief and former Paypal president David Marcus was questioned about the project[11] by the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs. He promised that the company wouldn't launch Libra until regulators' concerns were addressed.Read more: Facebook made the unusual decision to push back directly on Elizabeth Warren and her criticism of the company, but its attempt to defend itself backfired spectacularly[12] In July, Rep. Maxine Waters and other lawmakers sent a letter[13] to Facebook calling on the company to stop Libra implementation over "serious concerns" about the project. Increased regulatory scrutiny spooked many of the project's backers, and more than a quarter[14] of initial partners have backed out, including PayPal[15], Mastercard, Visa, and eBay.[16] These criticisms also come amid worries that Facebook and other big tech companies are monopolies without sufficient competition. Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren[17] has made breaking up large tech companies a cornerstone of her platform. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is slated to testify before Congress — which will include critics like Waters — about Libra on October 23.NOW WATCH: Why Apple's Mac Pro 'trash can' was a colossal failure[18]See Also: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will give his 'most comprehensive take' on freedom of speech in a livestream on Thursday[19]Evan Spiegel and Miranda Kerr just welcomed their second child together. Here are 14 other power couples who rule the tech world.[20]Facebook is 15 years old. Here's a look into the life, career, and controversies surrounding CEO Mark Zuckerberg[21] SEE ALSO:TikTok hired former US lawmakers to review its content policies after facing backlash and urn:contentItem:5Y04-4321-DXH2-654V-00000-00JPMorgan Beasts Estimates; Trends in Health Care; Fighting the Opioid Crisis; Taiwan Re-Elects Pro-Democracy President; Leader Carrie Lam Pledging to Help Struggling Economy; Esperion Awaiting FDA Approval on Cholesterol Drugs2020-01-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTAnthony Chan, Joel Marcus, Rupert Hammond-Chambers, Tim MaylebenNEWSFinancial011402cb.231JPMorgan Beasts Estimates; Trends in Health Care; Fighting the Opioid Crisis; Taiwan Re-Elects Pro-Democracy President; Leader Carrie Lam Pledging to Help Struggling Economy; Esperion Awaiting FDA Approval on Cholesterol DrugsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Liz Peek, Cheryl Casone, Jackie DeAngelis

ANTHONY CHAN, FORMER JPMORGAN CHASE CHIEF ECONOMIST: Saying that they've - - they've run up quite a bit in 2019. I'm still bullish for 2020 because I'm bullish on the economy.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: BARTIROMO: All right, I just -- I just -- I just want to point out that JPMorgan quarterly average total loans down 1 percent or up 3 percent, excluding the impact of loan sales and home lending.

So, again, lending is really a key component here and you are seeing the more -- the portfolio in terms of lending reflect that businesses are still uncertain. There is some uncertainty out there. So we'll keep watching that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And, Maria, you've been --

BARTIROMO: Anthony, it's --

MCDOWELL: I just wanted to quickly say --

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Because you've been talking about the importance of asset management for all these financials. Assets under management of 2.4 trillion, was up 19 percent. Up 19 percent.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: So that is an incredibly important number. That's from the JPMorgan press release.

And, by the way, I pointed out, the stock was down year-to-date. And that's one of the reasons. There was -- you surprise to the upside and you get a lift because people were under-estimating at least to start the new year what JPMorgan would do.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think one other thing that -- and it's important to the stock, Maria --

BARTIROMO: It's a big number.

Yes.

PEEK: Is -- and to the bank stocks in general is that for sure, over the last 24 months we've had an easing of regulatory oversight of the banks. I don't mean that the regulators have walked away. But if you talk to any senior banker, they'll tell you that the general tone in Washington is much more positive, more positive about allowing the banks to engage in mergers and --

BARTIROMO: OH, yes.

PEEK: And grow their businesses and stuff. I don't think we should forget that because that's an underpinning for this whole sector.

CHAN: And, Maria, you know that's great for --

BARTIROMO: Yes, 100 percent. It's a great point.

Yes, go ahead, real quick, Anthony.

CHAN: And, Maria, you -- you know that's great for fee income because as the value of these assets, the market went up 30 percent last year. You get that fixed -- that fee income going up as the market goes up. And that was good for JPMorgan . It's been good for a lot of the asset managers.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean that -- and that's -- and that's one thing I asked Jamie Dimon about, in terms of Schwab cutting fees to zero, what does that mean for asset management? What about active versus passive? So you'll hear that coming up.

JPMorgan kicking off this big healthcare conference and the bank earnings with a strong start this morning, posting a beat on both the top and bottom lines for their fourth quarter at JPM.

I spoke exclusively with JPMorgan Chase Chairman and CEO Jamie Dimon late yesterday ahead of the earnings in a wide-ranging interview. We touched on hot button topics ranging from the China trade deal to the ongoing debate between capitalism and socialism.

We begin with the state of the U.S. economy.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

So let's start on the economy. You've got such an incredible vantage point. How do you see things today?

JAMIE DIMON, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, JPMORGAN CHASE: Yes, it's doing OK. You know, the United States consumer, which is 70 percent of the GDP, their confidence levels are very high, their jobs are going up, their wages are going up, their savings are strong, their balance sheet is in excellent shape, more household formation. So I'd say it's very good.

Thirty percent is the -- is business. And that -- that confidence came down, CapEx came down, and I think a lot of it is driven by trade and trade uncertainty. And that all seems to have stabilized. And, obviously, if we do this trade deal in the next couple days, I think that will be a small plus for that.

BARTIROMO: So you're looking for a good year?

DIMON: Yes, so far it looks like at least the first part of the year is going to be pretty good. And, obviously, you know, things happen to change that. But I think the economy can continue to hum along.

BARTIROMO: There's such an incredible amount of liquidity out there. The Federal Reserve expanding money supply by more than $400 billion.

How does that manifest itself? Do you see higher deposit money?

DIMON: Yes. Well, eventually, it adds to deposits. Some of these activities. And, you know, I think most of that $400 billion the Fed did to -- to ameliorate what's going on in the money markets. So it had a very targeted -- targeted theme. But it does have other effects and stuff like that. So I think the Fed did the right thing to react to that. I think they need a more permanent stabilization as opposed to jump in every time they don't like what's happening at the repo rates.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because people were wondering what was going on with the repo market with that overnight need to do something.

DIMON: Yes. So, remember, that's happened many times before. And the question is, when should the Fed do something about it, not whether it's going to happen.

In this case, there were a lot of reasons for it, from tax payments to, you know, to certain regulations that caused the year-end numbers to change a little bit. I think they should fix all of that and make it a non-issue, which I personally think is achievable, but it's going to take a little bit of time to -- I think for them to figure out exactly what they want to change.

BARTIROMO: I mentioned to you earlier, I love how much data you have. And you use your card data really effectively to know where to put new branches, where to put new ATMs. Two-thirds of accounts in new markets have been digital.

Tell me about the branches that you're opening. How much branches did you open last year? What are your expectations this year?

DIMON: Yes, so we're -- we're thrilled to be expanding again. And we're in -- you know, we're going to D.C. and Philadelphia and Pittsburgh and Boston and North and South Carolina and we love opening branches. And, as you say, we do a lot of products and services. And the branch is kind of the hub of that. And clients know us because even though we're not in that state, they have our credit cards. So that credit card relationship is a pretty important thing.

And the branch is doing quite fine. It's still early. You know, we don't want to talk too much about it, but they're doing far better than we would have thought. And partially because the clients tell us they love the digital services, partially because they love linking various services. But we're going to be opening another 300 in the next couple years and another, you know, total of 16 states, including the ones we did this year.

So I love expanding. It feels great. We visit those markets.

The other thing about those markets, I mean you go there, those branches help private banking, middle market, small business, mortgages, and even government business. So -- and even investment banking because it makes you -- it gives you more stature in the state. People know who you are. And so they've been (INAUDIBLE). It's a wonderful thing to do.

BARTIROMO: We had a guy on the other day, a credit card specialist, and we said, what's the best credit card out there today? He said the Sapphire card.

DIMON: Sapphire, yes.

BARTIROMO: Just so you know.

DIMON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I wanted to make sure to tell you that.

DIMON: Thank you. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

You were taking -- with all of this expanding, you're taking --

DIMON: I can't take credit for that, by the way. There are a bunch of -- mostly women who actually designed that product years ago. It's just done an outstanding job.

BARTIROMO: It's resonating for sure.

So you're taking market share from a lot of the regional banks as you move into new states. Sun Trust and BBT recently completing the biggest bank merger since the financial crisis, done largely to keep up with you and your spending at JPMorgan .

Do you expect we're going to see more regional bank mergers in 2020?

DIMON: I think so. I think there's a lot of business logic for it. And bank mergers, the business logic is there, the industrial logic is there, the economies of scale is there. The difficult part is always what we call the social stuff, name, location, who's going to be the CEO, and those are complex things but if people could overcome that, I think you'll see more mergers for good reason.

BARTIROMO: What states are you expanding in this year or the next three years at JPM.

DIMON: Well, I think -- we did South Carolina, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts. We're doing Minnesota. I think Kansas. So it's all over. Sixteen more. We're already in 23. So now it's going to be -- we'll be in a total of almost 40.

BARTIROMO: I know you said that the economy is looking good, the consumer is looking good and you've got the data to show us that. But talk to us about the corporate side. We've got this chart that we're going to show and it shows corporate borrowing down in the last year, certainly in the last couple of years.

What do you think is going on? Is there uncertainty on the corporate side of the economy?

DIMON: Yes. So the corporate side, confidence was very high, and it came down -- very high. Literally all-time high after tax reform. It came down to -- I call it average. CapEx came down the same way. And a lot of that we think was trade uncertainty. Some geopolitical stuff, but mostly trade uncertainty, which hopefully have a bunch of that behind us now. I don't think it's going to be totally gone, but hopefully a bunch of it is behind.

But you have to remember, just a very important fact, companies spend capital when they need to spend it. They don't just kind of guess out there. So very often, you know, when there's consumer demand, that's when they start to build a new plan to hire the new workers. And we've had a very slow growing economy for the better part of 10 years. And it sped up a little bit in the last two years. But the fact is, a slow-growing economy will mean that companies need less capital expenditures to keep up with their demand. And so it's hard to figure out exactly what the interplay is, but I do think it's part of the reason.

BARTIROMO: What about the auto lending market? This is another issue. There was an article in "The Journal" the other day that one guy bought a $27,000 Ford truck. He actually spent $45,000 on the truck.

DIMON: Yes. Yes, I think it's OK. I mean it's a trillion three. Like the mortgage market's at 10 trillion. Of the trillion three, something like 450 million or billion or so is subprime. And there's always going to be stuff like that. So I think, you know, leases got extended. Collateral has gotten less. I just don't think it's systemic. And my guess is, it's a couple players who are really on the fringes there who will regret having done it.

BARTIROMO: OK, so you were the first or really --

DIMON: Actually, on our position, we don't -- if we -- if we're uncomfortable, we simply don't do it. We've told the people in the auto business or any loan business that you can't make good loans, don't make the loans, let the book go down. That's completely fine.

BARTIROMO: And in 2007, you saw the crisis coming before a lot of people. In fact, you started, you know, avoiding riskier places.

Do you see risky areas in the market today that you want to avoid?

DIMON: Not really. I mean if you look at credit, wholesale, consumer, it's pretty pristine. And so I think you mentioned one where it's out there. I think student lending, which was done by the government, has -- has -- is going to have a huge -- hundreds of billions of dollars of problems. It's not systemic.

You know, prime -- mortgages have been pretty good. The amount of subprime came down dramatically. It's going up a little bit. And it should. It's making mortgages more affordable to lower income individuals. But at one point those trends will get to a point -- I'm going to be sitting here talking you, now that we've gotten to the point where I think they can cause problems.

BARTIROMO: OK.

DIMON: But it's not there yet.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the government sponsored entities, Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, continued conversation about these companies going public again. How do you handicap the likelihood of this and how do you anticipate that's going to impact the mortgage business?

DIMON: Yes. I don't know -- I can't handicap it because you can do it through legislation, though I've been told that some of the things they're talking about doing, they can just do without legislation. If it was with legislation, I think it's virtually impossible.

But I think what they're talking about is exactly right. You know, it's to get those companies public, recapitalized, to, you know, be very transparent about the guarantee, to have the guarantee paid for by the mortgage underwriters so that you have a very healthy mortgage system with total transparency and those entities should not get involved in political lending. If the government wants to get involved in all forms of other lending, let them do it directly, but not through these public companies.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about spending in terms of your investing because you've done a lot for Detroit. You've done a lot for Chicago. When you get into a city, you start investing there and you can turn a deprived situation into economic progress.

What other cities are on your agenda in that regard?

DIMON: Yes, remember, that's what a bank does, you finance the growth of an economy. And so it could be a country, it could be a city, it could be a company, it could be a small business. And, of course, what we're talking about now is also we do what, you know, more corporate social responsibility stuff. So there's basic banking. But we could help those cities with locating, you know, attracting workers, attracting companies, training workers properly, affordable housing, you know, capital for minority entrepreneurs who may not be able to get it in the normal way. So you can help accelerate the whole city.

So Detroit was a huge benefit. And we weren't the only ones. A lot of companies who did a lot of work in Detroit. And it works. You would actually take -- a city was -- virtually totally collapsed in terms of unemployment, population and taxation and has turned the corner because of an excellent mayor, et cetera. So we're doing -- those lessons are being replicated by us in New Orleans, LA, Chicago, San Francisco, Paris. And as we've learned, we're going to share that with other person. So this is not about just JPMorgan , it's about what are the things that business can do to help lift up society in a way that's good for everybody.

BARTIROMO: But, I mean, this city, for example, I mean I know you've done this conference for a long time and it's record numbers, everybody comes. Even your competitors, they go, they get hotel rooms elsewhere so that they can talk to your clients.

But look at the city. The homelessness issue is skyrocketing. There's -- I don't even want to say, poop on the street, et cetera. I mean would you consider moving this conference to another city? Have any of your attendees said to you, look, Jamie, San Francisco's just -- can't do it anymore. Can you move the conference?

DIMON: Not quite that -- not quite that bad. I understand your point. And bad policy causes all these various issues.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

DIMON: But, you know, what happens in these things, people, they know where they're going, they plan for it the same time of the year, they have their friends and so we have Chase Center here, by the way, so we're doing some functions down there which can accommodate large groups of people.

But I think the bigger point, cities need policy that actually works to educate the kids, create affordable housing. So, you know, here, a lot of the affordable housing isn't because people won't do it, it's because of zoning laws. And, of course, you have a lot of the big companies don't want to do it. So we do a lot of affordable housing. We're going to get deeply involved in San Francisco across the board. We're a big bank here now and we want to be -- want to be the people that help lift up this city too.

BARTIROMO: By the way, did you see in New York the new bail reform law that they don't -- they can't hold anybody for bail, so they just let out inmates and they let out people who they hope will come back for court.

DIMON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: There's this one guy that they let out. He keeps going back and robbing Chase banks.

DIMON: Yes. Oh, really? I -- I -- I did see that.

BARTIROMO: He hands the teller a note. And then -- I mean he's only gotten away with like a couple of thousands of dollars, but he keeps going back to Chase banks --

DIMON: And he keeps -- and he --

BARTIROMO: As a New Yorker and as the head of Chase, I mean any -- any remarks?

DIMON: That's -- you know, I -- I read about that. I think they are going to -- I read that they're going to try to modify it and make it -- there's a reason to do some of it, but maybe it over -- they over -- went overboard.

BARTIROMO: Yes, looks that way.

Let's talk technology for a second. You've been investing billions in technology every year, more than 11 billion. Is there an opportunity to acquire a technology company or do you think you're going to keep up that kind of level of spending in technology? Give me the in and out.

DIMON: Yes, with technology you always want to spend it wisely. But if we're going to build products and services and digital and cloud and AI and reduce fraud and offer you things that you like and get (INAUDIBLE), it's all technology, which (INAUDIBLE) all people. That's what gets that stuff done.

So we have to do that to compete. And we are very rigorous about doing it. And, yes, we could acquire things. We bought WePay, which is in the merchant processing business. We bought InstaMed, which connects providers and customers for medical payments, which I forgot the number, maybe 80 percent is still done by check. So there are -- there will coming (INAUDIBLE) require which are more technology companies than banking companies that help serve our clients, particularly around -- possibly on payments and data and APIs and things like that. We own a piece of 100 different companies, you know, when we -- particularly when we do business with them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got much more of my exclusive interview with JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon coming up. Stay with us. We get into China, as well as the world coming up.

Then, Trump getting his wall built. The president taking additional steps to fulfill a key campaign promise. We've got those details coming up.

Then this, royal settlement. Queen Elizabeth agreeing to let Prince Harry and Meghan Markle step away from royal duties. Inside the palace split, right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

More money could be on the way to complete the border wall.

Cheryl Casone with the details now on the president's plans.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Maria.

President Trump planning on diverting $7.2 billion. This is according to "The Washington Post." All of it apparently coming from the Pentagon. The money would finish the project by 2022 and bring the total miles of wall to 885. More than the 509 miles originally planned by the Trump administration. This would bring the total amount of federal funds allocated under the president to $18.4 billion.

Well, Visa seeing green and Plaid. Visa's buying the Silicon Valley start- up for $5.3 billion. Plaid is the financial technology company that powers Venmo and other banking apps. The deal will help Visa expand its access to fin tech firms as it takes another step to move beyond traditional credit cards. You were just talk about that with Jamie Dimon.

Well, the Megxit drama still unfolding. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle getting the queen's consent to live part-time in Canada. This decision coming out of a royal crisis summit concerning the couple's decision to step back from their duties. Harry arrived two hours early, by the way, to meet with her royal highness alone. That's according to "The Daily Mail." Canada has yet to decide whether it's going to pay for security, which could cost upwards of $1 million a year for the couple.

An American muscle taking home top honors in the motor city. The 2020 Corvette named the North American Car of the Year by a panel of automotive journalists. The model is a complete redesign with the engine moved to the back of the car, which is kind of similar to some other high-end sports cars that we've talked about on the show. The base price for the 2020 Corvette, Maria, $60,000.

I'll send it back to you and Dagen because for me a car is just something that gets me from point a to point b. You all are way more into this stuff than I am. She's the car girl.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's not electric, right?

CASONE: She's the girl.

BARTIROMO: It looks good.

What do you think, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Are they giving them away. I drive it if it was free. I'm just joking. It's a mid-engine car. So a Porsche 911 is a rear engine car. This is a mid-engine car. I think that they had some difficulty kind of fine- tuning that move -- that placement of the engine. But it looks more like a super car than the previous Corvette.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So they're clearly going after somebody that might buy, I don't know, a more expensive Lambo or even a Ferrari.

BARTIROMO: All right. Little red Corvette, looking good.

Coming up, corporate real estate this morning. I'll be speaking with one of the leading investors in lab and technology locations. Wait until you hear what's going on there.

Then, Astros fired. The front office and Major League Baseball coming down hard on one of last year's World Series contenders. The fallout all ahead.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Alexandria Real Estate Equities is a market leader in labs and technology facilities in America. The company named the number one and most active corporate life sciences investor in Silicon Valley bank's annual ranking. This is the third year in a row they've gotten that distinction.

Joining me right now is the chairman and founder of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, executive chairman and founder, Joel Marcus.

Joel, it's great to see you again.

JOEL MARCUS, FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ALEXANDRIA REAL ESTATE: A pleasure. Happy New Year, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You too. Thank you so much for joining us.

How's business? Give us an update in terms of what you're seeing with healthcare and technology coming in and renting space in Alexandria.

MARCUS: Well, we're very fortunate, 2019, the stock had a total performance of 44 percent, which doesn't happen every year. So it was very great. We're seeing the demand for our spaces and really our clusters and our campuses in those clusters to be as white hot as they've ever been.

BARTIROMO: So the stock is obviously performing so well in reaction to your growth. You are expecting growth in 2020 of what?

MARCUS: Twenty percent over 2019.

BARTIROMO: That is a huge number, 20 percent.

MARCUS: It is.

BARTIROMO: So where does that growth come from?

MARCUS: Well, it comes from a number of locations, really, the demand in Cambridge still remains the strongest in the country. Here we are sitting in San Francisco. That is really also kind of competing for the most demand by our tenants. Many of the companies reporting here and presenting here at JPMorgan .

I think people want to see these clusters, they want to be in these clusters because they can attract the best talent in both these -- both these locations together with places like Seattle, San Diego. New York City has been very, very strong.

And I think over the last year or two, we've kind of increased our focus on these campuses within these great brain trust clusters and created what we call the mega cluster, or the mega campus within the cluster.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's --

MARCUS: A million square feet together. It's -- think of it as almost a new kind of shopping center, but not like the ones we have today where you have a deep concentration of life science and technology tenants surrounded by - - anchored by a transportation hub and surrounded by amenities, places where you want to be, because that's where the collision of science creates these great medicines of the future.

BARTIROMO: It's actually fascinating to see your business and how it has evolved in terms of the tenants.

MARCUS: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Because that really is an indication of what's going on in America. You've got traditional retail, the malls, if you will, moving out and healthcare moving in.

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Technology moving in, right?

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell me how that has evolved in the last five years.

We've been speaking with you on this program for about four or five years here --

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And you've walked us through this transition.

MARCUS: Yes. I think the companies have doubled down on the locations. The hardest thing in corporate America today is the hiring of critical talent for businesses. And we're in the knowledge and information business, the scientific business, and you can only get those quality people in certain locations, in depths, and you must provide great environments, creative environments, you must provide amenities, places where they can hang out close to where they can live and on great transportation hubs. And I think that's what's driven these so-called mega campuses that we've really instituted over the last couple of years and within these great clusters today here in the United States.

BARTIROMO: So is retail, tradition retail, moving out or I mean it's -- it's -- it's fascinating what you say. The big challenge for companies today is getting the right talent.

MARCUS: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And they're finding that talent in your -- in your neighborhoods.

MARCUS: Yes. And you find key amenity -- key retail people moving out of some of the malls --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARCUS: And some of the strip malls and they're coming into places like we have. We just bought a campus in Watertown, right near Cambridge, a million square feet, called the Arsenal on the Cambridge, right on the water.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MARCUS: And people want to be in that location, access to living, you know, living quarters, and retail being very nearby. And so that's kind of the evolution of what you see today.

So although retail in malls is down, retail within these campuses is really very big demand.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the opioid crisis.

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Alexandria Real Estate teaming up with Google --

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) to build a new way and a place to fight the drug epidemic in America.

MARCUS: Correct.

BARTIROMO: OneFifteen is a technology focused opioid rehab campus in Dayton, Ohio.

MARCUS: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about that. It's helping patients, regardless of insurance coverage, right?

MARCUS: Yes. So it -- right now it's open, taking outpatients. Next summer it will open to be able to treat about 3,000 people. The first one of its kind ever in this country, maybe in the world, where you can not only just go through the detoxification for 28 days, which is the normal standard of care, but you're put out on the street, here you go, to sober living, you go to family reunification, after that job training and then job placement. So it's the whole continuum, the wrap-around services, data driven, very importantly, so you can understand how to treat, because not everybody -- many of the addiction kind of impacts are really caused by deeper problems, depression, schizophrenia, bipolar issues.

We also think this may be, and we may launch something in San Francisco, this may be a model for homelessness where you bring homeless people into a wonderful environment, you try to help them from -- whether it's mental health or physical health, you try to get them to live independently. You reunify them with their families, you train them and then you put them into the workforce.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MARCUS: So it might even be extended to something as big a problem here in California, as you know, as homelessness.

BARTIROMO: That's unbelievable.

MARCUS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I can't believe the homelessness that has really skyrocketed in places like San Francisco here and in Los Angeles as well. Great idea, Joel. And it's certainly needed.

Great to have you and congrats on --

MARCUS: Thank you very much. Thank you. A real pleasure to be here and Happy New Year.

BARTIROMO: And to you. Joel Marcus joining us there. Alexandria Real Estate.

We will take a quick break but stay with us. We continue our live coverage from the JPMorgan Healthcare Conference.

This week on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, tomorrow, big tech bracing for big regulations but stocks continue to soar. We are watching your wallet.

Thursday, increasing Iranian saber rattling, bringing the U.S. to the brink of war. Senator James Lankford on the path forward.

And Friday, it is time to Ask Maria, I'm answering the questions that matter to you, that's all right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Coming to you live this morning from the JPMorgan Healthcare Conference here in San Francisco. It is Tuesday, January 14th. Your top stories right now 07:33 a.m. on the East Coast.

Bank earnings set to drive the action on Wall Street this morning, JPMorgan reporting better than expected results this morning, the stock is higher on the news, up 1-2/3 percent.

The company will hold a conference call this morning at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We'll probably get more headlines out of that call when the CFO and CEO, Jamie Dimon speak and that may very well move the stock further.

We are awaiting results from Citigroup and Wells Fargo later this morning.

Meanwhile, Futures this morning indicating a pretty much a gain at the start of trading for the Dow Industrials, although it has been a mixed situation there as you can see, Futures are showing a gain on the Dow. We'll get that board fixed for you.

We had gains across the board yesterday, the momentum continues. The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at all-time highs yesterday. As you see, the Dow was up a quarter of a percent, the NASDAQ was up better than one percent and the S&P up three quarters of one percent.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices right now are showing a mixed story. FT-100 is basically flat in London, up a fraction, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down three points and the DAX Index's Germany is up nine points, so very much a fractional move across Europe this morning.

Asia overnight, mixed performances overnight and the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up three quarters of one percent.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning but first, our top story this half an hour, a win for democracy this weekend. This weekend's presidential election in Taiwan dealing a major blow to Beijing.

Pro-democracy candidate Tsai Ing-wen winning the election, strengthening the island's commitment and defending itself against mainland China's influence and the authoritarianism there.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo tweeted his congratulations saying this; the U.S. congratulates Dr. Tsai Ing-wen on her re-election in Taiwan's presidential election. Taiwan once again demonstrates the strength of its robust Democratic system. Thank you President Tsai for your leadership and developing a strong U.S. partnership, wrote Secretary Pompeo.

Joining me right now is U.S.-Taiwan Business Council president Rupert Hammond-Chambers. And Rupert, it's good to have you this morning. Thanks very much for being here.

RUPERT HAMMOND-CHAMBERS, PRESIDENT, U.S.-TAIWAN BUSINESS COUNCIL: Thank you, Maria, it's my pleasure.

BARTIROMO: So your reaction to the election victory this weekend and what that means for the rest of the world, in particular the U.S. and its dealings with China?

HAMMOND-CHAMBERS: Yes, it was -- Tsai Ing-wen's reelection was not a surprise. The margin of her victory perhaps was slightly -- she really had a significant gap between her and Han Kuo-yu who she defeated. I think that perhaps the biggest surprise in the election was the parliamentary results where her party retained control of the legislative chamber and unifies governance on both ends and the legislature and the executive branch.

For the states, we retain an important partner in the Asia-Pacific that President Trump and his administration has been working with closely on democracy promotion, on the economic challenge of a predatory China and on the security challenge of a predatory China. Taiwan has been tremendous for U.S. policy, Indo-Pacific policy and we're going to see continuity for that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, it was amazing to look at the pictures this weekend. You had people rallying in the streets in Taiwan and then you had people rallying in the streets in Hong Kong, holding the American flag. You even had Iranians in Iran for a different reason obviously, pushing back against the authoritarianism in Iran.

I sat down with former White House strategist Steve Bannon this weekend on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" over on Fox News. And he noted the incredible signs that he saw about pro-democracy movements across the world. Watch this. Got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Reaction to what's taking place across the world?

STEVE BANNON, FORMER STRATEGIST, WHITE HOUSE: What, this is the Trump doctrine, whether it's in Hong Kong, the ballot box in Taiwan, in the streets of Tehran, freedom and democracy. This is what --

President Trump has stood up to the Chinese Communist Party, the dictators in Beijing. He stood up to the mullahs in Tehran and now you're seeing it, you're seeing the people, whether it's the ballot box in Hong Kong or in the protests. It has had a sweeping victory there a couple of weeks ago. A landslide victory for the -- for the freedom and Democracy Party in Taiwan with a record turnout and this is what the Chinese Communist Party is trying to put their thumb on the scale.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Rupert, what do you say?

HAMMOND-CHAMBERS: He's absolutely right. Mr. Trump's policy towards China has been a huge breath of fresh air over the last three years after very difficult times under Mr. Bush and Mr. Obama.

And the promotion of democracy, a recalibration of our economic relationship with the Chinese was badly needed. Their predatory approach to America, to the world indeed, the theft of intellectual property and trade secrets had us on the back foot.

And also, we as a country, we're not handling our relationship with the Chinese well. There was self-censorship in our approach with the Chinese, we felt we needed to appease them to gain narrow -- to gain progress and narrow goals.

With Mr. Bush in his second term it was with the North Koreans, with Mr. Obama, particularly in his second term it was with the Paris accord. And of course, the Chinese made gains across the board when it was clear we were focused on only a single issue.

So, it has been a breath of fresh air. We've made progress on democracy, on economic engagement and critically as well in our security relationships in the -- in the region.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And not only that, but you're seeing the U.S. continuing its relationship with Taiwan, selling them arms. This is obviously to the chagrin of the Chinese. What does that relationship look going forward look like between Taiwan and the United States and how does this signing of the phase one deal with China impact all of this that's happening tomorrow?

Secretary Mnuchin making a big deal, a big splash of the signing of this phase one deal tomorrow in Washington.

HAMMOND-CHAMBERS: On security cooperation, Maria, Mr. Trump has rightly demanded that our friends and allies take up more responsibility for their own security.

And President Tsai in her first term jumped at that opportunity. She's raised real defense spending, she has modernize her arm forces, she has bought modern equipment from the United States such as F-16 fighters, modern tanks and that has improved the security in the Taiwan strait. And we can expect President Tsai to continue to improve her security footprint and look for ways to cooperate with the United States in an Indo-Pacific security framework.

On the -- on the phase one trade deal, I think the important thing to recognize here from a Taiwan angle is the United States will need partners in executing some of the trade deal, particularly in the areas of intellectual property and trade secrets.

Taiwan's role in the global supply chain is absolutely critical. Their tier one systems integrators like Hon Hai Foxconn and perhaps the most important technology company, few people have ever heard of, Taiwan Semiconductor, these companies are essential to our economic health and well-being. So we'll need partners to pressure the Chinese to live up to their obligations.

Obviously, the Chinese are very good at headline commitments, making big splashy announcements but over time do they stick to those deals, do they actually do what they say they're going to do? That will be where the rubber meets the road. Taiwan will be an important part in ensuring the Chinese meet their commitments.

BARTIROMO: Well, you're right. I mean, you've got the pressure from Taiwan and then you've got the pressure from Hong Kong as well. Look at those pictures of the Hong Kongers in the street, they're holding up the American flag. Look at those picture of the Taiwanese in the street, that ha -- that has not go unnoticed by the Chinese.

HAMMOND-CHAMBERS: Absolutely not. But I would -- I would caution any view that the Chinese would make any significant or any change candidly in their approach to Hong Kong. They appear to be doubling down. They've just appointed a hard-liner as their representative in Hong Kong and with Taiwan too.

We fully expect China to double down on its policies towards Taiwan to constrict and restrict its international space, to undermine its physical security and to coerce it economically.

And our hope is that the Trump administration will look at Taiwan as a key ally in the Indo-Pacific area, to look at a bilateral trade agreement as a priority in Tsai's second term and hope -- and hopefully moving forward here with Mr. Trump and his government.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Rupert Hammond-Chambers. It's great to get your insights, sir. Thanks very much, Rupert.

HAMMOND-CHAMBERS: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Rupert Hammond-Chambers joining us there.

We'll take a break. When we come back, Astros fired, the front office Major League Baseball coming down, one of last year's World Series contenders, the fallout out next.

And then Adam Sandler thanking Mama.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KATHY BATES, ACTRESS: You don't understand me, Mr. Coach Klein, my boy is all I've got left.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. The star's response to his Oscar's snub right after this. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Hong Kong's leader is pledging support. We want to tell you more about this story because we are looking at a new support this morning coming out of -- coming out of the situation. We will get more on that coming up because Hong Kong's support, Carrie Lam is pledging to help the struggling economy. Of course, the economy under severe pressure given the fact that we are seeing really people in the streets, in the millions, day after day. Cheryl Casone with the details now in headlines, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, well said, Maria. And it is a story we've been watching for a while on this program. So Carrie Lam, as you said, she's promising 1.3 billion in relief measures to prop up the economy there.

Now, the region's sinking into recession for the first time in a decade amid months of anti-government protests. And this new spending proposal brings total stimulus to 4.5 billion, just since the summer there. Big story we're watching obviously Maria, is Hong Kong.

We're also watching this, Major League Baseball handing down a major fine. The League has suspended Houston Astros general manager Jeff Luhnow and manager A. J. Hinch for sign stealing. The team owner then fired them both after the announcement yesterday. The League also fining the team $5 million. This after the World Series appearance folks.

Well, only one tiger could win and the LSU Tigers defeated the Clemson Tigers, 42-25 last night, that makes them the new College Football champions. President Trump and the First Lady attended and were greeted with cheers as they walked out onto the field.

Now the president even hung out with actor Vince Vaughn which caused some controversy. Some on social media calling for Vaughn to be canceled.

Well, finally this, no nomination, no problem. Adam Sandler taking the comedic route over his Oscar snub. Here's what he tweeted. Bad news, Sandman gets no love from the Academy. Good news, Sandman can stop wearing suits. Congrats to all my friends who got nominated, especially Mama. He's referring to Kathy Bates there, that's Mama.

A lot of buzz he was going to get nominated Maria, for "Uncut Gems". It was a serious role for him and we talked about it on the show that the -- he had done this amazing job on "Uncut Gems", but Oscar voters didn't seem to care, Maria. Oh, well.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, what do you think?

MCDOWELL: So Kathy Bates responded to that Adam Sandler tweet. And this is he -- she played his mother, Mama, in "The Waterboy". And his name -- here's what Kathy Bates said on Twitter. And I'm reading it in maybe Mama's voice. I love you my Bobby Boucher. You was robbed but Mama loves you. I learned a new urban slang word for you. You the goat, not the one we eat at home, son. That's the response from Kathy Bates. It exploded on Twitter. I retweeted it yesterday. God love her and God -- and God love Adam Sandler.

BARTIROMO: That was very funny. He's one of the best for sure.

All right, quick break, and then when we come back, we are looking at tackling cholesterol, how one company is looking at new ways to help solve the problem. He is here with me at the JPMorgan Healthcare Conference. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are talking about tackling cholesterol, heart disease is the number one killer in the United States every year. That remains the case for years. Millions of Americans are struggling to get their cholesterol levels down. One company now waiting for FDA approval on two drugs to help patients get the results they need with me right now.

Joining me right now is Esperion Therapeutics Incorporated CEO, Tim Mayleben. Tim, it's great to have you. Thanks so much for being here.

TIM MAYLEBEN, CEO, ESPERION THERAPEUTICS INCORPORATED: Good morning, I'm very pleased to be here this morning.

BARTIROMO: When would you expect approval from the FDA on your first drug? Let's talk about that because you've got two new medications. This is a very important topic for so many people out there.

MAYLEBEN: Sure, so we're expecting approval from FDA as early as next month. So this is a very timely discussion for sure.

BARTIROMO: Tell me about the drugs.

MAYLEBEN: So our drugs are -- well, new medicines to lower bad cholesterol and one of the things that I would highlight, in fact, surprises most people is there are 18 million people in the U.S. who still need something additional to help them get their bad cholesterol levels down to a healthy level. And I could break that down for you into two groups. One --

BARTIROMO: Because there are other medications already on the market, right? Like statins, like Lipitor.

MAYLEBEN: I was just going to mention that.

BARTIROMO: That's the most common, right, Lipitor?

MAYLEBEN: Statins, they are great drugs for most people, eight or nine out of 10 people who take a statin do great. But those people need a non-statin means for getting additional LDL cholesterol lowering or bad cholesterol lowering.

But probably the biggest group are people who can't or won't take statins because of side effects and they need a non-statin pill to get their cholesterol to a healthy level. And this is beyond the diet and exercise that we all strive to do, of course.

BARTIROMO: That's terrific. What about diet, how important is that? Obviously --

MAYLEBEN: Diet is fundamental, all of us need to obviously be on a good diet but most of us can't achieve a healthy cholesterol level on diet alone or exercising and that's where medicines like ours would come in.

BARTIROMO: And real quick on your burn rate, you are obviously going to see profitability once you get the -- with the drugs approved. When would profitability happen and what's your burn rate on cash?

MAYLEBEN: So we expect within a couple of years that we could be profitable. As I mentioned earlier, this is a really high unmet need. There's a lot of patients who -- 18 million people who need non-statin ways of lowering their bad cholesterol and we think --

And you know, I would highlight too, this is going to be surprising, but our pills to lower bad cholesterol, they're non-statin pills, will be the first non-statin pills approved to lower bad cholesterol in almost two decades.

BARTIROMO: Wow, that is fantastic. Tim, it's a really important topic. We appreciate you joining us. Thank you so much.

MAYLEBEN: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching the approval process at the FDA, Tim Melben -- Mayleben rather, pardon me.

We want to get right to Jackie DeAngelis, Wells Fargo is out, it is a miss as we're looking at these numbers right here. Jackie, over to you.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you Maria. And Sharp contrast to what we saw with JPMorgan , this is a big miss, $0.93 adjusted in earnings, expectation was $1.12. A revenue miss as well. So both top and bottom line, 19.9 billion is the actual number, the estimate was for 20.14 billion.

Some commentary coming from the CEOs, CFO, rather, saying that some of the expenses were too high, becoming efficient is a top priority here. So this is a stock to watch today, although it's trading a little bit higher right now.

BARTIROMO: All right. Jackie, thank you. We will be right back. Stay with us.
