Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TR0-3YG1-JB20-G3DC-00000-00JPMorgan Chase & Co at BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference - Final2018-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexis110818a11944795.795JPMorgan Chase & Coat BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Lori Ann Beer

JPMorgan Chase & Co.- Chief Information Officer

Conference Call Participants

* Gerard S. Cassidy

RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division - Analyst

* James Hanna

Millennium Management LLC - Portfolio Manager

Presentation

GERARD S. CASSIDY, ANALYST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Thank you, everybody. I'd like to welcome you. I'm Gerard Cassidy, President of the BancAnalysts Association of Boston. This is our 37th Annual Conference that's been held here at this same hotel, believe it or not, for all those years.

Just a couple of housekeeping items for you. For folks that want the WiFi password, it's bancanalyst18. Banc is with a C, not a K. I'd also like to point out that this has been a challenging year with a number of banks canceling at the last minute. And so Flagstar, who's supposed to present tomorrow, had to cancel this week so we'll have an extended coffee break tomorrow morning. And just a reminder, tonight's dinner at the Museum of Science, Bank of America being hosted by Brian Moynihan, Chairman and CEO of Bank of America. Buses will depart from the lobby starting at 5:30 and taking us over there. The last bus will depart about 6:15. Cocktail hour will be from 6:00 to 6:45. Dinner from 6:45 to 8:15, and then buses back here to the hotel.

We're going to kick it off, as we've done in years' past, with JPMorgan, and it's a fireside chat. So we'll get started in a couple of seconds here.

Thank you again, everyone, for joining us. Today, we have Lori Beer. She's JPMorgan's Global Chief Investment Officer. She joined JPMorganin 2014, and prior to joining JPMorgan, she was the Executive Vice President of Specialty Businesses and Information Technology for WellPoint Inc. As many of you know, JPMorganhas one of the largest technology budgets in the U.S. banking system. She manages more than $10 billion with nearly 50,000 technologists in her group. She supports the JPMorgan ChaseRetail, Wholesale and also the Wealth Management businesses. Lori, welcome.

LORI ANN BEER, CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO.: Thank you. Nice to be here.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: We'd like to start off with some questions about scale and competition. And similar to other fireside chats from last year, if there are questions from the audience, please raise your hand as we are talking and we'll get to your question.

Questions and Answers

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Maybe, Lori, you can share with us what are the drivers of scale across the JPMorgan, from a technology standpoint at JPMorgan.

LORI ANN BEER: So when we think about scale across technology, it actually starts with the incredible scale we have in our businesses. So incredible scale, both on the Consumer side as well as the Wholesale side. So when I think about scale, for example, on wholesale payments, we process $5 trillion a day. The scale around the processing, just the infrastructure and environments to process and move that money across the globe, we have to have incredible scale, resiliency and infrastructure to support businesses like that.

And on the Consumer side, being in 50% of all U.S. households really scale on a digital platform, the real front-facing platforms that our customers engage with us. So if you then again transfer that to scale across digital platforms, we also have to have incredible scale around how do we protect not only JPMorgan, but our customers as well. And I think part of it, as we've talked about earlier, we spend over $700 million in cybersecurity alone. So incredible scale around cybersecurity, how we protect our customers. Incredible scale around our systems and solutions.

I think another dimension of scale is the scale of creating new ideas and bringing them to market at scale. So every time we want to innovate on a new consumer feature in our digital lab, the ability to take that from small proof-of-concept where we're vetting that with a consumer into production, the scale [across] the number of digital customers that we have is also another way to think about scale in our business. And then, of course, our data assets. We have incredible scale across our data assets, which is going to be incredibly important as we think about how to use that data in more of the world where we start becoming more of an AI-driven or insight-driven company as well. So those are some ways I think about scale.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: So to follow-up on your comment, how long will it typically take to go from proof-of-concept to actually having a product that's out there for the customers to use?

LORI ANN BEER: From the consumer space, we actually have tried what is typically talked about as agile teams. And these are small teams of individuals that work on very specific features in the digital space. We actually, in our digital labs, one is in New York in Five Manhattan West. We'll bring our customers in, we'll bring consumers in and we'll test the products. So we could actually deploy software on a pretty regular basis. In fact, doing so in the digital environment, we can deploy weekly. And sometimes now when you look at the amount of change that we are implementing across the broadest estate of JPMorgan, it factors into about deploying a change a minute. And that's something we are continuing to increase. Just when you take the total number of changes that we do and think about that, that scale. So a lot of changes going into the environment on a regular basis.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Got you. When you think about your technology budget of close to $11 billion, what do you focus on for that spend? What is the mix involved in, in terms of what strategic versus maintenance?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes, so I think we generally talk about $5 billion we spend as investments, and I'll talk about that in a minute. But what's really important when you think about just the underlying infrastructure and data storage and data centers, day-to-day, our data centers that we have to have just to support our customers every day, there's a significant investment in just that alone. And then when you talk about the investments that we make, we like to think about those that are short-term investments. So how are we transforming the digital, anything that's on a digital paradigm, whether it's to support consumers or an asset wealth management, even some of the client-facing institutional capabilities that we are building. Anything in that digital world where we're trying due to very bring value to customers faster, that is an area where we think more about what are the short-term iterations, as I mentioned earlier. And then there's some of the longer-term strategic investments around how are we transforming our payments business, the underlying engines that transform our payments business, our custody fund services businesses. And we also like to think about investments about research and development. The pace of technology is changing faster than it ever has. And so we're already thinking about what are some of the next-generation capabilities that may, both on the business side, new products like whether it's Sapphire or new products like Finn, whether that's going to be long-term, we want to look at those from an innovation perspective. We also want to think about new emerging technologies. Even quantum computing or partnering with IBM to look at some -- already taking some of the traditional derivative processing algorithms and saying how does that perform on a quantum algorithm? So that's the other extreme of R&D. So customer-facing R&D and also some of the pure, more technology R&D. And so it's always important that we take, say, about 10% of some of the investments that we make and focus on those kinds of things, either business innovation or R&D or technology R&D.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: One of the questions that this group often has to determine or answer is how the banks are differentiating themselves in this area. Obviously, you guys are spending a considerable amount of money. So when you look at it, how do you differentiate yourself from the competition? And how can others remain competitive?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes. So I think so one of the ways that we differentiate ourselves, I think, certainly our customers vote, especially in the consumer side. And if you think about that we are the.

(technical difficulty)

mobile app, also the one that was the highest rating, in J.D. Power, we actually moved up to the #1 position. So certainly, customers, all of our Net Promoter Score across those Chase products, we've seen increases in them. So we are always, especially in a consumer business, looking at how our consumers are voting with the capabilities that we're delivering. So I think business performance clearly as well as consumer experience, and we like to keep those front and center. On the same time, on the wholesale side, our businesses have performed well. And I think it's always constantly looking at where is the market moving. What are the capabilities that are truly competitively differentiating, focusing on putting our investments there and not being afraid of if it's not a competitively differentiating capability, we'll partner for that. We'll use a third-party solution for that. So really being disciplined. And I think a lot of it, if you think about it, everybody's got -- every industry has a digital strategy. Every industry is thinking about how to become AI driven. The key to success beyond the strategy is talent and execution, and that's where we spend a lot of time focusing on, how do we get the top technology, the talent, the best data scientists. How do we make sure that we streamline decision-making so that we can get new capabilities from ideas to the market faster.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Yes, question?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I've got a question about the Wholesale side. If you can talk about which bits of Wholesale is transforming faster, and which bits of Wholesale are most open to disruption, if you're open about it.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: If you can repeat the question?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes, so which bits of Wholesale are transforming faster. Which bits of Wholesale are open to disruption. So some of the areas that we're really focusing around the Wholesale is the transformation of the underlying payments ecosystem. Not necessarily the execution of payments itself, but what are the value-added clients capabilities that you can put around that if we're trying to serve our customers? And so we've put a lot of innovation, not only transforming the underlying engine that processes payments. We've got a lot of work going on in that space, but how does a Treasury Service client -- how do we give them the data and the insights? How do we change the way they manage their accounts? Traditionally in that business, you would think about lots of different accounts, and we're giving them a virtual account structure where they really have, through the use of data, we can actually allow them to break that account up into different views without physically having to have multiple accounts. And so the areas that we're going to watch very carefully, because there's also a lot of regulation on the Wholesale space that also creates not necessarily a lot of the new entrants, if you would say. But we obviously watch the intersection point with our clients. We want to make sure that we're maintaining that rich experience with our clients. [Cost and Fund] services has been another area where we've put a lot of investment into those businesses. And I think you saw we won the BlackRock deal, successfully migrated all their business seamlessly without disruption onto our platforms. At the same time, because we're making the investments and we have the scale, I think a lot of folks in that business are saying, "Do I really want to do some of that middle-office processing? Or do I want to take advantage of the investments we're making?" And you saw some of the next-generation things we're even talking about there, which are starting to expose data analytic capabilities to our customers for them to leverage. So you go from something that was processing a business to creating a platform to start offering new products and capabilities, like data and analytics, to our customers in a different way.

And, of course, the markets businesses. We continue to electronify in those markets businesses and in the equity space. And, again, I think you can track our growth and successes as we come into the top 3 in the equity space. So those will be some of the areas in the wholesale side I would point out. And Wealth Management, I didn't mention but, obviously, we've been spending a lot of time digitizing in the Wealth Management space. You Invest with one of our interesting products where we brought the scale of the platforms together, our consumer platform with Wealth Management, created a new experience for consumers that brought You Invest to market.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: If I could just follow up with (inaudible)?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes. So we're very...

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Repeat the question again.

LORI ANN BEER: Oh, sorry. So cash management. Generally, just to paraphrase, clients complain about the speed and the processing of banks when you're going cross-border as well as -- so how are we thinking about that? And also Goldman has been talking about getting into the cash management business. So again, to respond to that. So a couple of things I would say. The historical cash management platforms for us and many banks were more mainframe or more older technology type platforms. We embarked on a journey. We call it Graphite, which we were building the modern architecture, cloud-based architecture. And one of the reason that's critically important is if you look at the flow of how money moves and payments, it's very spiky. So it fits -- if you think about -- one of the benefits of a cloud-based architecture is that it allows you to only consume what you need. And so if I'm only consuming if it's flatlined, and then it spikes up and I only need to consume, compute or infrastructure at those peaks, it actually allows me to reduce the cost of how I process a payment transaction, so that's the cost aspect of it. If you think about all the work around real-time payment in the U.S., that also, given some of that regulation, is also -- on the modern platform we rebuilt how we thought about processing and payments. The other thing you have to think about when you think about the core cash management capabilities is all the supporting processes around it. So fraud, for example. We've seen an increase in wholesale payments in the fraud space. And so one of the things we've done through the use of technology is how do we get smarter at being able to detect? This is actually a place we're applying machine learning, detect a real fraud from white noise. Because again, from a customer's perspective, paying their supplier across the globe, they don't want us to necessarily slow down the payment. But the other processes we have to wrap around that are fraud, sanctions, anti-money laundering. And so not only do you have to innovate the process of processing a payment, but how you actually transact across border and how you support all those supplemental processes as well. And I think Goldman's getting into cash management because there's a great opportunity there, and we see it too. And we feel really good about how our technology is positioning and also growing those -- as you can see, our numbers in those businesses -- growing those businesses as well. And those are rich, deep customer experiences. And the key for us there beyond -- similar to consumer. Not just similar to consumer, because you're right. Consumer trends set the expectation in these institutional wholesale businesses, which is they want real-time data. They want it at speed and that's some of the things we're doing as we innovate even how we think about payment. So we hear the term API thrown out, but it's really about how do you more directly connect with your clients. So think about a case where a client may have SAP, and through their SAP platform, they want to process the payment. Instead of having a back office to enter the payment into JPMorgan, we can directly connect through an API. And that makes it much more of a seamless experience and allows them to take out some of the back-office processing that they have to support. And so those are just some of the examples and ways. So I think, obviously, as Goldman loves to expand the breadth of their businesses, they're looking at cash management as one opportunity. We have the benefit of having significant scale in that business already, so that as we're able to do these innovations, we're able to then apply them at scale across our customer base and that's also allowing us to acquire new customers as well.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Speaking of payments, obviously, Zelle has been very successful by the banks that have introduced it. Does Zelle -- which is a consumer P2P as we all know, is there any application for Zelle on the commercial side that you see down the road?

LORI ANN BEER: Looking -- there's always sort of -- I think time will tell how much that will take place versus -- there are a little, fewer different characteristics, but again, I think those are some of the ways that we can facilitate more direct payments across. And I think if we remain focused on feeding that and making it a seamless process -- but I think time will actually tell in terms of -- I think companies certainly are looking at peer-to-peer payments in the business-to-business space. But again, we are -- we have a lot of the rails that are there today, so we can also continue to think about how we want to innovate around that.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Great. One of the other questions we often wrestle with is how, obviously, you've got bank competitors in this technology area, but how do you think about disruption from the fintech companies and other nontraditional financial companies?

LORI ANN BEER: Here's the way we think about it. Because a lot of these fintech companies are parts of our ecosystem today. So if you think about some of the examples, as we've been working on transforming our mortgage experience, deeply integrated in that is something called Roostify, and that's a fintech company. As we try to simplify the billing in our commercial banking businesses, we partnered with a company called Bill.com. So many of these companies -- and why do we look at them and how do we make those choices? Because I think that's important to understand. Fintechs are very good at taking a simple problem and simplifying it. And a problem that has been a consumer or customer-facing challenge and just streamlining and simplifying it and focusing on that and speed. Speed because they have a little bit more of a greenfield technology environment. The challenge they often face is size and scale, so especially the size and scale of JPMorgan, and understanding the complexity of the regulatory environment. So just to give you an example, when you think about payments, somebody trying to come in to the Wholesale payment space, we have over 200 regulators that regulate that business. So the complexity and the size and scale of trying to deliver something new without understanding the regulatory implications around things like sanctions, money laundering, et cetera as well is really highly complex. And then understanding also how to achieve size and scale when you're dealing with the numbers. So fintechs for us are an opportunity, sometimes, to put it as part of our end-to-end customer experience and deliver solutions, such as mortgage, as I mentioned, with Roostify. And sometimes we bring them inside. We have a program called Fintech In-Residence. We also noticed this problem. By the way, given we're an investment bank, we think a healthy fintech ecosystem is also really important to grow new companies as well. And many times, if they work for us in part of our ecosystem, we can help those companies scale. But our Fintech In-Residence program was created because we saw these challenges around how do I understand the size and complexity of JPMorgan. How do I understand the regulatory requirements that also may surround that? So we actually bring the fintech inside our walls. They're generally very early-stage companies. We put our technology and senior business leadership around them. We allow them access into our data and technology environment, obviously, with all the right controls in place. And then we help them incubate. They maintain their IP. We choose, ultimately, if we want to invest. And we had 1 company, it's the company called Mosaic that actually went through our Fintech In-Residence that ultimately we deployed in production. Sometimes we decide, like WePay, that it was such a differentiating capability that we wanted to acquire them. And in that scenario, we acquired WePay. Sometimes we just choose to invest.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: One of the other questions that we wrestle with is how do you attract and retain tech talent at a bank when you're competing against the tech companies like Facebook and Google and others? How do you keep those people or how do you attract them?

LORI ANN BEER: We actually are very fortunate that we're able to attract a lot of technology talent. You can imagine with the numbers that we talked about and the fact that our technology investments have been growing, that we hire a lot of talent on an annual basis. One of the things that has been really interesting, when I think about the top senior levels in the technology organization that we've been hiring, about 25%, sometimes that swings up a little bit higher, are coming from technology companies. So there is actually a myth that we can't hire from technology companies. In fact, the in AI space, since we're very early stage at taking some of the capabilities we have there and scaling them more broadly, we were able to bring a top executive from Google, Apoorv Saxena, that's helping us build out our frameworks. And when you think about Apoorv, you think about this other talent of why they would want to join us. When you're at a tech company, it's generally focused on a few products, but they don't necessarily have the data and they don't necessarily have the scale [as] JPMorgan. So for some people that talk about why they came to JPMorgan, it's really about, I want to solve a really hard -- technologists are generally wired to wanting to create value, a purpose. How do I solve a really hard problem. We have a lot of those really hard problems to solve. We have the data. And at a company like JPMorgan, there's generally 2 kinds of technologists; those that like to create the next technology and those that like to apply it. We actually have both use cases. Sometimes like our Quorum product, we actually have created technology. And other times, of course, we have many applications of applying it. So I think the bigger thing we focus on is how do we keep the talent. So when you think about the top talent in the technology space and the really hot field at cybersecurity. Again, the investments we make and the partnerships we have with all the -- the government are really interesting problems for those in the cybersecurity space. Cloud, cloud skills, data scientists and AI. So we have very special programs around how we attract, retain and develop that type of talent. But that's really -- and talent is so critical. Success in technology, it really -- at the end of the day, technologists are creators of the products and solutions for us. So talent is one of the #1 focuses for us.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Yes?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I've got a question. Before the (inaudible)?

LORI ANN BEER: Not a revenue center, but we absolutely impact revenue from that perspective. So a couple of things. So $10.8 billion is what you heard from us from Investor Day is what we spent. In terms of -- we made a significant investment this year year-on-year, and there were a couple of reasons for that, which allowed us to put more like $5 billion towards creating new capabilities. We wanted to accelerate into the building out of our digital capabilities, accelerating our payments transformation, custody fund services and make sure that we are making the right investments on things like data as we prepare for -- I mean, the real oil that fuels AI is all about the data. And so really making sure we're getting ahead of understanding the information and data we need to have more of an insight-driven business going forward. So we were very thoughtful about the investments that we wanted to put into this year, but that I would say what's a little bit of a bump. As you think about going forward, I think -- when we're building out data centers, we've got a lot of investments that will continue, but I don't think you -- I think you'll see generally in the same ballpark in that at our Investor Day, we'll share more details. We're still working through the budgeting process now. The thing that I would say is every year, we are able to, through technology, find a lot of efficiencies. So whether that's for Gordon in the consumer business, these things -- you kind of have to connect the dots through these things. So as more and more of these transactions, whether you're talking about an ATM, which has really become a banking kiosk, or in a branch, more of those transactions have become digital. So team has been able to optimize his workforce and operations. Even though the digital cost might have gone up, he's actually been able to bring his operational cost. Now his cost of acquiring a new customer -- it's like, as he talks, it's almost pennies to nothing, right? And so the way I think to think about it is -- and if you look at custody and fund services or some of the Wholesale business in payment, those businesses or equities, those businesses have grown. And a lot of the reason for their growth is a lot of the investments that we've made in technology that are pulling through. We try to be very disciplined. As you look at cloud, for example, over time, a hybrid cloud strategy, which means we are using infrastructure. Cloud really is just servers in our data center. It really isn't much more mysterious than that, but it allows you to get scale. So we can scale inside our 4 walls as we consume infrastructure. Cloud just gives you another way to share that scale more in a multitenant kind of environment. And so as we consume more infrastructure, because the more you want to do with data, the more you want to do with AI, you're actually needing more ability to process. Rather than building that up in those cases on the inside of our walls, that allows us to use the resources you have in a cloud-like environment. And so I think one of the ways to look at it is business-outcome based. What's the marginal cost to add a new customer as we look at digital account opening? How are we performing and growing businesses? What is the over -- how are our customers rating us from a Net Promoter Score of an overall experience? Because a lot of that is being brought together to the investments in technology.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Yes, over here.

JAMES HANNA, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, MILLENNIUM MANAGEMENT LLC: It's Jimmy Hanna. So I'm trying to (inaudible)?

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Can you repeat the question?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes, so really the question's around go a little bit deeper on some of the things you're doing to continue to optimize the investments, the thing that I alluded to, and what our sort of some of the next things that we should be thinking about. Let me start with saying -- I was just out in the Valley about a month ago. The pace of change of technology is changing more than -- actually, the paradigm is shifting a bit. It's changing faster than we've ever seen it. So the one way I would look at it is the ball is constantly moving in terms of new technologies coming to the market that allows us to lower the cost of processing on infrastructure. What's allowing this ability to do AI now, AI has been around forever. I always remind people, it's been around since before I was born. What's matured is actually some of the machine -- some of the algorithms is maturing and they're being democratized. So I can go out on to Google and use TensorFlow, just as an example, and get access to machine learning. Because I can use the cloud, I can do -- I can take my data and I can do that in a much more cost-effective way that I spin up the compute. This is very intensive to do, AI, and spin it down when I don't need it anymore. So it's really driving AI, ML. And now, you actually need more data. You actually need more infrastructure, but what's actually allowing you to do that at a reasonable cost is the convergence of better technologies around the data, better technologies around the cloud, companies -- large companies getting comfortable to have a hybrid strategy where I use some internal capabilities but I can also use the same ones that are available to any fintech or emerging companies. So you what I'm seeing? The paradigm's shifting. And so the average lifespan of technology is actually reducing. And it's really actually a positive thing in the sense that there's constant innovation around. So I don't think we would say that we're ever going to be done. Some of the things that we're focusing on in the short term is we are definitely focusing on the infrastructure space. How do you take some of the traditional ways they consume infrastructure and you move to a hybrid cloud paradigm? Remember, cloud is just servers in a data center, but what I am really talking about is instead of the old days where you ran an application on a physical piece of infrastructure, you now share infrastructure. Before, from a -- if I was a software engineer, right, it actually becomes agnostic to physically where my software is running. But what does that translate into, the efficiency of my ability to run it is increasing, but the model's getting complicated to figure out. Do you see what I mean? That's what I'm just trying to say. The paradigm is shifting because companies used to have data centers full of servers. And so one of the things you got to think about is it also helps drive speed. Now I don't have to wait to stand up a data center. If I want to do an innovation, I can just open up -- so you have to balance the cost with how it's also helping accelerate the speed of innovation. And I think in the shorter term, the technology you're going to see that help the most is AI, machine learning, which includes many paradigms like natural language processing, et cetera. So that's one way to think about it. So we're still looking. I would say we focus a lot on building out platforms. So let me give you an example. When we -- we were able to build Finn in 6 months or less because Finn was built on the Chase Mobile platform. We created a new digital bank solution targeted at the millennial. Still really in its innovation R&D phase, if you will, but we were able to build a lot of that based on the core capabilities we had in Chase Mobile. So if you think about it, even though Finn has a really creative user design, when I'm looking at debt account balance, it's actually calling the same transaction the Chase Mobile. So think about that leverage and reuse. So the other paradigm that's shifting in technology is the building out of platforms. You hear them call it building out of micro-services. We used to build technology, in the older days, of this big -- you hear monolithic platforms. Now everything is being broken down into components and services, but that allows the speed of innovation to create a new customer experience. That's what technology companies, like an Amazon, is really good at, right? They take the core problem, they break it down. They're able to stitch a new customer experience together, and that's the path we're going down on too. So as we continue to do that work, as we continue to -- so it's less -- you'll hear us talk less about application consolidation. It's more about how do you build those strategic micro services. So when I want to build the next Finn or the next You Invest, You Invest was the same way, built on assets we already have that serves other customer purposes. That's the leverage of platform. That's the leverage of scale. Does that help?

GERARD S. CASSIDY: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (inaudible) we often hear is that how can a regional bank compete with JPMorgan (inaudible).

LORI ANN BEER: It actually -- from -- if you look at it from -- so the question is, talk a little about the disadvantages. And one of the notions was for regional banks, it's hard to compete. You could also argue, if you think about APIs and open banking and cloud, et cetera, it could level the playing field. But one interesting thing where it has changed, if you thought historically, if I needed to do a big application rationalization to get to the strategic state, I'll use payments again, we would have typically -- here's a target state -- here's a system. We're going to shut this system down. We're going to migrate it, and you had those [Big Bang] system migrations. It actually allows us to do the same thing. By applying those types of architectures, it allows us to isolate the brownfield, if you will, and more quickly deliver. I don't have to wait to do a system migration before I can start delivering new customer capabilities, and that's exactly, in some of the spots around payments and custody and fund services, we were able to innovate while we were doing migrations. And the goal is obviously how do you make those migrations seamless and transparent? When I think about the smaller players, certainly for a fintech or smaller regional player, you'll probably see them more aggressively go to the cloud or go to some of these other capabilities. The other pieces that I think are also critically important -- this is a business of trust. So the investments that they can afford to make in things like cybersecurity, the scale, the talent. We can compete on talent with some of the big tech companies. Some of the smaller players can't. One of the things that we're really focused on is making sure we can push decision-making down to the right level. So how do you find that balance of an organization that has incredible scale? That they too can push appropriate decisions down, so those teams can move as quick as those digital teams that I talked about. Those are the things that we're really focusing on. How do we set the right framework so decision making can happen at the speed, so that we can innovate at the speed we need to for our customers.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: 15 years ago, we started a lot of it. It was all centered on cross-selling. And one of our customer add was (inaudible).

LORI ANN BEER: So the question is we used to talk a lot about cross-selling, and in the shorter term, I'm paraphrasing again, but in the shorter term, we focused a little bit more on building the rails, the digital, the security, all those kinds of things and is that still happening around knowing your customer and knowing the full set of their capabilities? And the answer is actually yes, it is. And so historically, when you thought about being in 50% of U.S. households with Chase products, we're not necessarily in 50% -- we're not in 50% U.S. households with every product. And even think about -- when you think about that customer experience, when we're trying to certify that someone has the credit, whether it's for an auto loan, credit card, et cetera, we can really transform the way we think about it. We actually have been investing, and again, this is important for multiple reasons, but one of the reasons is for the one that you mentioned. It's also important we start talking about leveraging our data in the AI world. But we're actually creating like a One Chase. So what is all the data you know about Lori Beer? And so when I go to engage with you, you understand my credit worthiness. You understand what might be the next best product that's relevant to me, not the advertisement that's coming across the banner, but what's a relevant product to me. Because the trend that's actually happening, which is why we need to understand these rich data insights about an individual, both internal and publicly available information, is an expectation that's a richer, personalized experience. And one of the ways, whether you're talking on the consumer side or the wholesale side, you can deliver a richer personalized experience, whether it's creating products, managing your products, et cetera, is about the leverage of data and knowing about you and exposing that. One of the reasons we try to seed the team with some of these resources I talked about earlier, when you look at some of these big tech companies, they're really good at that. And part of it is because they were built greenfield. And one of the things that they did was really understanding the data at every interaction point with the consumer, regardless of product. And that's what we really have been building to facilitate a richer, personalized experience going forward.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: We have time for one last question. Yes?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (inaudible)?

LORI ANN BEER: Yes. So a couple of questions in there. One is it seemed like organizations, big organizations like us, used to want to run everything on the inside? We went through that phase too. Now with public cloud and the maturing of that, are we open to running production workloads on the public cloud? And how do we think about that? And what does that do to the cost structure over time? The one reason, just to give you a little bit more color, we actually do run production workloads on the public cloud today. So -- but we don't for highly confidential data yet. And one of the things, and this is the way we actually work the technology ecosystem, we work very closely with those cloud providers. We visit them regularly. We talk to them. We strategize because we want to make sure that the security controls, our minimum control requirements, can be met. The great thing about at that is because the cloud providers are actually getting it. What they're hearing is big companies are not going to bet on 1 cloud provider. We are going to want the optionality. Remember, the future state as we think about it is the software engineer or the person consuming the technology shouldn't actually have to worry about physically where it's running. And so I want to actually also be able to move some of my workloads across providers to spread it out across those 3 big public cloud providers. By the way, they're building different capabilities too. And if I wanted to take advantage of the fact that Google is going deep in data and that's going to align to my AI strategy, it may change that we innovate there first and then decide to bring it in. So it actually changes the paradigm of how we think about this. So when you think about it, it is a hybrid cloud strategy and a multi-cloud strategy meaning we will still have big data centers for some of our workloads. We haven't gotten comfortable yet. We're never going to push everything -- oh I should never say never. But we're not at a point now in our strategy that we're going to push everything out to the public cloud. What we're really trying to do is take advantage of what's happening there from an innovation perspective. The cost leverage of only consuming what I need -- I can build a smaller footprint, right, as we go to our strategic data centers and leverage when I need. So when we run things like CCAR today, it leverages my internal resources. When it spikes, we can actually burst out to the public cloud. It shuts down. I didn't have to have the headroom on those inside machines to support that. And so that's just a whole different paradigm around how that works. But the one thing which I always caution everybody, especially with AI coming, I think the need for compute, especially with AI models and things going forward, that's more intense. But the good thing is we're trying to mature these capabilities so we can optimize the value of the public cloud as that comes on board versus building all that on the inside too. So that's the way I think about.

GERARD S. CASSIDY: With that, we've run out of time. Lori, great job. We really appreciate you being here. Thank you.

LORI ANN BEER: Thank you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y1B-MCR1-JCMN-Y0CV-00000-00JPMorgan Chase: First Among Equals2020-01-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJPMorgan Chase: First Among EqualsChris M Skinner

Jan 20, 2020( The Finanser by Chris Skinner: http://thefinanser.com/ Delivered by Newstex) When The Financial Times does what they're good at - covering financial markets and not technology - then they do produce some fascinating content. Case in point is the latest coverage of JPMorgan Chase's (JPMC) 2019 results. The bank's latest results are stunning, with the fourth-quarter profit soaring to $8.52 billion or $2.57 a share. A year earlier, the bank reported a profit of $7.07 billion or $1.98 per share. It is now one of the most valuable banks in the world (after the Chinese[1]), with a market capitalisation of almost half a trillion dollars ($430 billion), and builds upon a wildly successful decade of market growth, beating all of the banks' US peers.

https://thefinanser.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FTMarCap.jpg Source:The Financial TimesThe Financial Times had two exceptional columns reviewing JPMorgan's success. The first looked at the US banks overall[2], and tracked the fact that the past decade since the financial crisis has been kind to American banks (unlike European banks). America's largest universal and investment banks - Bank of America, Citibank, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo - have more than doubled their collective profits since 2009. You could put this down to the strength of the American economy, which has seen eleven years of continuous growth, but its more than this. For example, the big banks are eating the small banks deposits, with Bank of America and JPMorgan increasing deposits by 4% and 6% respectively last year, even as economic growth slowed. The FT quotes[3] Mike Mayo, an analyst at Wells Fargo: 'The moats around the largest banks are as deep as they've ever been. That's due to technology and marketing skills, but also due to new regulations that require a good degree of overheads.' And The FT continues: 'Remarkably, banks' return on equity remains near the levels of a decade ago, despite rules requiring them to hold much more capital. Cost-control initiatives have played a key role in this. Bank of America is again a good example: its overhead costs last year were $65bn, $10bn lower than five years earlier, despite higher revenues. 'A decade ago, too, there was much concern that financial start-ups and big tech companies would invade industry territory. But marketplace lenders, social media platforms and other tech groups have, for the most part, ended up partnering with banks rather than displacing them and why has JPMorgan outperformed all the others by such a large margin? It came out of the crisis with fewer holes in its balance sheet than Citi or Bank of America, and unlike Wells Fargo, has not had any major scandals. In banking, more capital and fewer mistakes are a potent combination.' Nice. There's then an opinion piece by Tom Braithwaite that expands on JPMC's strengths. Jamie Dimon is causing headaches for rivals — and himself[4] One line in Tom's piece really strikes the point home about how Europe is languishing and America, particularly JPMC, are steamrolling over the banking world: 'JPMorgan's market capitalisation of $430bn is higher than the combined value of Barclays, Socit Gnrale, Standard Chartered, UniCredit, Credit Suisse, UBS, BBVA, Royal Bank of Scotland, Crdit Agricole, ING and Lloyds.' Wow! Just wow! OK, JPMC is worth less than Apple, Google, Amazon, Tencent and Microsoft, but is worth a lot more than the largest group of European banks. It makes you realise that Europe's banks are now valued about as much as half a Stripe if they're lucky. Shoot. And Tom builds on the earlier point, that it's not just about America's economy. 'The comparative strength of the US economy is helpful, but it cannot be the only explanation. After all, Mr Dimon is also embarrassing Wall Street rival Goldman Sachs, whose once stellar profitshave dimmed[5]and whose new gambits, such asconsumer banking[6],are yet to pay off. 'You can point to JPMorgan's boost from consolidation. Mr Dimonswooped on Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual in 2008. But he was only in a position to strike those deals because he had protected his own balance sheet. And if crisis-era acquisitions were all that mattered then Barclays, which picked up the core of Lehman Brothers, and Bank of America, which bought Merrill Lynch and Countrywide, would be worldbeaters too.' In other words, it's all down to having a strong balance sheet, good management, great leadership and a focus upon innovation and regulation in equal balance. Meantime, for all the bleating about disintermediation, disruption, digital transformation and revolution, JPMC is a bank that truly is showing how to deal with all these challenges and find a strategy for success. No wonder they are one of the stars of my new book Doing Digital[7]. Finally, in a third piece[8], The FT interviews Brian Moynihan, the CEO of Bank of America (BoA) over the past decade. Brian doesn't like BoA being compared with JPMC, even though the latter has a valuation a third more than BoA today when, ten years ago, they were neck and neck. He claims that this is because JPMC was far better capitalised as it came out of the crisis although, imho, that's not the answer. I always remember reading a research report in the 2000s about BoA's amazing success at turning customers online when many were struggling. This was due to a time-series analysis the bank performed which discovered little online banking usage in the first six months, as customers didn't trust it. After nine months it picked up however and, after eighteen months, online was the primary customer focus. This led to BoA becoming an internet banking lead in the USA (see end note). Today, BoA is lagging behind JPMC in online, digital and mobile banking. Brian Moynihan: 'We have 38 million digital customers and 29 million-plus mobile customers who grew 10 per cent year over year.' JPMC has almost 52 million digital and 37 million mobile customers. No wonder Mr. Moynihan reckons that Bank of America can double their market share[9]:'Our market share in consumer is probably 12, 13, 14 per cent, depending on who counts . . . The reality is, you could double that.' And they will do this digitally. Not by opening more branches.OPTIONAL READING This is a TowerGroup (now part of Gartner) research note from 2004, written by George Tubin. How Bank of America became the biggest US online bank Coming out of the dot-com boom, brick-and-mortar businesses across all industries were forced to reexamine their online strategies. After the mad dash to gain market share and 'online real estate,' the real economic underlying value of the online channel came under considerable scrutiny. This question was especially difficult for the banking industry with its highly complex delivery system, organizational structure, product mix, and geographical reach. In short, measuring the economic value of the online banking channel is difficult. Unlike most other top-tier US banks, Bank of America was determined to confront this issue head on. Realizing that measuring the profitability or return on investment of the online banking channel directly was fraught with problems, the bank decided to approach this issue from a customer-centric perspective. Rather than trying to determine the value of the online channel in isolation, the bank chose to determine the value of customers that used the online channel compared to those that did not. Online Banking Time Series Analysis Although the approach and results of Bank of America's online customer profitability study have been publicly available for some time, a brief description is warranted for those who may not have had the opportunity to review it. After evaluating approaches to determine the nagging question of profitability of the online channel, Bank of America took a unique approach to determine the answer. Rather than simply comparing the profitability of online customers as a segment to that of offline customers, the bank performed a time series analysis that tracked both online and offline customers over a period of time. Online customers were compared to control groups of customers who were not online, based on several measurements taken over an extended period. To isolate the effects of the online channel on the overall customer relationship, control groups were chosen that had demographic and tenure attributes similar to those of the online group. This analysis was structured to isolate the effects of online banking on customer profitability. Bank of America started collecting this data in late 1998 and completed the first time series analysis in the middle of 2000. The study showed that, after going online, customers actuallybecamemore profitable than their control group counterparts. Put another way, the study determined that online banking led to higher customer profitability. Although online bill pay customers cost more to serve, these costs were more than offset by an increase in account retention rates and an expansion in the number of products used. But the most significant profit driver for online customers proved to be an increase in account balances. That is, the interest income derived from higher account balances produced the most significant lift in customer profitability. After nine months, profitability of the online groups was 5% lower than the profitability of control groups, but by the end of the 31-month period, online customers became 21% more profitable than their offline counterparts. Results of Bank of America Online Bill Pay Customer Time Series Analysis (2001)   https://thefinanser.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Exhibit-2.jpg To gain the backing of the entire organization, Bank of America's e-commerce unit realized that it should share the online profitability findings widely. Not only did the bank communicate its findings across the entire organization, but Ken Lewis, Bank of America's CEO, actually presented the bank's findings outside the company. In fact, the presentation is publicly available on the company's Web site. The results of the time series analysis formed the crux of how the bank makes decisions about online banking, including the decision to offer free online banking and bill pay. As a result of this and subsequent studies, Bank of America decided to aggressively pursue projects that would increase online banking adoption and usage across its customer base. Subsequent time series studies with different customer groups have shown similar results. As the technology infrastructure was being improved to support the bank's anticipated growth, the organization focused on overcoming customers' potential misperceptions or objections to online banking. Deeply committed to Quality and Six Sigma approaches, the bank's management believed that by really listening to customers and understanding their needs, the bank could focus on implementing programs to improve customer satisfaction and delight its customers. The organization believed that this approach would lead to broader relationships and, hence, higher customer profitability. The bank used a Six Sigma approach known as 'Voice of the Customer' to understand what customers really wanted in an online banking application and to prioritize projects aimed at removing barriers to customer adoption and usage. This approach allowed the bank to target its marketing and development efforts to areas that would produce tangible results. Further, the bank shared findings from the Voice of the Customer project across the organization to provide a common understanding among the thousands of bank associates. After carefully planning, a Voice of the Customer project involves gathering both solicited and unsolicited input from the customer base. Solicited input came from several sources, including focus groups, online questionnaires, and mail surveys. Unsolicited input came from e-mail, mail, contact centers, and branches. To obtain a comprehensive view of the customer base, the bank ensured that input came from both online and offline sources. Reams of data were then organized and scrubbed to provide a good basis for Voice of the Customer analysis. As with any data analysis project, the first step was to ensure the validity and accuracy of the data to be analyzed. Voice of the Customer analysis proved fruitful The bank was able to translate and prioritize customers' objections to online banking into several categories but discovered that four objections were the most significant barriers to adoption. By concentrating on these top objections or barriers, the bank was able to implement programs and policies that directly addressed the areas that would eventually provide the most benefit to their clients, and henceforth, the bank. Although the bank continues to conduct conducts Voice of the Customer projects and share the analysis across the organization, on its road to 11.2 million customers, the bank needed to overcome these four primary barriers to online banking: Barrier 1: 'Online Banking Costs Too Much' Today, it is fairly common practice for large retail banks to offer online banking for free. However, this was not the case just a few short years ago. Most banks would charge a monthly fee for online banking or online bill payment, or provide it for free with high minimum balance requirements. In May 2002, Bank of America announced it would join the budding movement to provide online banking with bill pay free of charge. This decision removed one of the largest obstacles that kept customers away from banking online: cost. Thanks to the bank's sheer size and market impact, almost the entire industry followed suit and began offering free online banking with bill pay. However, many of the other banks did not fully grasp the impact of this move. They had not performed any kind of detailed customer profitability analysis and did not know the value of their respective online banking programs. Most banks feared that online banking was unprofitable for them to begin with and that giving it away would only make it more unprofitable. But, because the largest retail bank in the US was giving the service away, other banks felt forced to provide the service for free as well. They hoped that Bank of America knew what it was doing and that providing free online banking would somehow provide a benefit. Indeed, Bank of America knew exactly what it was doing when it made the decision to go free. Its time series analysis proved that customers became more profitable as a result of going online. The elimination of online banking and online bill pay fee income was far outweighed by the increased profitability derived from customers banking online. Barrier 2: 'Online Banking Is Not Safe' Online security continues to be a top concern for many consumers, especially in light of the many phishing and spoofing scams that have surfaced across the financial services industry. Even before the recent spate of phishing attacks, consumers were wary of conducting financial transactions online. Consumers continue to believe that simply signing up for online banking could enable a fraudster to gain access to one's username and password and thereby gain access to the account, either by intercepting information during an online banking session or by simply 'hacking' the username and password. Consumers believe that without an online account set-up, they are not vulnerable to this type of fraud. They are unaware that thieves can use stolen identification information to establish an online banking account. In order to make customers more comfortable with banking online, the bank realized it had to stand behind its product. Bank of America was one of the first institutions to offer its customers an online banking guarantee, providing '$0 Liability' for any unauthorized activity originating from online banking. Customers, of course, are required to protect their usernames and passwords, not leave their computer unattended during an online banking session, and promptly notify the bank of any unauthorized activity. Barrier 3: 'Online Banking Is Difficult' Bank of America realized that many consumers stay away from online banking because they fear making mistakes in performing financial transactions. Ordering the wrong book is one thing; accidentally sending your mortgage payment to a shell company in Dubai is another. The bank continues to focus considerable effort on simplifying their customers' online experience from enrollment to transaction execution to cross-sales. In a recent review of top online banking providers, TowerGroup found Bank of America to be clearly in the top tier (along with Citibank and Wells Fargo). The top providers not only provide a higher level of features and functions than their peers but also seem to have a knack for providing highly usable and intuitive user interfaces. Barrier 4: 'There's No Real Need to Bank Online' Other than simple ATM withdrawals, consumers traditionally looked to branch and contact center agents to execute their financial transactions. The checkbook remains a sacred relic and check writing a venerated practice among US consumers. Suggesting that bank clients stop using their dear and trusted friends at the local branch and deprecating the check register are considered heresies in many circles. Yet, online banking promises to replace or supplement traditional banking methods with simple, real-time, 24-hour banking. According to TowerGroup primary market research, approximately 93% of all consumer banking customers continue to visit a bank branch at least once a month. Bank of America realized that the most effective way to convince its client base to try online banking was to do so in their branches. But, to promote online banking in the branches would require the branch staff to fully understand and support this effort. If consumers sensed that the branch staff was not enthusiastic about online banking, or worse, unwilling to use online banking themselves, the response would be clear: 'If bank employees don't use it, why should I?' To encourage the branch associates to use online banking, the bank ran several enticing promotions with prizes, including a PT Cruiser and $10,000. Not surprisingly, in a short time over 80% of all branch associates were using online banking on a regular basis. Because of the genuine enthusiasm for online banking exhibited by the branch staff, in-store enrollment for both existing and new customers showed a marked improvement. Today, the bank generates a greater proportion of new online banking enrollments via the banking centers than via the Web, with the majority of customers being new to the bank. Posted on: January 20, 2020 [ 1]:   https://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/122315/worlds-top-10-banks-jpm-wfc.asp [ 2]:   https://www.ft.com/content/5cce1b7c-387d-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4 [ 3]:   https://www.ft.com/content/5cce1b7c-387d-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4 [ 4]:   https://www.ft.com/content/63e6d4e8-3851-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4 [ 5]:   https://www.ft.com/content/667cf3f8-37cb-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4 [ 6]:   https://www.ft.com/content/145467d6-da1b-11e9-8f9b-77216ebe1f17 [ 7]:   https://www.amazon.com/Doing-Digital-Lessons-Chris-Skinner/dp/9814841439/ref=sr_1_3?keywords=doing+digital...=1576054336...8-3 [ 8]:   https://www.ft.com/content/a1a25664-38ff-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4 [ 9]:   https://www.ft.com/content/6e0491b8-396e-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5ST8-JXD1-DYX4-046K-00000-00JPMorgan finds lead in tech talent tango;Bank hires tens of thousands of tech specialists annually, transforming its customer interaction and bringing about greater personalisation2018-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:40ZLexisNexisBANKING & FINANCETop StoriesJPMorgan finds lead in tech talent tangoBank hires tens of thousands of tech specialists annually, transforming its customer interaction and bringing about greater personalisationJamie Lee , JPMorgan finds lead in tech talent tango

Singapore

ABOUT 40 per cent of the senior technology specialists hired by JPMorgan each year have come from technology companies, said a top executive from the bank.

This trend may surprise, given the rising fear that technology companies are draining talent from banking circles. But to Lori Beer, global chief information officer of JPMorgan, the trend reflects the tide of technology staff who want to solve complex problems in banking, a sector that has the data and the scale to bring large projects to fruition. This contrasts with a more product focus at technology companies, she said in an interview with The Business Times.

The bank is also putting significant investment dollar on the table that can rival Big Tech firms, with its global technology spending hitting some US$10.8 billion this year, and as it hires tens of thousands of tech specialists annually.

With the heavy focus on technology at the bank, there has been greater "digital fluency" within the business segments, she added, as banking units seek out staff such as data scientists to figure out how data can solve specific banking problems.

Ms Beer noted that technology is helping the bank transform the way it interacts with customers, bringing about greater personalisation. Indeed, with the greater use of machine learning, banks such as JPMorgan have been using computer programs that help bankers sieve out the clients that are most likely to take up additional fundraising.

JPMorgan is more actively engaging financial technology companies as well, with Ms Beer pointing to the bank's in-residence programme that has fintech companies sit with the business teams in the bank to develop new solutions. These fintech residents join the bank for six months, and have access to the bank's facilities and systems.

The programme also puts the fintech firms in touch with the regulatory environment of banks, including ensuring that the fintech solutions pass cybersecurity standards. Of the US$10.8 billion spent on technology by JPMorgan, about US$700 million goes to cybersecurity.

"We have about 100 fintech emerging tech pilots at any given time that we're executing, or partnering on," said Ms Beer. "Operating under intensive regulation adds a whole new complexity. We're used to working with that environment - we're very good at managing risks and controls."

Singapore plays a part in JPMorgan's global technology drive.

In Singapore, the number of technology staff at JPMorgan - or technologists, as they are known at the bank - has grown almost 40 per cent since 2013, with Singapore having gone through a "growth cycle" last year in terms of tech hiring, said Ms Beer.

The current tech headcount in Singapore is about 1,200 staff, with the team in Singapore forming a key part of developing the bank's cloud strategy and helping drive adoption globally. The Singapore team has worked on applications used by traders in the service called Symphony - a chat tool backed by top Wall Street banks including JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs that is meant to compete with that from Bloomberg.

Singapore also remains one of the 14 strategic hubs globally for the bank, with some round-the-clock functions anchored in Singapore. Global banks offer "follow-the-sun" support to large clients that have multiple operations in different timezones, as they require services such as 24-hour cashflow management.

There remain broader challenges about technology ahead, with questions still remaining over how machines are being used to process data that may have bias in them, and the impact of that on society.

Meanwhile, while much has been said about the long-term value of blockchain, it remains "an evolving landscape", as Ms Beer noted.

Still, some costs are on corporates' side in the area of innovation. Ms Beer noted that the falling cost of computing has helped to spur greater adoption of innovation such as machine learning among corporates today.

"AI existed before I was born," she quipped. "It's just coming of age."

"We have about 100 fintech emerging tech pilots at any given time that we're executing, or partnering on," says Ms Beer.

urn:contentItem:5X7D-YTK1-JCMN-Y234-00000-00JPMorgan Gets Back Into the Electricity Business2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:40ZLexisNexisJPMorgan Gets Back Into the Electricity BusinessDavid Dayen

Oct 09, 2019( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) Mega-bank JPMorgan Chase, years after being fined over $400 million for manipulating energy markets, is effectively purchasing an electric utility in El Paso, Texas, laundered through an allegedly independent investment fund. The 'owners' of the fund appear to not be owners at all, but members of its board of directors, all of whom have ties to JPMorgan. And 48 executives of the investment fund are actually paid employees of JPMorgan, which is lending out their services.The fund, known as the Infrastructure Investments Fund, or IIF, contends that it is merely 'advised' by JPMorgan. 'It's no secret that there's a relationship there,' says Tyson Slocum of Public Citizen, who has tracked the sale.

'But I've been looking at electric utility mergers for 20 years, and I have never seen anything as convoluted as this.'It's not even necessarily illegal for a bank to purchase an electric utility, though some believe it should be. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 was intended to separate banking and commerce, but decades of Federal Reserve interpretations broke down that wall, allowing banks to justify their ownership of nonfinancial businesses as part of 'merchant banking' activities.An ownership stake in physical commodities, including metals mining, oil and gas drilling, and electricity generation, gives banks tremendous information advantages that can be used to trade for profit. 'If we have three big banks controlling the energy sector, and three big tech companies controlling everything else, then what kind of world are we living in?' asks Saule Omarova, a professor at Cornell Law School who specializes in analyzing linkages[1] between banking and the commercial economy.At issue in this case is El Paso Electric[2], a franchise utility inaugurated in 1901, serving 429,000 customers in the city of El Paso and other parts of Texas and New Mexico. The investor-owned utility has been traded on the New York Stock Exchange[3] for 72 years. In June, El Paso Electric agreed to be taken private in a $4.3 billion deal[4] with IIF. It would continue as an independent system operator, with the same staff.To win the approval of the El Paso City Council, IIF put in sweeteners, including $21 million in credits on ratepayer electric bills (which amounts to only $1.36 per month on people's bills, for three years), charitable contributions, and funds for a local economic-development fund. Though at least one former Texas Public Utility Commission member believes[5] that IIF is still extracting too much profit without enough givebacks, the city council, one of several government entities that needed to approve the merger, seemed poised to rubber-stamp it.At the time, IIF was described in the press as 'JPMorgan's Infrastructure Investment Fund,' though the El Paso Electric press release[6] called it 'an Investment Vehicle Advised by JPMorgan Investment Management.' The $11.3 billion fund has interests in the U.S., Europe, and Australia. El Paso Electric would be its first U.S. electric utility, but it holds 11 other energy and electric-generation companies in its portfolio. It operates like a private equity fund; investors can buy into it and earn dividends and awards as the portfolio companies rise in value. Most of IIF's investors are retirement funds.Slocum, of Public Citizen, was immediately skeptical of the merger. For one, in the application to authorize the merger with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), IIF listed three 'owners' of the fund but never actually named them. A footnote to that application stated that the names were disclosed in a 'confidential attachment' in a separate filing to FERC from nine months earlier. 'Public Citizen lacks access to time travel necessary to intervene and request the contents of a confidential attachment filed 270 days before,' Slocum's organization wrote in an objection[7] to the failure to disclose.Lawyers for El Paso Electric and IIF filed a dismissive response. 'They were like, 'Go F yourself,'' Slocum says. However, the response offhandedly noted that the owners were named in a separate application with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in conjunction with a different purchase. It turned out that document wasn't public either, but the response did name the owners as Rita J. Sallis, Christopher Ward, and Dennis Clarke. Sallis formerly ran New York City's public pension fund[8], the type of investor client that IIF caters to.But the disclosure raised additional questions. In numerous[9] documents[10] filed[11] with the[12] Securities and Exchange Commission[13], Sallis, Ward, and Clarke are described as 'directors' and 'managers' of different entities of IIF. They are also all affiliated with JPMorgan Investment Management, a subsidiary of JPMorgan Chase. 'That seems to indicate that they're no more than a board of directors,' Slocum says.The Nuclear Regulatory Commission application, eventually obtained by Slocum, also includes evidence that these are just directors, not owners. The application states that Clarke intends to 'resign' as an owner at the end of the year, with the others conducting a search for a replacement. 'Owners do not typically resign, and remaining owners do not typically seek a replacement candidate,' Public Citizen wrote in an October 7 filing with FERC.An owner would have exclusive control of the fund, while a board of directors would leave the question of who actually owns IIF open. And if the 'owners' are all affiliated with JPMorgan Chase, it's reasonable to assume that IIF is merely an affiliate. For its part, IIF states on its FERC application that JPMorgan is not an affiliate or parent or merger subsidiary, and not party to the deal.Slocum then found a 2019 PowerPoint presentation IIF made to various cities it was looking to persuade to invest in pension funds. While the presentation insists that JPMorgan Investment Management 'does not own or control' IIF, it states that 'material decisions are made by IIF's independent board of directors in light of recommendations' made by JPMorgan (emphasis mine). The board's existence was never disclosed to FERC; IIF only talked about 'owners.'Furthermore, the PowerPoint notes that a team of 48 individuals provides fundraising, asset management, and acquisition services to IIF (which is practically everything IIF does), and that this team is 'within JPMorgan Investment management solely dedicated to IIF.' That entire team is listed on page 6 of this public presentation[14] IIF made to the city of Fresno, California. One of the team members, Managing Director Landy Gilbert, is named as IIF's managing director[15] in news stories. JPMorgan directors have also spoken on behalf of IIF[16] in public hearings. As Slocum puts it, 'JPMorgan literally staffs IIF.'Slocum believes IIF is trying to have it both ways, while hiding the depth of the JPMorgan relationship from FERC. 'IIF bends over backwards to say we have the best of both worlds, we can access great services by JPMorgan, but we're free and independent of them,' he says. 'JPMorgan is making management recommendations, with some sort of contractual relationship. But hey, independent board, so it's all kosher.'When I described this relationship to Cornell Law professor Saule Omarova, she responded that 'it's sort of straight out of the playbook all these big financial holding companies have been using to acquire commercial businesses.' She added that the financial disclosures are often not granular enough to make out what a bank holding company actually owns or controls, and where there's merely an advisory relationship. 'They're trying to comply on the face with all the regulations, but in reality all it does is create many layers of BS on top of the same business,' Omarova says.Under the Dodd-Frank Act, big banks like JPMorgan can set up or sponsor private equity-style funds, as long as they limit their equity stake in them to no more than 3 percent. But Slocum brings up another factor. In 2013, JPMorgan paid a record $410 million settlement[17] with FERC, over a bank subsidiary charging electricity grids in California and the Midwest 'as much as 80 times the prevailing power prices at certain hours of the day.' The market manipulation yielded $125 million in 'unjust profits.'According to Slocum, 'The understanding in 2013 was that FERC said we're going to go easy on you in exchange for you guys getting out of the physical energy business.' So the obfuscation may be a function of JPMorgan trying to honor that handshake agreement while still buying back into the electricity market.Scooping up El Paso Electric would be lucrative for JPMorgan. Not only are there 429,000 captive customers delivering steady cash flow, but the service territory includes the Permian basin, one of the largest fields for fracking in America. 'Fracking is power hungry,' Slocum says. 'You're hooking up a jet engine to force chemicals and water into that shale formation. El Paso Electric is in a good geographic position to become a pure utility for the Permian.'Slocum wants FERC to hold an evidentiary hearing to get answers on the corporate structure of IIF, the 'ownership' stakes, and any affiliate, financial, and contractual relationships with JPMorgan.Shareholders overwhelmingly approved[18] the El Paso Electric sale in September; regulators in Texas and New Mexico still must sign off, as well as FERC. JPMorgan Chase and IIF did not return requests for comment. The New Mexico attorney general's office, which also has jurisdiction over the deal as a consumer advocate, responded that they were looking into the matter.The Prospect also asked Beto O'Rourke, the presidential candidate and El Paso native, if he had a comment about his hometown electric utility entering into a deal with a large Wall Street bank. O'Rourke's campaign declined to comment.Banks with stakes in commercial businesses increase concentrations of economic power. So do tech companies that are now moving into financial services[19], These corporations effectively build conglomerates with the power to affect market dynamics. For example, if JPMorgan knows that El Paso Electric, or its suite of electricity generation companies, will be surging or shutting down power to the grid, they can use that information in trading in energy markets. On a larger scale, integrated banking and commerce giants can intimidate suppliers, abuse customers, and use their political power to obtain favorable rules.'The business and commerce separation, this principle has been ignored and mocked over the years,' Omarova says. 'But the question of who owns El Paso Electric is actually not so little. It's one example in a big game, and we don't know where it leads.'
