urn:contentItem:5XW8-FKY1-JDVW-N3CT-00000-00JPMorgan recognizes threat from big tech; Morgan Stanley cuts 1,500 staff2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:40ZLexisNexisExclusiveJPMorgan recognizes threat from big tech; Morgan Stanley cuts 1,500 staffShreya Tyagi

Also, Wells Fargo's CEO Charlie Scharf's intense review and scrutiny of the bank's operations has led to distress among employees over potential changes. The transition from Libor to secured overnight financing rate to pick up pace in 2020.

In an interview with CNBC, JPMorgan Chase & Co. co-President Daniel Pinto flagged the potential threat of big tech companies venturing into financial services, calling them "real competitors," especially in the retail banking business. Pinto also mentioned the changes in the trading business and the impact of environmental, social and governance investment strategies. "It's possible that some companies will really struggle to finance themselves, their cost of capital will go to the sky and they may not exist going forward," he said.

At a time when banks around the world are increasingly cutting jobs to save costs, Morgan Stanley is the latest firm to make a year-end efficiency push, cutting about 1,500 jobs, Bloomberg News reports, citing people familiar with the matter. CEO James Gorman said the cuts would account for about 2% of the bank's staff. Across the global banking sector, the layoffs represent the biggest workforce reduction since 2015, according to filings by companies and labor unions, the report added.

Wells Fargo & Co.'s new CEO Charlie Scharf has closely scrutinized the bank's operations since he took over in October, which has led to distress among employees over potential changes, American Banker reports, citing people who asked not to be identified. The prospective changes are related to the firm's strategy, relations with regulators and shuffling executives, among other matters.

The transition from the London interbank offered rate to the secured overnight financing rate is expected to pick up the pace in 2020, with regulators putting more pressure on companies to make the switch ahead of the 2021 year-end deadline, American Banker reports. "And if you think about how much needs to be done, two years is not a lot of time," Lary Stromfeld, a partner with Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, told the publication.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and JPMorgan have adopted ways to keep trading in the $1.2 trillion U.S. repo market while minimizing capital requirements at the end of the year and limiting regulatory controls, the Financial Times reports, citing people familiar with the banks' strategy. Goldman has initiated using derivatives known as total return swaps that carry lower capital requirements than regular repo trades, while JPMorgan has encouraged the use of so-called "sponsored repo" deals. Both Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan declined to comment to the news outlet.

In other parts of the world

Asia-Pacific: China revises securities law; 10 Japanese banks under regulator's watch

Europe: Italy gets more time to plan MPS stake sale; new Danske lawsuit; RBI wins appeal

Middle East & Africa: Qatar moves to bolster law against dirty money; Tunisia holds rate

Now featured on S&P Global Market Intelligence

Fed looks to keep rates steady in 2020, but downside risks remain: The Federal Reserve has signaled it aims to keep interest rates steady in 2020, but lingering downside risks to the economy and below-target inflation figures could force it to ease policy again.

The day ahead

Early morning futures indicators pointed to a higher opening for the U.S. market.

In Asia, the Hang Seng rose 0.33% to 28,319.39, while the Nikkei 225 declined 0.76% to 23,656.62.

In Europe, around midday, the FTSE 100 was down 0.39% to 7,615.18, and the Euronext 100 was down 0.25% to 1,153.68.

On the macro front

The international trade in goods report, the retail inventories report, the wholesale inventories report, the pending home sales index and the Dallas Fed Manufacturing Survey are due out today.

Click here to read about today's financial markets, setting out the factors driving stocks, bonds and currencies around the world ahead of the New York open.

The Daily Dose has an editorial deadline of 7:30 a.m. ET. Some external links may require a subscription. Links are current as of publication time, and we are not responsible if those links are unavailable later.

urn:contentItem:7Y7Y-MNF1-2RY2-929H-00000-00JP Morgan Reports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges China2010-04-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJP MorganReports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges China

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Breaking news this morning. At least 400 people killed and many nor feared dead as the series of strong earthquakes strike Western China. Ten Thousand more are injured according to "State T.V." that's reporting many remained buried under ruble. The initial quake had a magnitude of 6.9 and was followed by several other strong after shocks. Charles McCord will have more on this story later in the show.

Now, we're going to turn to your Fox Business Minute. And some of your top business stories of the day, JP Morganwill give Wall Street an initial read on the big banks when it reports its first quarter numbers this morning, at 7:00 eastern time. The company is expected to post a profit of $2.9 billion or 64 cents a share. We're going to have that report for you live as it breaks here on Fox Business.

Overseas markets rising on a positive report from Intel. That company kicking off earnings season for tech companies in a big way. Shares jumping as much as 4% after profit in the quarter nearly quadrupled. Intel says it got a lift from sales of new chips for computer servers. That's the type of purchases companies had been holding off on during the recession.

And, Toyota will stop selling its 2010 Lexus GX 460 after "Consumer Reports" says people shouldn't buy it. The company asking dealers to pull the SUV until it can do its own test. The magazine says the SUV has an unusually high risk of rolling over. This problem reportedly has to do with the electronic stability control, not the brakes or the gas pedals. FRIEDMAN: Well, the point I was trying to make, Don, is simple that, you know, George Bush approached Afghanistan -- just to simplify it was to say, you know, let's keep things there to a bare minimum. You know, we'll keep Karzai in power, we really don't care what he and his cronies do to rip off the country. Just let our troops operate there and focus on tracking down al Qaeda guys in Afghanistan and Pakistan, and keeping them off balance.

And it was a very kind of realist or near-realist approach. You know, what matters is really our interests, tracking down these guys. We really don't care whether Afghanistan is a well-run country or a poorly-run country. That's an exaggeration, but that was the core approach.

Basically, what happened, though, was that Karzai's misgovernance reached such industrial proportions, that tens of thousands of Afghans turned away from him and said, you know, we actually prefer the Taliban back compared to these guys. And that was kind of when Obama came onto the scene.

Now, you remember during the campaign, Obama really criticized the Bush administration on Iraq and Afghanistan for focussing on values and whatnot, and not our core interests. But basically what Obama has done is flipped it, and his whole policy in Afghanistan is predicated on the point of we have got to clear the Taliban out, then once we do that, we've actually got to deliver good governance to the Afghan people. And only by doing that will they restore their allegiance to the government, join the army, and allow us to get out of Afghanistan without having to worry of al Qaeda coming back.

So, the thing I was pointing out was simply two things. One is, it's really interesting that Obama's now really pursuing a much more idealist, as opposed to sort of hard-core realist, foreign policy in Afghanistan and, by definition, in Iraq. And the corollary to that is -- you know, a lot of people criticize Obama for getting in Karzai's face about his corruption, to which I say, you know, you can't get in his face enough, especially if this is your policy. So, that was really what I was trying to point out.

IMUS: But if this is the Obama policy, then this is the dictionary definition of nation-building, isn't it?

One is if Obama actually does what he's saying he isn't doing, state-building, and if Pakistan really becomes a much more different country and takes on the Taliban inside.

You know, I think to Obama's credit, one thing that's happened -- and the reason people are feeling a lot better about Afghanistan, say, today than three or four months ago, is Pakistan really has taken on the Taliban inside and clearly shared a lot of intelligence with us. So, our Special Operations people and CIA people have been able to track down and eliminate or capture a lot of key Taliban leaders, and that's gone a little better.

Whether the situation on the ground, whether we can deliver -- you know, General McChrystal in Afghanistan -- I think he's a terrific guy -- calls it government in a box, which is basically, we clear out the Taliban and then we come, actually, with a box full of, metaphorically speaking, Afghan officials, and they provide good governance. That's what they tried in the first town they cleared, in Marjah. The next big test is Kandahar.

But, basically, you know, it's the old story. If you owe the bank $1,00, that's your problem. If you owe them a million dollars, that's their problem.

You know, he needs us just as much. And I just really resent that. When you want it more than they do, you always end up getting in trouble.

How do we think this through rationally? How do we get it to work, if at all? Because we're in the middle of it, and so that's really what I'm trying to apply my gray matter to.

IMUS: Why are we being so icky to Netanyahu?

I think what, you know, sort of Biden's blast at Netanyahu for announcing, you know, this new settlement project in Jerusalem when he was there, it wasn't just about, you know, this moment and that perceived slap in the face when Biden had actually come over to kind of make up with the Israelis and put things right. It was really about 40 years of Israeli officials misleading -- I would say cheating -- themselves and the world by constantly building settlements in a way that I don't think is in their interest. I know it's not in our interest.

And I think that Obama was really reflecting the anger of a lot of secretaries of state, a lot of presidents, that, you know, guys, this has got to stop. Because if it doesn't stop, there's no way we can actually produce, you know, a peace process. But more importantly, how are you going to remain a Jewish state if you permanently devouring more and more of the West Bank and ultimately absorbing their Arab-Palestinian population.

And so I'm all for red lines. I said in my column then, I said this morning, friends don't let friends drive drunk. And to me, you know, we've had way too many American presidents just kind of tolerating with the Israelis are doing there, which is bad for us and bad for them.

And when the United States comes to Israel and says look, guys, we have 200,000 troops in the Middle East right now, in Iraq and Afghanistan, they're not there for you, they're there for us. But their being there, actually, certainly helps you. It wiped out one of your biggest enemies, Saddam Hussein.

So, when we come to you and ask you for the smallest favor, which is, like, don't build any more settlements right now while we try to get a peace process going, which we think would improve the atmosphere in the region and help our troops, there's only one right answer to that question, and that is, yes, Mr. United States, we will do that. urn:contentItem:5KR6-6F91-JBHT-D51W-00000-00JP Morgan Reports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges China2010-04-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisJP Morgan Reports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges ChinaLanhamFULL TEXT

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Breaking news this morning. At least 400 people killed and many nor feared dead as the series of strong earthquakes strike Western China. Ten Thousand more are injured according to "State T.V." that's reporting many remained buried under ruble. The initial quake had a magnitude of 6.9 and was followed by several other strong after shocks. Charles McCord will have more on this story later in the show.

Now, we're going to turn to your Fox Business Minute. And some of your top business stories of the day, JP Morgan will give Wall Street an initial read on the big banks when it reports its first quarter numbers this morning, at 7:00 eastern time. The company is expected to post a profit of $2.9 billion or 64 cents a share. We're going to have that report for you live as it breaks here on Fox Business.

Overseas markets rising on a positive report from Intel. That company kicking off earnings season for tech companies in a big way. Shares jumping as much as 4% after profit in the quarter nearly quadrupled. Intel says it got a lift from sales of new chips for computer servers. That's the type of purchases companies had been holding off on during the recession.

And, Toyota will stop selling its 2010 Lexus GX 460 after "Consumer Reports" says people shouldn't buy it. The company asking dealers to pull the SUV until it can do its own test. The magazine says the SUV has an unusually high risk of rolling over. This problem reportedly has to do with the electronic stability control, not the brakes or the gas pedals. They were part of that massive recall for Toyota. Toyota shares traded lower in yesterday's session state side.

Here's a quick look at our European markets as we head into Wednesday's session. Again, picking up of that positive news from Intel and trading in positive territory. Our U.S. stock futures doing something similar this morning also with some green arrows on the screen. We'll show you those. Right now, S&P 500 up 2/10 of a percent. "IMUS IN THE MORNING" next for you here on the Fox Business Network.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DON IMUS, FBN HOST: You know what's making me sick?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: What?

IMUS: Green tea -- making me ill, so --

MCDOWELL: I'm sorry about that. I just --

IMUS: So, my wife says to me -- I love her to death, believe me -- but she says, well this new stuff that she is giving me that kills -- they all kills cancer cells -- so far so good, you know, beats radiation or a stupid operation.

CHALES MCCORD, FBN NEWSCASTER: OK. Go on, make this a point.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: OK. But she says this new stuff she's giving me, she said it's detoxing your body.

MCCORD: Very well.

IMUS: And I'm thinking what is left to detox?

MCCORD: Yes, right.

IMUS: I mean, what's left?

MCCORD: I know --

IMUS: You know what I had for dinner? An f-ing radish!

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: No wonder you're a grumpy man!

IMUS: I mean --

MCDOWELL: No wonder you're crank tan.

IMUS: I had a radish!

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Oh, I'm full, thanks!

MCCORD: You look like an end of season corn husk. You've got to stop.

(LAUGHTER)

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, "IMUS IN THE MORNING."

IMUS: all right, five minutes after the hour here on the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program on the radio around the country and on the Fox Business Network. Pretty good line-up this morning. we'll start with Geraldo Rivera. He's coming up. We'll check in his five favorite songs, Charles. They are "Me And Bobby Mcgee," Janice Joplin. "Love Me Tender," Elvis. They sang all the Elvis songs last night on "American Idol," which was a mistake for most of them. "Girl From The North Country," Bob Dylan. "Dance With My Father," Luther Vandross, and the Bruce Springsteen song, "Streets of Philadelphia."

MCCORD: All right.

IMUS: And then David Kirby is coming up. David Kirby is the author of "Animal Factory: The Looming Threat of Industrial Pig, Dairy, and Poultry Farms to Humans and The Environment. He's selling one book a day on Amazon.

MCCORD: That is wrong.

IMUS: He can't get on any -- he can't get on Fox and Fiends. He can't get on "The Today Show." He can't get on anything. And, do you know why he can't?

MCCORD: I suspect why --

IMUS: Because nobody wants to talk about it. I was trying -- and I don't want to talk about it. I was talking to Lupica last night, and he starts going (INAUDIBLE). He wouldn't let me tell him about these factory farms. You know, there's -- nobody is railing against people -- I'm not at least, people who eat meat or poultry. I don't care what you eat.

MCCORD: Not at all!

IMUS: We raise cattle in New Mexico. My friends are cattle ranchers. That's not the point, but the way these animals are - well, you can't even -- like there's a site -- what is this site, Charles.

MCCORD: There's a site called Farm Sanctuary, which is it's an outfit that does rescues although it's a pittance because of the massive dimensions of the problem, but they do some rescues of some of these animals that are factory, you know, factory processed before they process them, and the web site is -- shows both the farm sanctuary side and also the concentrated animal feeding operations side.

IMUS: Don't want to see it.

MCCORD: And --

IMUS: And people in the morning are trying to have their bacon and eggs --

MCCORD: Of course!

IMUS: -- and sausage with egg and muffin and all that. You don't want to hear about it, so I don't blame you.

MCCORD: Particularly, if you look at the egg production process.

IMUS: Believe me, you just do not want to know, but I like Kirby, and it's an important - you ought to read it. You ought to know about it.

MCCORD: Yes, you really should. You really should.

IMUS: And, you know, there's a way to buy organic meat and to buy -- well, sort of.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And there's a way to -- well, there is and to eat animals, but animals are like us. They have -- I mean I've spent half \my life with horses. I mean they -- and cattle. They have emotions. They --

MCCORD: They are just as complicated physical systems as we do.

IMUS: They feel pain.

MCCORD: They certainly do.

IMUS: They -- well, they are not a bunch of happy animals skipping around old McDonald's farm going in and out of the red barn. Did you know that, Jenna?

LEE: Well, now I do.

IMUS: OK.

MCCORD: Is ain't an oink, oink here and a cluck, cluck there.

IMUS: No. Not a happy little pig oiking in the thing

MCCORD: Here a cluck, there a cluck, everywhere.

IMUS: No.

MCCORD: No.

IMUS: So --

MCCORD: Fuzzy-wuzzy was a bear.

IMUS: That's what you have to look forward to in about an hour.

MCCORD: Well, it's something that you should know about.

IMUS: He's the guy who wrote "Evidence of Harm," you know.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: You don't want to talk about that, either.

MCCORD: No, of course not]

IMUS: But, so -- including, by the way, me. But I will, because --

MCCORD: Animal lover.

IMUS: I don't know why I'm willing to do it, I just am. And then Tom Friedman is coming up. A good column he has in the paper this morning about Op-Ed page of the "New York Times" about Iraq and Afghanistan. How he -- did you read it, Bernie?

BERNARD MCGUIRK, EXECUTIVE PRODUCER: I read some of it. Yes.

IMUS: It's pretty good.

MCGUIRK: Damn good.

IMUS: Well, it is --

MCCORD: I'll take a look at it.

IMUS: -- heretofore whenever we get involved with one of these countries, we didn't care exactly what they did in the country and the cold war as long as they lined up with us. If we support some a despot, well that was just --.

MCCORD: Well, it was, yes.

IMUS: But, now we're more idealistic, and we want to change the culture of these countries.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: We want the people to be -- I mean it's just so insane.

MCCORD: Hearts and minds.

IMUS: You can't -- it's -- even Friedman this morning admits that it's stupid. So, all of that stuff is coming up. Charles, what's the big news?

MCCORD: The big news story is another bad earthquake in the headlines, I-man. This one in province in province in Western China, and the death toll has risen -- the known death toll to at least 400 now.

And there's a good news story out of Florida with the successful recovery of this 11-year-old girl who has missing in swamps for some four days.

And the president of the United States saying the world is a more secure place now, post-nuclear summit that they did actually achieve some things there.

IMUS: We're having a guy on Friday, just one of full of surprise for his book "The Dead End."

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: About the arms race trade in the United States and Russia. David Hoffman is his name. A spotlight on this whole, you know, what's really going on with this whole nuc thing

MCCORD: Clarity to that --

IMUS: Well, more interesting than talking about torturing little pigs and stuff. Jenna you don't seem that happy to see any of us this morning.

(LAUGHTER)

LEE: I'm thrilled to see you. How can you say such a thing?

IMUS: I don't know. You just came in and well, here's a thing with Jenna, so -- we love her to death, by the way.

LEE: Here's the thing with Jenna. Yes?

IMUS: Is that we love her to death. What's going on in business?

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: There you're done.

LEE: Very good.

IMUS: Yes. It's like, Wyatt says to me -- he's 11. He just says, "You have to know when to shut up. Just shut up."

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Wise beyond his years!

IMUS: Yes. Just be quiet. So, in business news, Jenna?

LEE: He seems to know more about women than --

IMUS: Oh, yes he does.

LEE: -- some other people in the room.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: Yes.

LEE: Well, the markets are trading higher this morning. We had a big tech company last night. Intel out with good numbers, and that helped the market. We're also going to get numbers from JP Morgan, a major investment bank today, or I should say, just bank in general. We're going to get those numbers in about 45 minutes and will mean a lot to the markets.

In the meantime, AIG is trying to pay us back, still they are selling 53 of their planes to a major Australian investment bank for about $2 billion, so that's going to come back to us and for all the private plane users in the room. This is for you, specifically. ABERCROMBIE & Fitch is paying their CEO not to use the private jet. And if he goes over a certain amount, he's going to have to pay. So, they're paying him $4 million, just in case he goes over the amounts and then he has to pay back the company.

IMUS: Certainly that's not directed at me, I can't imagine that.

MCCORD: No, it's the rest of us private jet users!

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: I just don't understand why we're bringing the hurt to the I- man. I just don't get that. Speaking of bringing of hurts to the I-man, Ronnie Deutsche --

MCCORD: Yes. I love this.

IMUS: -- who is this tax babe. She -- I don't know. I was just talking about her yesterday. This image I have of her at the end of the bar at 9:00 at night -- every night at the Blarney Stone with a pell-mell dangling out of the corner of her mouth, hunched over a glass of Jack Daniels, you know, who's going to be next.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Shot and a beer chaser!

IMUS: Exactly.

MCCORD: Oh my God!

IMUS: She says, "Dear Imus, I am a cigar smoking woman, so I thought you might enjoy my favorite cigar" -- and always a great thing to give a cancer patient --

MCCORD: Perfect!

IMUS: Somebody with emphysema. Anyway, enjoy -- this woman is so dumb. It makes my -- actually it makes my toenails hurt. "Enjoy and happy tax season."

MCCORD: There you go.

IMUS: Here's Ronnie, what you can do with this --

MCCORD: Well, no, no, no.

IMUS: Well, she's not dumb, and she's a nice lady, and here's the cigar.

MCCORD: That's no good.

IMUS: Nub using our Jackson. Actually, do you smoke cigars?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No.

IMUS: You don't? How about nub?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do!

IMUS: You can have this one.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you.

IMUS: OK. Anyway, Warner got sports. He's coming up. Jim Nantz all over Tiger Woods, huh, Warner?

WARNER WOLF, FBN SPORTSCASTER: Oh, man, what happened?

IMUS: Well, I mean just --

WOLF: Hey dawg!

IMUS: Well, you know, Warner. Somebody asked me, "why is Warner calling you dawg." I said, "Oh about a week ago, I said something, I referred to him as dawg, what's going on." And so now, Warner is doing that.

WOLF: That's right.

IMUS: But he does it and nobody knows why.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Well, I thought you were talking to Rob.

IMUS: Yes. Well, Rob is great for doing that. I'll make just some offhand comment.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: Sometimes even off the air, and Rob will write a bit about it, assuming that everybody knows what we're talking about and of course, nobody does. At any rate, -- well, Nantz is saying that if he would used the kind of language Tiger Woods used that had got on CBS mics as Tiger Woods did. He'll be fired, and he's right about that.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And, two, as others have said, Lupica and you, Warner Wolf, and Nantz, and that is the Tiger is going to use -- the Tiger says he's going to try to do better than do better.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: If you're going to behave better, then behave better, which he did not do, and as Nantz pointed out, if somebody offered him and said, well, tiger had a camera in his face all day. Nantz say "well, so did Phil Mickelson."

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Phil didn't say anything.

WOLF: No!

IMUS: All Phil did was win.

WOLF: That's it!

IMUS: Which Tiger didn't do.

WOLF: No.

IMUS: Well, he's right!

WOLF: Nantz is absolutely right, and Tiger is the one that brought it up.

IMUS: And the Yankees won the home opener.

WOLF: Yes, they did. Biggest crowd ever in the new stadium for a regular season game.

IMUS: Wow!

WOLF: And there's a couple of good stories. Bulls General Manager, John Paxon, apparently challenged Bulls' coach Vinnie Delnegro to a fight.

(LAUGHTER)

RUFINO: That great!

IMUS: What happened?

WOLF: Well, we'll see what happens there, and the Bulls are investigating. Well, that looks like the story. Ben Roethlisberger met with NFL commissioner Goodell yesterday and faces possible suspension and Beef Jerky has dropped their sponsorship for Big Ben's Beef Jerky giving our beef a bad name. And, Barry Bonds -- Barry bonds says, "I'm proud of Mark McGwire for admitting he used steroids." Barry Bonds.

IMUS: And Bernie has a briefing sponsored by P.C. Richard and Son. What's up, B?

MCGUIRK: Well, first of all. President Obama is going to go to Poland this weekend for the president's funeral, there. The polish president died in the air crash, which is a nice thing. He said a lot of things about President Obama, give up a weekend. It's actually a nice gesture.

IMUS: Yes.

MCGUIRK: And Conan O'Brien going to TBS. He's pushing back George Lopez, and there's a lot of talk about Lopez getting disked and getting the ironically the Conan treatment from TBS. Anyway, he had Chris Rock on the show last night, and they were discussing just that.

CHRIS ROCK, ARTIST (?): Where are you going?

CONAN O'BRIEN, TBS HOST (?): I'm going to midnight. He's coming on 11:00, and I'm going to midnight.

ROCK: Get the hell out of here!

(LAUGHTER)

ROCK: So, you're going to move for the white man! -

O'BRIEN: I am.

(LAUGHTER)

ROCK: I hope he appreciate this.

O'BRIEN: I think the white man does appreciate it very much.

ROCK: OK. You go got to clean the park or nothing.

O'BRIEN: No, I got to go to work an hour later.

ROCK: OK.

O'BRIEN: A dream come true.

MCGUIRK: I'm just glad Jimmie Norton didn't make those jokes but like the politically incorrect humor.

IMUS: Yes. That was good, funny.

MCGUIRK: That's from last night.

IMUS: Seventeen -- wheels just came off right there, didn't they, Charles?

MCCORD: A little bit.

IMUS: Seventeen after the hour here on the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program. Give you time to get your bacon and sausage going and all that and then we'll fire up "Animal Factory" and David Kirby in about an hour. However, next is Geraldo Rivera. This is one of his favorite songs, one of mine, too.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Are you looking for an investment opportunity, but you're not sure where to start? Why not get involved with what "Ink Magazine" has named one of the fastest growing companies in America, "Planet Fitness." "Planet Fitness" is a gym that attracts the average Joes, Charles. You don't need to be a muscle head to work out at the "Planet Fitness." You don't need to be a muscle head to buy into it, either. All you need is a desire to turn a quick profit with a company that knows a secret.

"Planet Fitness" will set up your gym, develop a marketing strategy that has a track record of putting up big numbers. How does an average of $1.7 million a year sound in sales, better yet, an average of $573,000 in profit? Think of all the plan of getting to join the gym, plus you always have a place to work out.

The economy is well doing a little better, but still sucks. This company does not, however. Go to planetfitness.com to find out about "Planet Fitness." Franchise opportunity is not an offer to sell. Offerings made by prospectus only. Planetfitness.com, check them out.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

IMUS: This is the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network, here's Jenna Lee.

LEE: Good morning, everybody. Here's you're Fox Business Minute on this Wednesday morning. President Obama meeting with congressional leaders from both parties at the White House today to talk about financial regulation reform. Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner saying, quote "republicans won't want to be on this wrong side of this." But, Mitch McConnell saying the democrats won't solve any problems and will provide endless protection for banks.

Big banks fighting against tough derivatives rules. Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, and Morgan Stanley telling the senate agricultural committee. Stricter rules will limit profits. The committee chairman Blanche Lincoln is expected to propose a more aggressive approach to sweeping changes to the derivatives market.

And, Fed Chief Ben Bernanke testifying on the Hill today to offer his outlook for the economy. Lawmakers on the joint economic committee will likely question him about the strength of the recovery and also the pace of job growth. Fed officials have pledged to keep interest rates at record lows for an extended period to boost spending. Wall Street waiting to hear if the Fed will move away from that commitments.

All right, let's take a quick look at our futures here on a Wednesday morning in positive -- well, positive territory ahead of JP Morgan's numbers. We expect those in a little more than half an hour. Over to Charles now for this morning's top stories.

MCCORD: And a couple of these stories that we're following this morning, Jenna. There's another bad earthquake in the headlines. The number of dead and injured from a strong earthquake Western China is climbing.

Chinese State Television saying at least 400 people had been killed, more than 10,000 injured. Rescue workers trying to dig trapped people out of the rubble of collapsed mud and wood houses. Scores of people gathering out in the open areas searching for relatives, a scene we have seen too much certainly of late.

Tea party movement having a homecoming of sports today. Sarah Palin scheduled to headline a rally in Boston. The city from which tea party supporters revolutionary spirit was born. They figured it will be like 10,000 people or so to turn out.

Couple of the headlines as the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program continues for you, right now, here on the Fox Business Network.

IMUS: All right. Twenty-four after the hour here on the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program on the radio all over the country and on the Fox Business Network. Geraldo Rivera is coming up in just a couple of minutes here.

And the David Kirby and his book, "Animal Factory." Charles and I were talking about last night and we're talking about it this morning, and I don't know what the solution is. But it's certainly is worth discussing. You know, but -- you know, people like John Stewart, you know I like.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And David Colbert -- or Steven Colbert and some of these other shows that this would be a natural for -- Stewart is much as I like him. He won't beat up on anybody. He won't talk about anything, unless it's safe. I mean beating up Fox News or whatever it is or Glenn Beck, that's a safe target for him.

MCCORD: Exactly.

IMUS: So -- but, putting somebody on or Colbert putting -- putting David Kirby on with "Animal Factory" is not safe for them, and they don't have -- I don't want to be too harsh here. They won't do it. They just don't have the guts. They're fighting and they don't want to know about it, and they don't want somebody in a suit to tell them they can't do it.

MCCORD: It is certainly worth the conversation, the subject.

IMUS: But, people think well, then, you know, people like David Kirby are screaming at you that you can't eat meat, but he's not saying that.

MCCORD: That is not -- at all.

IMUS: But there's certainly is far more humane way to go about this and it will cost more.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: But, the amount of money saves in health care costs would be so astronomical that it would be ridiculous, but that doesn't help the people processing the meat and the poultry because they don't -- they costs them more.

MCCORD: And as you said last night, it doesn't have to be done overnight, but you can take a baby step here and there.

IMUS: It's already tedious, and we've only talked about it for a minute ago.

MCGUIRK: No not at all.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Well, we want to --

IMUS: Bernie already wants to kill him.

MCCORD: Oh my God!

IMUS: Well, that's me point. Here's Warner with sports. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man. Baseball, 49,000, Yankees Home Opener including George Steinbrenner. Yankees almost blew a 5 up and lead held on beat the Angels, 7 to 5. They took Andy Pettitte out after 6 with a 5 nothing lead. Jeter and Nick Johnson home run for the Yanks. Here's the call, Michael Kay, Yes Network.

MICHAEL KAY, RADIO COMMENTATOR: This was a hit to right field. There it goes. See yeah!

WOLF: The biggest hand, Angels DH and former Yankee Hideki Matsui hugged by his teammates receiving a standing-o, receiving his World Series Ring. However, as a joke, Derek Jeter gave Matsui a fake ring.

DEREK JETER: We knew he wouldn't be able to compare to it anyone because he was on the other side. So, knowing Matsui, he's probably proud to get the bootleg one too, and then we get him the real one.

WOLF: And the Jays beat the White Sox, 4 to 2. Guess what, I-man?

IMUS: What a whacky team, huh?

RUFINO: Yes, crazy.

MCGUIRK: Loose.

RUFINO: We replaced the ring and give him this one!

MCGUIRK: Not so funny!

RUFINO: And then we gave him triple glass.

WOLF: You thought I was going to play the Japanese voice, right, I- man?

IMUS: Well, you never know.

WOLF: No. I wouldn't do that to you.

IMUS: Of course you would!

We also got retail sales, up 1.6 percent in March, better than expected. A lot of that gain was due to strong auto sales. If you take out autos, you actually get the reading of .6 of a percent higher. That's also a bigger gain than economists were expecting.

And shares of JPMorgan rising in the pre-market as well after the bank reports better-than-expected earnings. It continues to see stabilization in delinquencies on consumer loans and mortgages. It's seeing broad-based improvements, and it's hopeful for a strong economic recovery. CEO Jamie Dimon says he doesn't know if regulators will allow JPMorgan to raise its dividends.

So we'll keep an eye on that stock.

Lots to keep an eye on this morning. Let's take a look at the European markets that picked up off that positive news from intel after the bell yesterday.

Trading higher this morning. As we take a look at our U.S. stock futures, we're seeing some green arrows on the screen as well. S&P 500 up .4 of a percent.

And stay with us on Fox Business for "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stuart Varney up at 9:20 Eastern Time.

In the meantime, you've got more IMUS IN THE MORNING coming to you next here on the Fox Business Network.

IMUS: All right. Six minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

That was probably the last time Friedman will be on, but -- I mean, that's crazy, isn't it?

MCCORD: Well, it's a little oversight.

IMUS: It has a greater impact on the health of people in this country than anything. More devastating to the environment than anything. Than anything.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK.

IMUS: And it wasn't on your radar?

MCCORD: Well, no, it wasn't on his radar. He had other elements of the problem. The sequel --

MCGUIRK: Maybe.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: He's updating from Beirut to whatever it is. Maybe he can update his stupid environment book, Hot, Flat, and Corrupt.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Keep it right here on the Fox Business Network throughout the day for the latest news and financial developments.

Then tonight at 6:00 Eastern Time, join Neil Cavuto and his guest, former New York City mayor Ed Koch. Ed Koch?

Tomorrow, on this program, we'll be joined by Anthony Mason of CBS News, and Mary and Carol Higgins Clark. Oh God. And they've got two new books. Oh, that's great.

And then Jerry Springer is going to be here to talk about his new game show.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Paula Deen is a best-selling author and the host of the Food Network's show "Paula's Home Cooking."

People love this woman.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: "Paula's Party," "Paula's Best Dishes." Her magazine, "Cooking With Paula Deen," appears bimonthly. She's the author of "Paula Deen: It Ain't All About the Cooking," "Christmas With Paula Deen," a whole bunch of other books, all have been best-sellers.

She's been on everything. She's the founder of the Lady and Sons restaurant, co-owner of Uncle Bubba's Oyster House.

She lives with her family in Savannah, Georgia. Her new book from Simon & Schuster is a coffee table book, beautiful, entitled "Paula Deen: Savannah Style," Paula Deen and Brandon Branch.

Please welcome to the program, Paula Deen.

Good morning, Ms. Deen.

PAULA DEEN, HOST, "PAULA'S HOME COOKING": Good morning, Imus. How are you?

IMUS: I'm fine, baby. How are you?

DEEN: What an intro. And may I say, I have loved listening to you and watching you through the years.

IMUS: Thank you very much. I appreciate that.

DEEN: Oh, I have loved it. And thank you so much for having me on.

IMUS: So, you got rid of the husband.

DEEN: Got rid of the husband, yes.

IMUS: What did he do?

DEEN: I was married for 27 years, and I married -- I met and married my neighbor when I moved out on to Wilmington Island. And we've been together six years, and it's like we're just soul mates and --

IMUS: Well, that's good.

DEEN: It's just been a wonderful, wonderful life. My husband liked cold beer more than his desire for his family, I guess you might say.

And he adored us. He adored us, but he could never put down the alcohol. And, you know, I tried for 27 years to fix it and I couldn't, so I had to accept the fact that I could not change that.

IMUS: It ruins everything.

You know -- we're talking with Paula Deen. Her new book called "Paula Deen: Savannah Style." It's a coffee table book. It is full of gorgeous photographs of how Paula and -- what's this guy's name, old Brandon?

DEEN: Brandon Branch.

IMUS: Old Brandon, who decorates these rooms. And man, you have to take your shoes off to walk into one of these rooms.

DEEN: Well, they're beautiful rooms. People -- Brandon and I, we tried to create a book that we could take people into these beautiful places, Imus, that when you come to Savannah you wouldn't ordinarily see.

You know, Savannah is made up of all kinds of magical, hidden gardens. And they're all behind walls, so you can't see them. So, this is our way of exposing people to these treasures.

IMUS: I like these songs you picked -- "At Last," Etta James.

DEEN: That was the song that my husband and I danced to, the first dance after our wedding.

IMUS: Your new husband?

DEEN: My new husband, yes.

IMUS: Oh, OK. Don't be picking songs --

DEEN: My for life husband.

IMUS: Don't be picking songs from the last one. We just got --

(LAUGHTER)

DEEN: You know, I ain't a quitter, Imus. It just kills me to give up. And so, you know, I hung in there for 27 years. So I said if I could hang in for 27 years with him, I could do 50 very easy with the man I'm with now.

IMUS: Well, that's one of the great records ever, and I love Elvis and Joe Cocker.

DEEN: Yes!

IMUS: Billy Joel, Ray Charles, not bad.

DEEN: Yes, yes, yes, yes.

IMUS: Well, it's a pleasure to talk with you.

DEEN: Soulful music. Well, the pleasure is all mine, my darling.

Like I said, I've been a fan for years, so to actually speak to you is just another wonderful memory for me to have.

IMUS: I can see why people love you, because I love you.

DEEN: Well, thank you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Time now for an IMUS IN THE MORNING Fox Business update. And here's Stuart Varney.

END

urn:contentItem:51D0-69P1-JB30-V0JW-00000-00JP Morgan Reports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges China to Let Currency Rises; Greece Raises $2 Billion; David Kirby Discusses His New Book about the Factory Farm Industry; Interview With Tom Friedman2010-04-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTDavid Kirby, Tom Friedman, Paula DeenNEWSInternational041401cb.220JP MorganReports at 7AM; TARP Watchdog Mortgage Plan Not Working; At least 400 Killed as Earthquakes Strikes Western China; Obama Urges China to Let Currency Rises; Greece Raises $2 Billion; David Kirby Discusses His New Book about the Factory Farm Industry; Interview With Tom FriedmanDon Imus, Dagen McDowell, Jenna Lee, Charles McCord, Bernie McGuirk, Lou Rufino, Warner Wolf, Tom Bowman, Stuart Varney

JENNA LEE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Breaking news this morning. At least 400 people killed and many nor feared dead as the series of strong earthquakes strike Western China. Ten Thousand more are injured according to "State T.V." that's reporting many remained buried under ruble. The initial quake had a magnitude of 6.9 and was followed by several other strong after shocks. Charles McCord will have more on this story later in the show.

Now, we're going to turn to your Fox Business Minute. And some of your top business stories of the day, JP Morganwill give Wall Street an initial read on the big banks when it reports its first quarter numbers this morning, at 7:00 eastern time. The company is expected to post a profit of $2.9 billion or 64 cents a share. We're going to have that report for you live as it breaks here on Fox Business.

Overseas markets rising on a positive report from Intel. That company kicking off earnings season for tech companies in a big way. Shares jumping as much as 4% after profit in the quarter nearly quadrupled. Intel says it got a lift from sales of new chips for computer servers. That's the type of purchases companies had been holding off on during the recession.

And, Toyota will stop selling its 2010 Lexus GX 460 after "Consumer Reports" says people shouldn't buy it. The company asking dealers to pull the SUV until it can do its own test. The magazine says the SUV has an unusually high risk of rolling over. This problem reportedly has to do with the electronic stability control, not the brakes or the gas pedals. They were part of that massive recall for Toyota. Toyota shares traded lower in yesterday's session state side.

Here's a quick look at our European markets as we head into Wednesday's session. Again, picking up of that positive news from Intel and trading in positive territory. Our U.S. stock futures doing something similar this morning also with some green arrows on the screen. We'll show you those. Right now, S&P 500 up 2/10 of a percent. "IMUS IN THE MORNING" next for you here on the Fox Business Network.

DON IMUS, FBN HOST: You know what's making me sick?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: What?

IMUS: Green tea -- making me ill, so --

MCDOWELL: I'm sorry about that. I just --

IMUS: So, my wife says to me -- I love her to death, believe me -- but she says, well this new stuff that she is giving me that kills -- they all kills cancer cells -- so far so good, you know, beats radiation or a stupid operation.

CHALES MCCORD, FBN NEWSCASTER: OK. Go on, make this a point.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: OK. But she says this new stuff she's giving me, she said it's detoxing your body.

MCCORD: Very well.

IMUS: And I'm thinking what is left to detox?

MCCORD: Yes, right.

IMUS: I mean, what's left?

MCCORD: I know --

IMUS: You know what I had for dinner? An f-ing radish!

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: No wonder you're a grumpy man!

IMUS: I mean --

MCDOWELL: No wonder you're crank tan.

IMUS: I had a radish!

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Oh, I'm full, thanks!

MCCORD: You look like an end of season corn husk. You've got to stop.

(LAUGHTER)

ANNOUNCER: Ladies and gentlemen, "IMUS IN THE MORNING."

IMUS: all right, five minutes after the hour here on the "IMUS IN THE MORNING" program on the radio around the country and on the Fox Business Network. Pretty good line-up this morning. we'll start with Geraldo Rivera. He's coming up. We'll check in his five favorite songs, Charles. They are "Me And Bobby Mcgee," Janice Joplin. "Love Me Tender," Elvis. They sang all the Elvis songs last night on "American Idol," which was a mistake for most of them. "Girl From The North Country," Bob Dylan. "Dance With My Father," Luther Vandross, and the Bruce Springsteen song, "Streets of Philadelphia."

MCCORD: All right.

IMUS: And then David Kirby is coming up. David Kirby is the author of "Animal Factory: The Looming Threat of Industrial Pig, Dairy, and Poultry Farms to Humans and The Environment. He's selling one book a day on Amazon.

MCCORD: That is wrong.

IMUS: He can't get on any -- he can't get on Fox and Fiends. He can't get on "The Today Show." He can't get on anything. And, do you know why he can't?

MCCORD: I suspect why --

IMUS: Because nobody wants to talk about it. I was trying -- and I don't want to talk about it. I was talking to Lupica last night, and he starts going (INAUDIBLE). He wouldn't let me tell him about these factory farms. You know, there's -- nobody is railing against people -- I'm not at least, people who eat meat or poultry. I don't care what you eat.

MCCORD: Not at all!

IMUS: We raise cattle in New Mexico. My friends are cattle ranchers. That's not the point, but the way these animals are - well, you can't even -- like there's a site -- what is this site, Charles.

MCCORD: There's a site called Farm Sanctuary, which is it's an outfit that does rescues although it's a pittance because of the massive dimensions of the problem, but they do some rescues of some of these animals that are factory, you know, factory processed before they process them, and the web site is -- shows both the farm sanctuary side and also the concentrated animal feeding operations side.

IMUS: Don't want to see it.

MCCORD: And --

IMUS: And people in the morning are trying to have their bacon and eggs --

MCCORD: Of course!

IMUS: -- and sausage with egg and muffin and all that. You don't want to hear about it, so I don't blame you.

MCCORD: Particularly, if you look at the egg production process.

IMUS: Believe me, you just do not want to know, but I like Kirby, and it's an important - you ought to read it. You ought to know about it.

MCCORD: Yes, you really should. You really should.

IMUS: And, you know, there's a way to buy organic meat and to buy -- well, sort of.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And there's a way to -- well, there is and to eat animals, but animals are like us. They have -- I mean I've spent half \my life with horses. I mean they -- and cattle. They have emotions. They --

MCCORD: They are just as complicated physical systems as we do.

IMUS: They feel pain.

MCCORD: They certainly do.

IMUS: They -- well, they are not a bunch of happy animals skipping around old McDonald's farm going in and out of the red barn. Did you know that, Jenna?

LEE: Well, now I do.

IMUS: OK.

MCCORD: Is ain't an oink, oink here and a cluck, cluck there.

IMUS: No. Not a happy little pig oiking in the thing

MCCORD: Here a cluck, there a cluck, everywhere.

IMUS: No.

MCCORD: No.

IMUS: So --

MCCORD: Fuzzy-wuzzy was a bear.

IMUS: That's what you have to look forward to in about an hour.

MCCORD: Well, it's something that you should know about.

IMUS: He's the guy who wrote "Evidence of Harm," you know.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: You don't want to talk about that, either.

MCCORD: No, of course not>

IMUS: But, so -- including, by the way, me. But I will, because --

MCCORD: Animal lover.

IMUS: I don't know why I'm willing to do it, I just am. And then Tom Friedman is coming up. A good column he has in the paper this morning about Op-Ed page of the "New York Times" about Iraq and Afghanistan. How he -- did you read it, Bernie?

BERNARD MCGUIRK, EXECUTIVE PRODUCER: I read some of it. Yes.

IMUS: It's pretty good.

MCGUIRK: Damn good.

IMUS: Well, it is --

MCCORD: I'll take a look at it.

IMUS: -- heretofore whenever we get involved with one of these countries, we didn't care exactly what they did in the country and the cold war as long as they lined up with us. If we support some a despot, well that was just --.

MCCORD: Well, it was, yes.

IMUS: But, now we're more idealistic, and we want to change the culture of these countries.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: We want the people to be -- I mean it's just so insane.

MCCORD: Hearts and minds.

IMUS: You can't -- it's -- even Friedman this morning admits that it's stupid. So, all of that stuff is coming up. Charles, what's the big news?

MCCORD: The big news story is another bad earthquake in the headlines, I-man. This one in province in province in Western China, and the death toll has risen -- the known death toll to at least 400 now.

And there's a good news story out of Florida with the successful recovery of this 11-year-old girl who has missing in swamps for some four days.

And the president of the United States saying the world is a more secure place now, post-nuclear summit that they did actually achieve some things there.

IMUS: We're having a guy on Friday, just one of full of surprise for his book "The Dead End."

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: About the arms race trade in the United States and Russia. David Hoffman is his name. A spotlight on this whole, you know, what's really going on with this whole nuc thing

MCCORD: Clarity to that --

IMUS: Well, more interesting than talking about torturing little pigs and stuff. Jenna you don't seem that happy to see any of us this morning.

(LAUGHTER)

LEE: I'm thrilled to see you. How can you say such a thing?

IMUS: I don't know. You just came in and well, here's a thing with Jenna, so -- we love her to death, by the way.

LEE: Here's the thing with Jenna. Yes?

IMUS: Is that we love her to death. What's going on in business?

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: There you're done.

LEE: Very good.

IMUS: Yes. It's like, Wyatt says to me -- he's 11. He just says, "You have to know when to shut up. Just shut up."

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Wise beyond his years!

IMUS: Yes. Just be quiet. So, in business news, Jenna?

LEE: He seems to know more about women than --

IMUS: Oh, yes he does.

LEE: -- some other people in the room.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: Yes.

LEE: Well, the markets are trading higher this morning. We had a big tech company last night. Intel out with good numbers, and that helped the market. We're also going to get numbers from JP Morgan, a major investment bank today, or I should say, just bank in general. We're going to get those numbers in about 45 minutes and will mean a lot to the markets.

In the meantime, AIG is trying to pay us back, still they are selling 53 of their planes to a major Australian investment bank for about $2 billion, so that's going to come back to us and for all the private plane users in the room. This is for you, specifically. ABERCROMBIE & Fitch is paying their CEO not to use the private jet. And if he goes over a certain amount, he's going to have to pay. So, they're paying him $4 million, just in case he goes over the amounts and then he has to pay back the company.

IMUS: Certainly that's not directed at me, I can't imagine that.

MCCORD: No, it's the rest of us private jet users!

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: I just don't understand why we're bringing the hurt to the I- man. I just don't get that. Speaking of bringing of hurts to the I-man, Ronnie Deutsche --

MCCORD: Yes. I love this.

IMUS: -- who is this tax babe. She -- I don't know. I was just talking about her yesterday. This image I have of her at the end of the bar at 9:00 at night -- every night at the Blarney Stone with a pell-mell dangling out of the corner of her mouth, hunched over a glass of Jack Daniels, you know, who's going to be next.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: Shot and a beer chaser!

IMUS: Exactly.

MCCORD: Oh my God!

IMUS: She says, "Dear Imus, I am a cigar smoking woman, so I thought you might enjoy my favorite cigar" -- and always a great thing to give a cancer patient --

MCCORD: Perfect!

IMUS: Somebody with emphysema. Anyway, enjoy -- this woman is so dumb. It makes my -- actually it makes my toenails hurt. "Enjoy and happy tax season."

MCCORD: There you go.

IMUS: Here's Ronnie, what you can do with this --

MCCORD: Well, no, no, no.

IMUS: Well, she's not dumb, and she's a nice lady, and here's the cigar.

MCCORD: That's no good.

IMUS: Nub using our Jackson. Actually, do you smoke cigars?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No.

IMUS: You don't? How about nub?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do!

IMUS: You can have this one.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you.

IMUS: OK. Anyway, Warner got sports. He's coming up. Jim Nantz all over Tiger Woods, huh, Warner?

WARNER WOLF, FBN SPORTSCASTER: Oh, man, what happened?

IMUS: Well, I mean just --

WOLF: Hey dawg!

IMUS: Well, you know, Warner. Somebody asked me, "why is Warner calling you dawg." I said, "Oh about a week ago, I said something, I referred to him as dawg, what's going on." And so now, Warner is doing that.

WOLF: That's right.

IMUS: But he does it and nobody knows why.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: Well, I thought you were talking to Rob.

IMUS: Yes. Well, Rob is great for doing that. I'll make just some offhand comment.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: Sometimes even off the air, and Rob will write a bit about it, assuming that everybody knows what we're talking about and of course, nobody does. At any rate, -- well, Nantz is saying that if he would used the kind of language Tiger Woods used that had got on CBS mics as Tiger Woods did. He'll be fired, and he's right about that.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And, two, as others have said, Lupica and you, Warner Wolf, and Nantz, and that is the Tiger is going to use -- the Tiger says he's going to try to do better than do better.

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: If you're going to behave better, then behave better, which he did not do, and as Nantz pointed out, if somebody offered him and said, well, tiger had a camera in his face all day. Nantz say "well, so did Phil Mickelson."

WOLF: Yes.

IMUS: Phil didn't say anything.

WOLF: No!

IMUS: All Phil did was win.

WOLF: That's it!

IMUS: Which Tiger didn't do.

WOLF: No.

IMUS: Well, he's right!

WOLF: Nantz is absolutely right, and Tiger is the one that brought it up.

IMUS: And the Yankees won the home opener.

WOLF: Yes, they did. Biggest crowd ever in the new stadium for a regular season game.

IMUS: Wow!

WOLF: And there's a couple of good stories. Bulls General Manager, John Paxon, apparently challenged Bulls' coach Vinnie Delnegro to a fight.

(LAUGHTER)

RUFINO: That great!

IMUS: What happened?

One is, it's really interesting that Obama's now really pursuing a much more idealist, as opposed to sort of hard-core realist, foreign policy in Afghanistan and, by definition, in Iraq. And the corollary to that is -- you know, a lot of people criticize Obama for getting in Karzai's face about his corruption, to which I say, you know, you can't get in his face enough, especially if this is your policy. So, that was really what I was trying to point out.

IMUS: But if this is the Obama policy, then this is the dictionary definition of nation-building, isn't it?

FRIEDMAN: Oh, yes. This is -- call it nation-building, Don, call it state-building, but that's exactly what it is.

And, you know, I think you and I talked right after the policy was announced. And the point I made is that, you know, the policy only works if a few things happen. One is if Obama actually does what he's saying he isn't doing, state-building, and if Pakistan really becomes a much more different country and takes on the Taliban inside.

You know, I think to Obama's credit, one thing that's happened -- and the reason people are feeling a lot better about Afghanistan, say, today than three or four months ago, is Pakistan really has taken on the Taliban inside and clearly shared a lot of intelligence with us. So, our Special Operations people and CIA people have been able to track down and eliminate or capture a lot of key Taliban leaders, and that's gone a little better.

Whether the situation on the ground, whether we can deliver -- you know, General McChrystal in Afghanistan -- I think he's a terrific guy -- calls it government in a box, which is basically, we clear out the Taliban and then we come, actually, with a box full of, metaphorically speaking, Afghan officials, and they provide good governance. That's what they tried in the first town they cleared, in Marjah. The next big test is Kandahar.

I think the jury is still really out whether that governance is delivering, but that is the strategy we've got in place. And I really was trying to write and then explain to people, that's what's at stake here. If that's what we're doing, this is what you better be rooting for -- one, better governance; and two, if Obama wants to get in Karzai's face, that's just fine with me.

IMUS: My head kind of was spinning though as I was watching Bob Schieffer on "Face the Nation" when Secretary Clinton and Secretary Gates were on and Schieffer said, well -- talking about Karzai -- he said, well, now he's been characterized by you all as a drug addict and a thug, and this and that. Well, they just scoffed at that and said, oh, no, he's -- so the line changed -- oh, no, he's terrific, and he's coming over and bringing these new capes and all that.

FRIEDMAN: Yes, I don't quite buy it, Don.

IMUS: What was that all about?

FRIEDMAN: I mean, Karzai is both the -- to me, the cause of the surge and the beneficiary of the surge. He's the cause of the surge because it was his misgovernance that allowed the Taliban to come back, and he's going to be the beneficiary of the surge.

But, basically, you know, it's the old story. If you owe the bank $1,00, that's your problem. If you owe them a million dollars, that's their problem.

He's the only horse we have to ride now. And therefore, these -- our senior officials simply are going to have to live with him. And to which, you know, I say OK, I understand that, I'm not naive about it, but don't let him take you hostage.

You know, he needs us just as much. And I just really resent that. When you want it more than they do, you always end up getting in trouble.

IMUS: Well, I don't see how -- even you acknowledge in your college this morning -- I don't see how this plan the president has for Afghanistan ever works. Ever.

FRIEDMAN: And this was my problem from the beginning, that, you know, it may work, Don, with infinite time and infinite money.

IMUS: But we don't have that.

FRIEDMAN: Yes, we have neither. And so that's what really troubles me about it.

But my attitude has been, look, I made my point earlier, I'm skeptical of this. But my country is in it now. We're in the middle of it, so I'm just focussed on, all right, we're in the middle of it. How do we think this through rationally? How do we get it to work, if at all? Because we're in the middle of it, and so that's really what I'm trying to apply my gray matter to.

IMUS: Why are we being so icky to Netanyahu?

FRIEDMAN: Well, you know, I think what all of that was about, Don, is a couple of things. And in a way, there's an analog with the Karzai story.

I think what, you know, sort of Biden's blast at Netanyahu for announcing, you know, this new settlement project in Jerusalem when he was there, it wasn't just about, you know, this moment and that perceived slap in the face when Biden had actually come over to kind of make up with the Israelis and put things right. It was really about 40 years of Israeli officials misleading -- I would say cheating -- themselves and the world by constantly building settlements in a way that I don't think is in their interest. I know it's not in our interest.

And I think that Obama was really reflecting the anger of a lot of secretaries of state, a lot of presidents, that, you know, guys, this has got to stop. Because if it doesn't stop, there's no way we can actually produce, you know, a peace process. But more importantly, how are you going to remain a Jewish state if you permanently devouring more and more of the West Bank and ultimately absorbing their Arab-Palestinian population.

And so I'm all for red lines. I said in my column then, I said this morning, friends don't let friends drive drunk. And to me, you know, we've had way too many American presidents just kind of tolerating with the Israelis are doing there, which is bad for us and bad for them.

And when the United States comes to Israel and says look, guys, we have 200,000 troops in the Middle East right now, in Iraq and Afghanistan, they're not there for you, they're there for us. But their being there, actually, certainly helps you. It wiped out one of your biggest enemies, Saddam Hussein.

So, when we come to you and ask you for the smallest favor, which is, like, don't build any more settlements right now while we try to get a peace process going, which we think would improve the atmosphere in the region and help our troops, there's only one right answer to that question, and that is, yes, Mr. United States, we will do that. Thank you very much.

IMUS: In the 20 years or so that you've been appearing on this program, as we often touch on this subject -- and the conversation never changes, just the people. It never changes.

FRIEDMAN: It's funny, Don, you know, I think one of the very first times I was on your show, which is 20 years ago, I had written "Beirut to Jerusalem."

IMUS: Yes.

FRIEDMAN: Which was my memoir of that time of the world. As our mutual agent Esther will tell you, the book is now about to reach its 20th year in paperback. And what happens when you have a paperback after 20 years, the license expires and it actually comes back to you.

And you cannot only sell the book, you can do whatever you want with it. So we're actually going to come out with a new edition in a year or so, and I've already decided it's going to have a new introduction. It's going to be one page, one line: "Nothing has changed."

IMUS: You know, I know you didn't call up to be chastised by me, but I'm stunned that you can write a book on the environment and not assess the impact that our nation's food supply has on the way that these animals are treated, the way the food is prepared, the way it's presented, and the impact it has on not only the environment, but the health care of people in this country.

FRIEDMAN: Well, there you go. I mean, I'm sure I missed a lot more than that, but I'm glad to know about it. And several people have written --

IMUS: This is an opportunity for you to get up to speed, isn't it, Tom?

FRIEDMAN: Yes, absolutely.

(LAUGHTER)

FRIEDMAN: I come on this show to be brought up to speed.

IMUS: In this case, you deserve it.

Thank you very much, Tom.

FRIEDMAN: Thanks, Don.

IMUS: Tom Friedman here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

LEE: Some breaking news this hour.

Apple delaying the international launch of the iPad. Fox Business the first to report to you that Apple is delaying the international launch of the iPad by one month due to strong demand.

That news driving the stock higher in the pre-market. And Apple saying the iPad has been a runaway success right here in the U.S. The company delivering more than a half-million iPads since its domestic launch. So we'll keep an eye on that stock today.

In the meantime, some economic news just in to us.

Inflation remaining tame in March. The Consumer Price Index rising by .1 of a percent, right in line with the estimate. When you take out food and energy, there's no change in prices compared to February, and this will likely allow the Fed to keep interest rates low.

We also got retail sales, up 1.6 percent in March, better than expected. A lot of that gain was due to strong auto sales. If you take out autos, you actually get the reading of .6 of a percent higher. That's also a bigger gain than economists were expecting.

And shares of JPMorgan rising in the pre-market as well after the bank reports better-than-expected earnings. It continues to see stabilization in delinquencies on consumer loans and mortgages. It's seeing broad-based improvements, and it's hopeful for a strong economic recovery. CEO Jamie Dimon says he doesn't know if regulators will allow JPMorgan to raise its dividends.

So we'll keep an eye on that stock.

Lots to keep an eye on this morning. Let's take a look at the European markets that picked up off that positive news from intel after the bell yesterday.

Trading higher this morning. As we take a look at our U.S. stock futures, we're seeing some green arrows on the screen as well. S&P 500 up .4 of a percent.

And stay with us on Fox Business for "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stuart Varney up at 9:20 Eastern Time.

In the meantime, you've got more IMUS IN THE MORNING coming to you next here on the Fox Business Network.

IMUS: All right. Six minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program.

That was probably the last time Friedman will be on, but -- I mean, that's crazy, isn't it?

MCCORD: Well, it's a little oversight.

IMUS: It has a greater impact on the health of people in this country than anything. More devastating to the environment than anything. Than anything.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK.

IMUS: And it wasn't on your radar?

MCCORD: Well, no, it wasn't on his radar. He had other elements of the problem. The sequel --

MCGUIRK: Maybe.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: He's updating from Beirut to whatever it is. Maybe he can update his stupid environment book, Hot, Flat, and Corrupt.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Keep it right here on the Fox Business Networkthroughout the day for the latest news and financial developments.

Then tonight at 6:00 Eastern Time, join Neil Cavuto and his guest, former New York City mayor Ed Koch. Ed Koch?

Tomorrow, on this program, we'll be joined by Anthony Mason of CBS News, and Mary and Carol Higgins Clark. Oh God. And they've got two new books. Oh, that's great.

And then Jerry Springer is going to be here to talk about his new game show.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Paula Deen is a best-selling author and the host of the Food Network's show "Paula's Home Cooking."

People love this woman.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: "Paula's Party," "Paula's Best Dishes." Her magazine, "Cooking With Paula Deen," appears bimonthly. She's the author of "Paula Deen: It Ain't All About the Cooking," "Christmas With Paula Deen," a whole bunch of other books, all have been best-sellers.

She's been on everything. She's the founder of the Lady and Sons restaurant, co-owner of Uncle Bubba's Oyster House.

She lives with her family in Savannah, Georgia. Her new book from Simon & Schuster is a coffee table book, beautiful, entitled "Paula Deen: Savannah Style," Paula Deen and Brandon Branch.

Please welcome to the program, Paula Deen.

Good morning, Ms. Deen.

PAULA DEEN, HOST, "PAULA'S HOME COOKING": Good morning, Imus. How are you?

IMUS: I'm fine, baby. How are you?

DEEN: What an intro. And may I say, I have loved listening to you and watching you through the years.

IMUS: Thank you very much. I appreciate that.

DEEN: Oh, I have loved it. And thank you so much for having me on.

IMUS: So, you got rid of the husband.

DEEN: Got rid of the husband, yes.

IMUS: What did he do?

DEEN: I was married for 27 years, and I married -- I met and married my neighbor when I moved out on to Wilmington Island. And we've been together six years, and it's like we're just soul mates and --

IMUS: Well, that's good.

DEEN: It's just been a wonderful, wonderful life. My husband liked cold beer more than his desire for his family, I guess you might say.

And he adored us. He adored us, but he could never put down the alcohol. And, you know, I tried for 27 years to fix it and I couldn't, so I had to accept the fact that I could not change that.

IMUS: It ruins everything.

You know -- we're talking with Paula Deen. Her new book called "Paula Deen: Savannah Style." It's a coffee table book. It is full of gorgeous photographs of how Paula and -- what's this guy's name, old Brandon?

DEEN: Brandon Branch.

IMUS: Old Brandon, who decorates these rooms. And man, you have to take your shoes off to walk into one of these rooms.

DEEN: Well, they're beautiful rooms. People -- Brandon and I, we tried to create a book that we could take people into these beautiful places, Imus, that when you come to Savannah you wouldn't ordinarily see.

You know, Savannah is made up of all kinds of magical, hidden gardens. And they're all behind walls, so you can't see them. So, this is our way of exposing people to these treasures.

IMUS: I like these songs you picked -- "At Last," Etta James.

DEEN: That was the song that my husband and I danced to, the first dance after our wedding.

IMUS: Your new husband?

DEEN: My new husband, yes.

IMUS: Oh, OK. Don't be picking songs --

DEEN: My for life husband.

IMUS: Don't be picking songs from the last one. We just got --

(LAUGHTER)

DEEN: You know, I ain't a quitter, Imus. It just kills me to give up. And so, you know, I hung in there for 27 years. So I said if I could hang in for 27 years with him, I could do 50 very easy with the man I'm with now.

IMUS: Well, that's one of the great records ever, and I love Elvis and Joe Cocker.

DEEN: Yes!

IMUS: Billy Joel, Ray Charles, not bad.

DEEN: Yes, yes, yes, yes.

IMUS: Well, it's a pleasure to talk with you.

DEEN: Soulful music. Well, the pleasure is all mine, my darling.

Like I said, I've been a fan for years, so to actually speak to you is just another wonderful memory for me to have.

IMUS: I can see why people love you, because I love you.

DEEN: Well, thank you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

IMUS: Time now for an IMUS IN THE MORNING Fox Business update. And here's Stuart Varney.

urn:contentItem:60X7-S4J1-F02J-835V-00000-00JPMorgan's $1 Billion Fine;Nike Stock Jumps2020-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:40ZLexisNexisINVESTINGStock Market NewsJPMorgan's $1 Billion FineNike Stock JumpsJohn Divine

Stocks are nearly in correction territory as the September swoon continues.

Wednesday was a wave of red on Wall Street, as all three major U.S. indices finished meaningfully lower. Bearish momentum has been building up in September as investors begin coming to terms with the growing likelihood that no further stimulus relief will be coming anytime soon.

The technology sector, which has been the star of the markets in 2020 and subject to recent scrutiny over high valuations, led Wednesday's sell-off, with the Nasdaq shedding 3%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 525 points, or 1.9%, to finish at 26,763.

[Sign up for stock news with our Invested newsletter.]

Nike's doing it. Shares of shoe and apparel giant Nike (ticker: NKE) popped 8.8% on Wednesday despite the broader market upheaval, as investors applauded blowout quarterly earnings and an upbeat forecast for the fiscal year.

Although revenue fell 1% from the same period a year ago, the $10.6 billion figure was nearly $1.5 billion higher than expectations, as the company's seen higher-than-expected demand for its products. Digital sales for the Nike brand surged 82% last quarter, and earnings per share actually rose 10% from a year ago.

Nike stock was up 25% in 2020 through Wednesday's close.

Looming JPMorgan settlement. JPMorgan ( JPM) is reportedly close to reaching a nearly $1 billion settlement with U.S. regulators over allegations it manipulated the market for metals and U.S. Treasurys. Three current or former JPM employees were criminally indicted last September under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, a law that gained prominence in the 1980s as it was wielded against organized crime.

DOJ homing in on Big Tech. It's no surprise that the U.S. Department of Justice aspires to clamp down on some of Silicon Valley's biggest names, but the department is now taking more concrete steps, putting a proposal before Congress that would trim back favorable legal parameters for companies like Twitter ( TWTR), Facebook ( FB) and Alphabet ( GOOG, GOOGL).

Current law limits the liability faced by such companies for content posted on their sites.

Picture, Behind stellar quarterly earnings and an upbeat forecast, Nike soared 8.8% on Wednesday., (Getty Images)
