Julian Howard discusses global economics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JULIAN HOWARD, HEAD OF MULTI-ASSET SOLUTIONS, GAM, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

MARCH 23, 2018

SPEAKERS: JULIAN HOWARD, HEAD OF MULTI-ASSET SOLUTIONS, GAM

ANNA EDWARDS, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And joining us now is Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM.

Julian, great to have you with us.

JULIAN HOWARD, HEAD OF MULTI-ASSET SOLUTIONS, GAM: Morning.

CEHIC: So we've just talked about the market reaction. Of course, you could argue, as some of it is knee-jerk at this point. I just want to quickly take you to a chart which is a great map, 7385, showing the exemptions so far globally, and from the U.S. tariffs.

Japan, notably absent from there. We have seen Japanese equities lead the losses overnight. How bad will things have to get for this sell-off to be sustained?

HOWARD: I think they would have to get a lot worse, and I don't think they will get a lot worse. So I think much of this is actually symbolic, and I think it's really about Trump appealing to the -- to his base, actually.

I mean, this was a -- a campaign promise, that he was going to do something about sort of undercutting, you know, Chinese imports and the way that that was undercutting U.S. industry. I think he's made that sort of symbolic gesture now.

And it's pretty small-scale, actually. I mean, this is -- this is not going to be -- have a big impact on growth. I think most of the estimates I've seen are about a 0.1 percent impact on U.S. GDP growth.

So it's all about symbolism. It's in line with, if you read "The Art of the Deal," it's in line with sort of making a big hoo-ha and then bringing people to the negotiating table.

So I think the market reaction, probably so far, is already a little bit sort of over -- overdone.

CEHIC: Right. And we have seen some key technicals. I can bring up a chart to show you that later. But we are only on day one. What would need to happen where you actually start to become concerned and think that the sell-off could be more sustained?

We heard Tom Mackenzie, there, point to some of the extra measures that China could take.

HOWARD: Yes. I -- I, well, I think it would have to be much more broad- based. I think it would have to be more -- more than just steel and aluminum. It would have to be across the board. It would have to be much more punitive. And then there would have to be immediate escalation. The exemptions would have to be rolled back.

I mean, I suppose technically the exemptions are on a temporary basis. Some of them are sort of, "We'll have this until -- this exemption until we have a conversation." So it could be that when that conversation happens, the exemption is, in fact, repealed.

So it -- it could, in theory, get a -- get a whole lot worse. But I would agree with the analyst that you quoted, that actually this is quite moderate so far. And -- and my sense is that it will remain pretty moderate, and that this will blow over and the news cycle will move on.

ANNA EDWARDS, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes. I mean, good morning, Julian. Listening to Trump's press conference yesterday, and actually listening to what Wilbur Ross had to say. He finished with some quite brief comments, saying "We'll end up negotiating, not fighting about this," were his words.

And then also, another reason to be cheerful if you -- if you like globalization, I suppose. He did talk about the -- the U.S. is going to challenge -- or -- or the government talked about how the U.S. is going to challenge China licensing practices at the WTO.

So some signs, at least, that the aim here is to get to negotiating table, and also that some of the well-trodden routes and paths to resolve these disputes may still be used. Some of those four (ph) that we thought were cast aside by the Trump administration could still be used, such as the WTO.

HOWARD: Yeah. I mean, I absolutely agree. I -- I think the aim, here, is not to damage U.S. GDP growth. I mean, the -- the administration has quoted the stock market, GDP growth and unemployment relentlessly since early 2017, as sort of signs of its success in economic policy.

And I think deep down, they realize that a concerted trade war, an all-out trade war, would be absolutely catastrophic. You know, surely the memory of the -- of the 1920s and the way that trade tariffs were increased by six percent, just at the wrong moment, that sent the U.S. into depression -- I think people are still conscious of that.

So I can't imagine that even this administration would want to risk those - - those kind of milestones that it's been marking out so -- so clearly over the last 18 months or so.

EDWARDS: And, Julian, we heard Trump also talk about how this is partly being driven by his desire to reduce the trade deficit with China. What would -- I mean, it -- clearly, a recession in the United States and reducing U.S. consumer spending would -- would do something to go along that route, but he doesn't want to do that, I'm sure.

But -- so what would bring down the trade deficit between the United States and China?

HOWARD: Well, I -- I guess an all-out trade war would, where -- whereby Chinese exports into the U.S. is -- is seriously constrained.

But I -- I think, actually, it's your first point that is the most obvious for bringing down that trade deficit, that actually there's a recession and the U.S. consumer's propensity to consume is based on imports. So as consumers feel wealthier, imports tend to get sucked in. So it would be one of those two things, neither of which is particularly desirable.

So actually, for me, the trade deficit is, in fact, a kind of indicator of economic health. And I don't think we should target it as this sort of boogeyman that needs to be corrected.

CEHIC: Julian, just got to break a headline crossing the Bloomberg. The Shanghai Composite Index has fallen 4.3 percent, extending its losses.

And at this point, if you're a Bloomberg client I just want to draw your attention to the TLIV blog on the Bloomberg that is tracking all the latest on this day one of a potential trade war, including all the market reaction. And, crucially, some of the key levels you want to watch in these equity indices over in Asia.

We've already seen the MSCI Asia Pacific Index drop below the 50- and 100- day moving average, and also we've seen Japanese equities drop below the 200-day moving average.

But I just want to still show this chart, Julian, which is 5781, and it's the risk-on, risk-off index. Bank of America Merrill Lynch did a survey recently, showing that even though investors are really concerned about things like trade, stagflation, they're still long-risk assets. Why?

HOWARD: Well, I think risk assets still represent the best risk-adjusted return versus Treasury bonds. I mean, the equity risk premium at the moment in the United States is two points -- about 2.6 to 2.8 percent.

So you are getting 2.8 percent more from holding stocks than you are from the risk-free rate in treasuries. That's attractive. And history suggests that a risk premium of about 2.8 percent goes on to give you a return of around six to eight percent from equities over the following two years. That's not a bad -- that's not a bad outcome.

CEHIC: All right. Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM, stays with us.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM, still with us on set in London.

Julian, when you look at the latest changes, we've got concern around protectionism writ large across these markets today. I guess the last thing investors needed was another concern, and that might be geopolitics.

Do these moves increase your concern that the hawk of hawks, as Eurasia (ph) calls him, will bring more geopolitical risk?

HOWARD: Well, I mean, John Bolton wrote this paper, didn't he? I think it was a couple of years ago. "The Legal Case for Attacking North Korea." So we kind of see what his -- what his -- his view is. You've got to -- you've got to set that off against Trump's sort of desire to do a deal.

And I think the idea of sitting down with Kim Jong is actually going to be so tempting for the -- for the U.S. president. You know, to be able to pull off this sort of grand master stroke.

So I think even though there are more hawks in the administration now, I think Trump won't sort of -- resist the temptation to sit down and try and pull off something, incredible deal around North Korea.

Now if that fails, we'll -- we'll have to see. But I think at the moment, it's not obvious that just having John Bolton in there is -- is going to mean a -- a kind of cooling of relations with North Korea.

If anything, things have gone quite well recently, and I think Donald Trump will want to sit down with -- with Kim Jong and try -- try and pull something off.

CEHIC: Julian, the 10-year Treasury yield hovering around 2.8 percent. Does it go lower from here on these concerns?

HOWARD: There -- there may be some short-term re-rating of growth, but I think the reason that the Treasury yield hasn't gone lower -- and this was something that we were talking about earlier -- I think it's because a lot of growth has (ph) priced into it.

It's not so much that the break-even is -- is moving, it's not so much an inflation change although that is, partly, a factor because of what Jerome Powell said about inflation. That there is no inflation threat. But it's just still a lot of growth priced into that yield.

CEHIC: Yes, and I'm so glad we showed this chart that you highlighted there as well, highlighted that point.

Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM, stays with us.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Let's now bring in Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM.

So, Julian, we've seen the reaction in Asian equities. We'll find out, in about an hour and a half, how European equities are going to react to all this.

In this potential global trade war, how much does Europe actually have to - - have to lose economically?

HOWARD: I think it could be significant, but I'm -- I'm very much encouraged by that initial exemption that's been granted, although it only lasts for -- it's a temporary one. But I'm -- I'm very much encouraged by that. So I think -- I think something will be -- something will be sorted out around that.

But I think, potentially, it -- you know, worst case, it could be very, very significant but I just don't think that's going to be the reality. I'm very encouraged that an exemption has been granted in the first instance.

CEHIC: What sort of impact might we see on the euro in all this? We've seen the yen bid, questions over whether it could go to 100. Does the dollar weaken and therefore the euro strengthens on the back of this and weighs on European inflation --

HOWARD: Yes.

CEHIC: -- I mean, what's the dynamic here?

HOWARD: Oh, it could -- I mean, it could even be the other way around --

CEHIC: Yes.

HOWARD: -- but actually, if -- if we have a really big trade war and a massive crisis, economic crisis, you know, the -- the dollar could become a haven currency.

But it -- you know, it used to have that status but it sort of kind of lost out to -- to the Japanese yen. But that could -- that could resume again. So potentially, you could get euro weakening from this point. Which, ironically, would actually be quite helpful for the eurozone's exporters and, indeed, the European equity market.

So there's a lot -- there's a lot of factors swirling around at the moment. So it's very difficult to make a kind of clear currency call on -- on euro- dollar. But generally, euro strength has been a bit of a headwind for European equities. So potentially an unwind of that could -- could be helpful, but for the wrong reasons.

EDWARDS: Julian, we heard from Mario Draghi, he was here briefing E.U. leaders yesterday. He talked about four risks. And one of them -- and in fact, the top one -- was around protectionisms. And it's clearly very much on the Central Bank's radar. Protectionism is the biggest risk to the European economy.

He also talks about less reliance on international forums that have been used previously, of course.

But in -- in terms of the size and scope of this -- this fear or this risk, the fact that Draghi puts that at the top at number one, suggests that it's something that the ECB is watching incredibly closely.

HOWARD: Yes. And I think that's actually potentially encouraging for -- for European stocks. I mean, it means that the interest rates in -- within the eurozone are going to be kept on the floor. I think that the language is -- was fairly dovish at the last conference.

He cited this risk, he recognizes that the Q.E. program's going to end in September, but he -- he was at pains to say that that doesn't mean that interest rates are going to be the next step.

So rates will stay low and I think this -- any fear of a trade war is going to keep rates even -- even sort of more permanently low than -- than we -- than market currently anticipates. So that could be good for equities.

EDWARDS: Could be good (ph) (INAUDIBLE). Interesting story on the Bloomberg, also, around productivity in Europe, Julian. As some of our colleagues writing about how some of the measures that have been taken by European governments are actually driving up productivity that -- labor that was on the sidelines is now coming back into the workforce.

And so as a result, Europe is actually discovering more slack, which means it can continue growing without creating inflation.

Now, while some of that might sound like very good news, as, of course, that makes the ECB's job more difficult when it continues to try and generate inflation.

HOWARD: Yes. I mean, we -- we talk about the Phillips curve challenge (ph) within the U.S., don't we? But Europe isn't even there yet. So we haven't even tested the Phillips curve in Europe.

You know, unemployment is -- is just under, I think, 10 percent at this point. So Europe can actually sustain a sort of Goldilocks scenario, whereby growth continues to improve but there's no inflation.

Yes, that might be frustrating for -- for the ECB, but I think actually it's -- it's probably quite a good state of affairs. And then we can sort of resume the conversation, I guess, when unemployment gets to the sort of six percent, five percent level.

But I think in the meantime, there's quite a nice sort of Goldilocks-type path for Europe, whereby growth improves but there's no -- no price pressure at the same time.

CEHIC: But Julian, what about the fact that we've seen some softness in recent eurozone PMIs for two months in a row, now? And not only that, but if I take you to this chart, 8431, the economic surprise index, the Citi (ph) economic surprise index actually undershooting expectations by the most in two years. Are eurozone equities still a buy, despite all this?

HOWARD: I -- I think there are two things going on. One is that the euro has been quite strong against the dollar. I think we're around 1.23 at the moment for that -- is proving a headwind for what I call "global Europe," so that's sort of globally-facing European exporters, that's - that is a bit of a challenge.

So I -- I think that -- that can be a bit of a headwind. And also, there - - there's this idea of hedonic adaptation, which is -- whereby, you know, the data's so -- has been so relentlessly good that people have just got used to it.

So unless the data remains, you know, amazing and continues to surprise, you're going to get this rollover in the indices. It doesn't mean that in absolute terms, that the data is poor.

You know, The PMIs are still firmly expansionary. But, yes, they've come off a little bit recently. But that's maybe one or two data points, so I don't think we can draw conclusions quite yet.

CEHIC: Julian, one of the points of discussion that was meant to happen at the E.U. leader (ph) summit but has sort of been pushed back somewhat, is this transitional deal. Does that change anything in the way you look at the U.K. as an investment destination?

HOWARD: Yes. So I -- I'm probably -- I've been quite optimistic so far this morning. On Brexit, I think, I'm -- I'm a bit more pessimistic, and particularly around this -- this conference that's happening today.

I think the Irish still have the ability to pull the plug on the transition deal. So we have this sort of run-up in sterling, sort of increased optimism that we're going to get transition.

But unless the Irish are happy around the border arrangement, they could still pull the plug. I mean, that would be the nuclear option for them, given that both governments got a stake in the Good Friday Agreement.

But -- but it is possible. I mean, there are red lines here around, you know, around a hard border. And we have this backstop idea, but I don't think the U.K.'s going to accept that, and I don't think that the DUP will either.

So that -- that is still an area of concern. In terms of investments, we try and avoid the U.K., not so much because of Brexit but we think the opportunities are better elsewhere, for example emerging markets.

EDWARDS: What would make you change your mind, Julian? What would change the dial for you on the Brexit conversation? Are you looking for, actually, the U.K. government to change its stance and decide to stay in the Customs Union? Would that be a game-changer? Or do you just need to see the existing plan delivered against? What -- what's the priority?

HOWARD: Yes. I -- I think it would be -- it would be what we call "BINO," Brexit in Name Only. You know, so that's a -- the sort of latest acronym doing the rounds. But I think some kind of Customs Union is (ph) at (ph) a very soft Brexit, where it's just a -- a kind of nominal "Yes, we'll tick the box that we are outside the European Union, but in every other way we are essentially still in."

I think that's really the only way to sort of preserve growth and access to -- to the markets that -- that, certainly, the financial community is looking for. But I think at the moment, we're headed for something probably a little harder.

I mean, there have been signs from, certainly, the hard Brexiteers, such as (INAUDIBLE) and Rees-Mogg, for example that, you know, there are signs of pragmatism, that he can't get everything that -- that he wants. Not that he represents the hard Brexit camp on his own, but there are signs that this could be a compromise.

So we're probably not going to have the hardest Brexit. It's -- at the moment, it looks like we're -- we're set on a middle course. But it's still going to be damaging for -- for growth in -- in the medium term for the U.K.

EDWARDS: What do asset allocation decisions look like around U.K. assets then, at GAM? When you talk about this, Julian. You said you're pretty negative on the Brexit story. But which of the assets that look -- look better than others, I suppose?

HOWARD: Yes. So I mean, it's not -- we're underweight, the U.K., not so much because of Brexit. Because, of course, there's this inverse relationship with sterling and the FTSE. So we're -- if -- if there was catastrophes, sterling would fall and the FTSE would -- would conversely rise.

And -- and we can't get a handle on -- on where sterling is going. It's very, very hard to predict how the currency is going to behave. 2018 saw sterling appreciate, and that was kind of quite unexpected. So we -- we try and stay neutral around sterling.

And then in terms of the equity market, we're underweight. But that's really because we -- we just think there are better opportunities elsewhere, such as emerging markets. Particularly now that we've had these sort of three, four percent sell-offs overnight. You know, across Asia.

I think that makes emerging markets very, very attractive. They're already trading at around 70 percent of the valuation of global equities, and now they're probably even cheaper.

So E.M., I think, is where the future lies. And -- and we've come to see almost quasi-permanent overweight allocations to that area. I mean, that - - that is where the growth is now, it's where the growth is in the long term.

EDWARDS: OK. Tying back nicely -- tying back nicely, Julian, to our top story, whether these market sell-offs, these equity sell-offs are overdone (ph). Thank you very much.

Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM, stays with us here on the program.

(BREAK)

EDWARDS: Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM, is still with us.

Again, difficult for the IPOs, I guess. But looking at the tax sector more broadly, then, Julian, it's been, of course, a fascinating week in the Facebook story.

Broadening that out, would it be -- to put it too strongly, to talk about a real threat to the business models? Almost an existential threat to any business models in tech that rely on the sale of data.

And I know Facebook doesn't only rely on that, it relies on other things like advertising. But any tech stock that relies only on the sale of data, does it have to worry more about regulatory risk now?

HOWARD: Yes. I -- I think there is the possibility of increased regulation. And I think Mark Zuckerberg gave a very sort of guarded invitation to -- for increased regulation, although I think it was more for the advertisers than for his own company.

But I think more generally, social -- the sort of social media tech is having something of a tobacco moment here, where -- whereby the business model is kind of being revealed to -- to the users.

I mean, the users, I think, are starting to realize that they are not the client. That, actually, it's the advertisers that are the clients, and in fact the user is paying for this apparently free service, you know, with the currency of their privacy and their data, which is then being, sort of -- they don't have control over it once they've handed it over.

So I -- I think it actually boosts the case for active management around technology. You know, perhaps starting to look very carefully around social media companies and -- and wondering whether, you know, the business model is sustainable, or at least is correctly priced.

And perhaps focusing instead on what I call the "second-line technology sectors," such as storage and automation. And, I guess, Dropbox, at a push, falls into the storage category.

EDWARDS: And perhaps you look at other -- other things, like hardware. Are you interested in tech hardware at this time, or perhaps other geographies? We were looking -- talking about the Tencent earnings earlier on this week. I mean, perhaps there is less of a regulatory threat in other parts of the world.

HOWARD: Yes. And I -- I think also, the fact that we've had this sell-off in Asia actually makes some of the -- some of the Asian, you know, companies, particularly attractive.

I mean, in -- I mean, without getting stock-specific, in the U.S. you have these sort of FANG (ph) giants who are considered unassailable. But I think it's the case that a lot of the Asian companies have -- have sort of been holding off competing with them because of the anti-Chinese rhetoric that's coming out of Washington.

So at some point, maybe if you're a long-term -- very, very long-term investor, this is a good time to buy, see through the Trump administration, then these guys start to compete against the FANGs (ph), that could be a very interesting opportunity.

EDWARDS: Yes. Julian -- I mean, and also we don't yet know exactly how GDPR, the advent of that in the E.U. might impact tech stocks globally as well.

But away from regulation, the trade story. Does that pose any concern around threat -- around tech, particularly in the U.S.?

HOWARD: Yes. Well, there's -- I guess there's the intellectual property issue. And we've also seen that the block -- the blocking of the deal between Qualcomm and Broadcom, although technically I think that's (ph) Singaporean rather than Chinese. So I think that's always something to bear in mind.

But what interests me is the fact that Asian tech at the moment is looking, you know, it's four percent cheaper today than it was, potentially, yesterday.

So I think that could be interesting, especially given that, in the U.S., it's really tech that's driven the market up all this way. And now that has been reversed. So it just makes Asia look that bit more attractive versus the U.S.

CEHIC: Yes. To that point, I've got a chart here, 516, in terms of the weight of tech. And this chart also shows -- shows the weight of financials, incidentally, of the S&P 500. Does that make you less positive on U.S. stocks overall? Or is there another narrative that means you're still bullish on them?

HOWARD: Well it -- it makes me think, actually, that -- that, if anything, you've got to be selective with tech. But actually, financials are the opportunity here. I think we were just commenting that the 10-year yield has not fallen as much as expected. And financials tend to do pretty well if you get a -- a rising 10-year yield and a -- and a sort of falling short-term.

Now we haven't had that so much yet, but the -- I think the backdrop's in place. Jerome Powell has talked about, you know, inflation not being the threat that everyone thinks it is, which suggests that the short-term should stay low.

Meanwhile, growth is improving in America. We've seen the ISM Manufacturing. That'll push the 10-year higher. This should be good for financial stocks.

CEHIC: So it's deepening (ph). Right -- Anna.

EDWARDS: Julian -- Julian, here in Brussels, the leaders gathered yesterday and one of the things they did do was cast some doubt over the European Commission's plan for a three percent revenue tax on some of these big tech companies.

That would -- would that be quite an unprecedented move, to see revenues taxed in that way?

HOWARD: I think it would. And I think it would be very self-interested. I mean, the problem is that Europe simply doesn't have the -- you know, the tech giants that -- that the U.S. does.

And I think this is part of the reason that European equities have this quasi-permanent discount against world equities. That there is no technology representation. Whereas in the U.S., obviously, it's a very big part of it.

So I think the Europeans need to be a bit careful about seeming to be anti- competitive, and it -- well, in fact, they didn't even have a tech industry to protect -- in the way that the U.S. does. So I -- I think it's a good move, if they -- if they roll back from that.

CEHIC: Julian Howard, head of Multi-Asset Solutions at GAM. Thank you so much for being with us.

And Julian continues the conversation with us at 7:30 am U.K. time, on radio.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

London: MP Julian Knight has issued the following news release: This week Parliament’s Digital, Culture, Media, and Sport Committee, on which I sit, published a damning new report into the role of social media in British society. MPs from all the major parties have spent the past two years investigating how Facebook and other tech companies can undermine our democracy and expose vulnerable individuals to harm – and now we’ve set out tough proposals to start putting it right. First, we want to make the social media giants sign up to a new code of ethics, backed up by a powerful independent regulator.

This would oblige them to take down illegal or harmful content as quickly as possible – and punish them if they don’t. We also want to introduce a new levy on the big tech companies and use it to beef up the Information Commissioner’s Office, who we have called on to launch an in-depth investigation into how Facebook uses (or misuses) its customers’ data. Further reforms are needed to help protect our democratic process. Our report calls for rigorous new transparency rules for online campaigning, and an increase in the powers of the Electoral Commission to collect evidence and issue fines for inappropriate behaviour. As a member of the Committee I have seen first-hand the harm that unregulated social media companies can do – and the huge level of global interest in our pioneering bid to bring them under control. When last year I called Facebook a “morality-free zone” whilst questioning its Chief Technical Officer, Mike Shroepfer, my comments were picked up by media outlets from all over the world. In more local news, I am very pleased to report that over seven hundred local residents have so far signed my petition urging the Post Office to reconsider their plans to close and relocate their local branch in Mell Square. I know from those of you that have got in touch with me about this that the proposals are the cause of a deal of worry here in Solihull, and at the end of the month I intend to present my petition to the House of Commons to highlight the strength of local feeling about this important local service.

urn:contentItem:5VFV-NS41-JCF2-H4F3-00000-00Julie Samuels: The big tech companies were built in vacuum. Those days are gone2019-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisEGI NEWSJulie Samuels: The big tech companies were built in vacuum. Those days are goneEmily Wright

The Google glory days are over, says executive director of Tech:NYC, as a new swathe of firms emerge in a tougher, more regulated environment.Julie Samuels is all about the future. Not unusual for someone who lives and breathes technology. But the executive director of Tech:NYC, an organisation that represents New York’s tech economy and works with city and state government on tech policies, is more forward-looking than most. So much so, she is not afraid to call the end of a phase of the current technology cycle that many might still consider a sign of things to come.“The last round of huge tech companies were created in the Valley and other more isolated geographies,” she says.

“Basically, places where people weren’t paying much attention and a company could be built and grown without anyone noticing. Those glory days are gone. The last generation of really big tech companies were built in vacuum. Regulators weren’t paying attention. Competitors weren’t paying attention.“I believe in these big companies, like Facebook and Google, but they would have a really hard time launching in New York. Especially now, with regulation hotting up. And I don’t think we will see the likes of them launch again now. It’s just not the world we live in any more. You can’t build a tech company now without people noticing very quickly and you need to know how to navigate thorny situations like handling competitors and regulators. We are good at that here in New York.”Compatible with techIt is this, she says, that makes strong, business-oriented cities like London and New York more compatible with tech start-ups than ever before.“In New York and cities like New York everyone is much more integrated with each other and you know the policy makers, your competition and your potential customers and clients.“Regulation will make starting up and growing businesses even more complicated, so you need to be somewhere people already know how to have these tough conversations.”What Samuels is effectively describing is the maturity of the tech sector. A process that will happen in stages most likely led by fintech with the likes of real estate technology, which is moving at a glacial pace in comparison, following behind.But she is confident that some of the proptech leaders are now at a stage that indicates the sector is in a strong enough position to weather a stricter, more regulated market.“We are seeing some big exits,” she says. “And there will be more. So some of these larger proptech companies – such as Compass and even Zillow – are starting to make a lot of people a lot of money. And they will put their money back into investing in a new crop of proptech companies and start-ups and it becomes a rinse-and-repeat cycle.“The idea is that when you have these big exits you create an ecosystem. You see the emergence of people who are smart about a certain thing with the money to put their capital – and I mean intellectual capital, too into the next generation. And then it starts to feed off itself. The tides are turning and changing.“Some of that is just customer and consumer demand. But proptech is getting accepted by the people who control real estate.“Look at the actual money. It’s widespread. People have a fear of missing out and you have really big companies out there now such as Cadre and Convene. These are not start-ups any more and the property sector can see it. It tips and then it goes. I think we are there at that tipping point now.”Part and parcel of this maturity is the increasingly prominent role of governments and policy makers in technology. While Samuels warns against over E'regulation, she says the government and public sector approach to (and involvement in) technology has never been more important.Industrial revolution“The path to building a successful technology business or integrating technology into a real estate business is hard and it’s complicated,” she says.“This emergence of technology worldwide will be like another industrial revolution in terms of its impact and job creation. There will be big winners but there is also going to be a lot of disruption. And government has a huge role to play in minimising that disruption, in making that transition better for its citizens.”To send feedback, e-mail emily.wright@egi.co.uk or tweet @EmilyW_9 or @estatesgazette

urn:contentItem:609C-X291-DXKH-N34J-00000-00July 03, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Fishing Bans And Import Costs Feed Through To Impact Bangladeshi Consumer Spending2020-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 03, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Fishing Bans And Import Costs Feed Through To Impact Bangladeshi Consumer Spending

Despite rising incomes, Bangladesh's fish consumption (their main protein source) has declined relative to rice. This is because of the rapid inflation of the domestic fish price, causing local consumers to switch to cheaper alternatives. The reason for this inflation is the difference in the domestic and export prices of fish, as well as short term pressures on fi.

Business Monitor International Inc. provides Country Risk and industry research analysis in the United States. The company was incorporated in 2009 and is based in New York, New York. Business Monitor International Inc. operates as a subsidiary of Business Monitor International Ltd.

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. We believe that international and domestic fitness service providers that continue to innovate, and continue to offer unique exercise experiences will be best placed to grow their offering and engage wit.

Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

Source: Company Website

We maintain our outlook for medium term crude oil production in Guyana as ExxonMobil positions Guyana at the centre of its investment strategy and restores production after technical issue. Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite surrounding countries in the region struggling. The government will continue to implement key fiscal policies to stimulate the economy. Healthcare spending per capita in Uruguay remains the highest in Latin America. Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite s.

As many nations struggle to keep Covid-19 infection numbers down, Taiwan has benefited greatly from the close coordination between its hospitals and central government. Another reason for Taiwan's success can be attributable to Taiwan's well-renowned healthcare system. Drug pricing pressure will weigh on the pharmaceutical market growth.

Demand for electric vehicles (EV)s in Austria will increase in 2020 following the announcement by the country's Ministry for Climate, Energy and Transportation that it plans to increase existing incentives aimed at reducing the cost purchasing an EV. The pending deadline for the implementation of EU wide emissions standards will boost demand for Plug-In Hybrid Vehicles (PHEV).

Based on clinical trial data from Russia and China, Russia has included favipiravir in its Covid-19 treatment guidelines. At a population level the benefits demonstrated by the drug in trials will help to alleviate the burden on Russia's strained healthcare system. We expect more countries to approve the medicines in order to tackle their respective Covid-19 outbrea.

Cuba's government has taken a proactive approach to fight the Covid-19 pandemic. Cuba maintains a high level of healthcare coverage and a world-class medical service in terms of basic healthcare indicators. The Covid-19 outbreak will pose additional challenges for Cuba, the economy of which has been battered in recent quarters by US sanctions and this will weigh on.

We do not expect a rapid, widespread expansio.

Over the long run, we expect growth in the Americas copper mine production will slow slightly but remain on a positive trajectory as favourable industry fundamentals continue to incentivise exploration and project approvals in the region. We expect Chile and Peru to remain regional outperformers, maintaining their status as the top two copper producers globally.

Multichoice is attempting to add value and stem declines in its South African pay-TV business by adding Netflix and Amazon Video streaming services to its premium bundles. For the over-the-top (OTT) players, greater exposure to a ready-made customer base and the opportunity to also tap demand for their standalone services will be the main appeal.

Source: Company Website

June 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Thailand To Speed Up Development And Local Production Of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients

Thailand will remain a key pharmaceutical market for drugmakers. There is a strong will to incentivize the production of active pharmaceutical ingredients locally and boosting Thailand's appeal for foreign drugmaker investment. Risks in the form of medicine pricing and budgeting for healthcare threaten drugmakers' revenue-earning capabilities.

Source: Company Website

June 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Serbia IT Spending To Rebound Post-Covid, With Cloud And E-Commerce In Focus

Demand for IT hardware, software and services products will be set back considerably in 2020, owing to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on supply chains and enterprise purchasing. The PC segment will be hit hardest, owing to restrictions on imports, although we had already expected sluggish growth as the market enjoyed a robust period of growth in 2019 due to upgrades driv.

Source: Company Website

June 12: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos: Key Markets Struggle With Covid-19 Impact

Asia will be one of the hardest hit regions globally in 2020 with a 16.1% decline in vehicle sales. Passenger vehicle sales will see the biggest decline of 16.8% compared with 13.5% for commercial vehicles as some countries turn to infrastructure spending as part of their recovery efforts, generating commercial vehicle demand. Covid-19 has created some upside poten

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

urn:contentItem:609C-X291-DXKH-N34H-00000-00July 03, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Higher Incentive Levels To Boost Austrian EV Sales In 20202020-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:40ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 03, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Higher Incentive Levels To Boost Austrian EV Sales In 2020

Demand for electric vehicles (EV)s in Austria will increase in 2020 following the announcement by the country's Ministry for Climate, Energy and Transportation that it plans to increase existing incentives aimed at reducing the cost purchasing an EV. The pending deadline for the implementation of EU wide emissions standards will boost demand for Plug-In Hybrid Vehicles (PHEV).

INDEX

SECTION 1 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. PROFILE

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2020

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2020

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

SECTION 1 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. PROFILE

1.1 ACTIVITIES

Business Monitor International Inc. provides Country Risk and industry research analysis in the United States. The company was incorporated in 2009 and is based in New York, New York. Business Monitor International Inc. operates as a subsidiary of Business Monitor International Ltd.

1.2 SUMMARY

PermID: 4296431365

Website: http://www.businessmonitor.com

Industry: Software and Technology Servic

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2020

June 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bahamas Poor Fiscal Outlook To Constrain Healthcare Spending

We at Fitch Solutions see downside risks to Bahamas growth as the coronavirus pandemic may cause extended damage to the tourism industry. The government's healthcare budget will come under pressure in the near term, as the Bahamas recovers from Hurricane Dorian and the Covid-19 impact. The Bahamas could increasingly attract investment from active pharmaceutical ingr.

Source: Company Website

May 13: Business Monitor International Inc.: Myanmar Emergency Tenders To Support Gas-Fired Power Growth

We have revised our Myanmar thermal capacity forecasts to account for the progress of several gas-fired projects under emergency tenders. While these projects have faced delays and missed their operational deadlines as we expected, progress will mean that they are likely to still come online within two years, by a conservative estimate.

Source: Company Website

April 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Collaborations Aim To Eliminate Medical Device Shortages Caused By Covid-19

Due to the increasing prevalence of Covid-19 (coronavirus), the demand for ventilators, personal protective equipment and testing devices is likely to remain unmet in the short term. In order to meet the sudden demand for respiratory devices, large medical device companies such as GE healthcare are collaborating with both medical and non-medical manufacturers. The d.

Source: Company Website

March 20: Business Monitor International Inc.: Big Tech After Covid-19: Cash And Regulation

We believe the Big Tech companies are in a strong position to expand post-coronavirus. There could be greater divergence between the US and the EU when it comes to tech regulation.

Source: Company Website

March 19: Business Monitor International Inc.: Gym And Fitness Subscription A Trend To Watch In China, Despite Covid-19 Outbreak

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. We believe that international and domestic fitness service providers that continue to innovate, and continue to offer unique exercise experiences will be best placed to grow their offering and engage wit.

Source: Company Website

March 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Sub-Saharan Africa 4G Developments: Licences, Launches And Investment

Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2020

July 07: Business Monitor International Inc.: Guyana And Suriname Continue To Attract IOCs Despite Political Uncertainty

We maintain our outlook for medium term crude oil production in Guyana as ExxonMobil positions Guyana at the centre of its investment strategy and restores production after technical issue. The commitment to exploration programmes from several international oil companies and ExxonMobil's farm-in to an offshore block constitutes an upside risk for Suriname's long term crude oi.

Source: Company Website

July 06: Business Monitor International Inc.: Uruguay's High Healthcare Expenditure Helps To Keep Covid-19 Pandemic Under Control

Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite surrounding countries in the region struggling. The government will continue to implement key fiscal policies to stimulate the economy. Healthcare spending per capita in Uruguay remains the highest in Latin America. Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite s.

Source: Company Website

July 06: Business Monitor International Inc.: Taiwan's Early Success Makes It A Role Model For Covid-19 Pandemic Management

As many nations struggle to keep Covid-19 infection numbers down, Taiwan has benefited greatly from the close coordination between its hospitals and central government. Another reason for Taiwan's success can be attributable to Taiwan's well-renowned healthcare system. Drug pricing pressure will weigh on the pharmaceutical market growth.

Source: Company Website

July 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Fishing Bans And Import Costs Feed Through To Impact Bangladeshi Consumer Spending

Despite rising incomes, Bangladesh's fish consumption (their main protein source) has declined relative to rice. This is because of the rapid inflation of the domestic fish price, causing local consumers to switch to cheaper alternatives. The reason for this inflation is the difference in the domestic and export prices of fish, as well as short term pressures on fi.

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Covid-19 Lockdowns To Accelerate E-Commerce Development In Latin America

rica are or have been in a state of lockdown, due to the spread of Covid-19 across the region. These lockdowns or stay at home orders have highlighted the value of e-Commerce, with consumers required to remain in their homes and so they have been utilising e-Commerce as a way shop, especially for non-essential goods and it is st

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Azeri Oil Sector Battling Accelerated Decline

Commitment to the OPEC+ production cut deal will place additional downside pressure on Azeri downside pressure over H220 and 2021, with government mandating cutbacks among private players. The Covid-19 induced price collapse will accelerate underlying decline rates, as companies sharply reduce their capital expenditures. The country has already been battling with declines, du.

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Russia Includes Avifavir In Covid-19 Treatment Protocol

Based on clinical trial data from Russia and China, Russia has included favipiravir in its Covid-19 treatment guidelines. At a population level the benefits demonstrated by the drug in trials will help to alleviate the burden on Russia's strained healthcare system. We expect more countries to approve the medicines in order to tackle their respective Covid-19 outbrea.

Source: Company Website

June 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: Healthcare System In Cuba Better Placed To Fight Covid-19 Pandemic

Cuba's government has taken a proactive approach to fight the Covid-19 pandemic. Cuba maintains a high level of healthcare coverage and a world-class medical service in terms of basic healthcare indicators. The Covid-19 outbreak will pose additional challenges for Cuba, the economy of which has been battered in recent quarters by US sanctions and this will weigh on.

Source: Company Website

June 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: EU's Contribution To Zimbabwe's Healthcare Fund Will Help Tackle The Covid-19 Pandemic

Zimbabwe continues to struggle to cope with the Covid-19 pandemic. The USD41mn contribution from the EU will help Zimbabwe reach its humanitarian appeal goal The lifting of the government freezing ban on healthcare will boost medical care available to the public.

Source: Company Website

June 18: Business Monitor International Inc.: Orange Africa Telecoms Expansion To Be Measured And Target High Value Markets

Orange is considering expanding its presence in Africa, tapping into the South Africa and Nigeria markets as potential near-term targets. A greenfield strategy is possible but Orange's desire for a more speedy entrance could see it acquire an outright, or significant, interest in established operators seeking investment. We do not expect a rapid, widespread expansio.

Source: Company Website

June 17: Business Monitor International Inc.: Americas Long-Term Copper Mine Development Outlook Remains Robust

Over the long run, we expect growth in the Americas copper mine production will slow slightly but remain on a positive trajectory as favourable industry fundamentals continue to incentivise exploration and project approvals in the region. We expect Chile and Peru to remain regional outperformers, maintaining their status as the top two copper producers globally.

Source: Company Website

June 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Multichoice Looks To OTT Players To Boost South African Pay-TV Appeal

Multichoice is attempting to add value and stem declines in its South African pay-TV business by adding Netflix and Amazon Video streaming services to its premium bundles. For the over-the-top (OTT) players, greater exposure to a ready-made customer base and the opportunity to also tap demand for their standalone services will be the main appeal.

Source: Company Website

June 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Thailand To Speed Up Development And Local Production Of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients

Thailand will remain a key pharmaceutical market for drugmakers. There is a strong will to incentivize the production of active pharmaceutical ingredients locally and boosting Thailand's appeal for foreign drugmaker investment. Risks in the form of medicine pricing and budgeting for healthcare threaten drugmakers' revenue-earning capabilities.

Source: Company Website

June 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Serbia IT Spending To Rebound Post-Covid, With Cloud And E-Commerce In Focus

Demand for IT hardware, software and services products will be set back considerably in 2020, owing to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on supply chains and enterprise purchasing. The PC segment will be hit hardest, owing to restrictions on imports, although we had already expected sluggish growth as the market enjoyed a robust period of growth in 2019 due to upgrades driv.

Source: Company Website

June 12: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos: Key Markets Struggle With Covid-19 Impact

Asia will be one of the hardest hit regions globally in 2020 with a 16.1% decline in vehicle sales. Passenger vehicle sales will see the biggest decline of 16.8% compared with 13.5% for commercial vehicles as some countries turn to infrastructure spending as part of their recovery efforts, generating commercial vehicle demand. Covid-19 has created some upside poten

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

Gregory Roth, Global Head-Communications

Lyndsey Anderson, Global Head-Research

We expect Chile and Peru to remain regional outperformers, maintaining their status as the top two copper producers globally.

Source: Company Website

June 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Multichoice Looks To OTT Players To Boost South African Pay-TV Appeal

Multichoice is attempting to add value and stem declines in its South African pay-TV business by adding Netflix and Amazon Video streaming services to its premium bundles. For the over-the-top (OTT) players, greater exposure to a ready-made customer base and the opportunity to also tap demand for their standalone services will be the main appeal.

Source: Company Website

June 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Thailand To Speed Up Development And Local Production Of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients

Thailand will remain a key pharmaceutical market for drugmakers. There is a strong will to incentivize the production of active pharmaceutical ingredients locally and boosting Thailand's appeal for foreign drugmaker investment. Risks in the form of medicine pricing and budgeting for healthcare threaten drugmakers' revenue-earning capabilities.

Source: Company Website

June 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Serbia IT Spending To Rebound Post-Covid, With Cloud And E-Commerce In Focus

Demand for IT hardware, software and services products will be set back considerably in 2020, owing to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on supply chains and enterprise purchasing. The PC segment will be hit hardest, owing to restrictions on imports, although we had already expected sluggish growth as the market enjoyed a robust period of growth in 2019 due to upgrades driv.

Source: Company Website

June 12: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos: Key Markets Struggle With Covid-19 Impact

Asia will be one of the hardest hit regions globally in 2020 with a 16.1% decline in vehicle sales. Passenger vehicle sales will see the biggest decline of 16.8% compared with 13.5% for commercial vehicles as some countries turn to infrastructure spending as part of their recovery efforts, generating commercial vehicle demand. Covid-19 has created some upside poten

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

urn:contentItem:609C-X291-DXKH-N34G-00000-00July 06, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Uruguay's High Healthcare Expenditure Helps To Keep Covid-19 Pandemic Under Control2020-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:41ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 06, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Uruguay's High Healthcare Expenditure Helps To Keep Covid-19 Pandemic Under Control

Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite surrounding countries in the region struggling. The government will continue to implement key fiscal policies to stimulate the economy. Healthcare spending per capita in Uruguay remains the highest in Latin America. Uruguay has managed to keep Covid-19 cases under control despite s.

INDEX

SECTION 1 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. PROFILE

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2020

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2020

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

SECTION 1 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. PROFILE

1.1 ACTIVITIES

Business Monitor International Inc. provides Country Risk and industry research analysis in the United States. The company was incorporated in 2009 and is based in New York, New York. Business Monitor International Inc. operates as a subsidiary of Business Monitor International Ltd.

1.2 SUMMARY

PermID: 4296431365

Website: http://www.businessmonitor.com

Industry: Software and Technology Servic

SECTION 2 PRESS RELEASES: 2020

June 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bahamas Poor Fiscal Outlook To Constrain Healthcare Spending

We at Fitch Solutions see downside risks to Bahamas growth as the coronavirus pandemic may cause extended damage to the tourism industry. The government's healthcare budget will come under pressure in the near term, as the Bahamas recovers from Hurricane Dorian and the Covid-19 impact. The Bahamas could increasingly attract investment from active pharmaceutical ingr.

Source: Company Website

May 13: Business Monitor International Inc.: Myanmar Emergency Tenders To Support Gas-Fired Power Growth

We have revised our Myanmar thermal capacity forecasts to account for the progress of several gas-fired projects under emergency tenders. While these projects have faced delays and missed their operational deadlines as we expected, progress will mean that they are likely to still come online within two years, by a conservative estimate.

Source: Company Website

April 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Collaborations Aim To Eliminate Medical Device Shortages Caused By Covid-19

Due to the increasing prevalence of Covid-19 (coronavirus), the demand for ventilators, personal protective equipment and testing devices is likely to remain unmet in the short term. In order to meet the sudden demand for respiratory devices, large medical device companies such as GE healthcare are collaborating with both medical and non-medical manufacturers. The d.

Source: Company Website

March 20: Business Monitor International Inc.: Big Tech After Covid-19: Cash And Regulation

We believe the Big Tech companies are in a strong position to expand post-coronavirus. There could be greater divergence between the US and the EU when it comes to tech regulation.

Source: Company Website

March 19: Business Monitor International Inc.: Gym And Fitness Subscription A Trend To Watch In China, Despite Covid-19 Outbreak

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. We believe that international and domestic fitness service providers that continue to innovate, and continue to offer unique exercise experiences will be best placed to grow their offering and engage wit.

Source: Company Website

March 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Sub-Saharan Africa 4G Developments: Licences, Launches And Investment

Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2020

July 07: Business Monitor International Inc.: Guyana And Suriname Continue To Attract IOCs Despite Political Uncertainty

We maintain our outlook for medium term crude oil production in Guyana as ExxonMobil positions Guyana at the centre of its investment strategy and restores production after technical issue. The commitment to exploration programmes from several international oil companies and ExxonMobil's farm-in to an offshore block constitutes an upside risk for Suriname's long term crude oi.

Source: Company Website

July 06: Business Monitor International Inc.: Taiwan's Early Success Makes It A Role Model For Covid-19 Pandemic Management

As many nations struggle to keep Covid-19 infection numbers down, Taiwan has benefited greatly from the close coordination between its hospitals and central government. Another reason for Taiwan's success can be attributable to Taiwan's well-renowned healthcare system. Drug pricing pressure will weigh on the pharmaceutical market growth.

Source: Company Website

July 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Higher Incentive Levels To Boost Austrian EV Sales In 2020

Demand for electric vehicles (EV)s in Austria will increase in 2020 following the announcement by the country's Ministry for Climate, Energy and Transportation that it plans to increase existing incentives aimed at reducing the cost purchasing an EV. The pending deadline for the implementation of EU wide emissions standards will boost demand for Plug-In Hybrid Vehicles (PHEV).

Source: Company Website

July 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Fishing Bans And Import Costs Feed Through To Impact Bangladeshi Consumer Spending

Despite rising incomes, Bangladesh's fish consumption (their main protein source) has declined relative to rice. This is because of the rapid inflation of the domestic fish price, causing local consumers to switch to cheaper alternatives. The reason for this inflation is the difference in the domestic and export prices of fish, as well as short term pressures on fi.

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Covid-19 Lockdowns To Accelerate E-Commerce Development In Latin America

rica are or have been in a state of lockdown, due to the spread of Covid-19 across the region. These lockdowns or stay at home orders have highlighted the value of e-Commerce, with consumers required to remain in their homes and so they have been utilising e-Commerce as a way shop, especially for non-essential goods and it is st

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Azeri Oil Sector Battling Accelerated Decline

Commitment to the OPEC+ production cut deal will place additional downside pressure on Azeri downside pressure over H220 and 2021, with government mandating cutbacks among private players. The Covid-19 induced price collapse will accelerate underlying decline rates, as companies sharply reduce their capital expenditures. The country has already been battling with declines, du.

Source: Company Website

June 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Russia Includes Avifavir In Covid-19 Treatment Protocol

Based on clinical trial data from Russia and China, Russia has included favipiravir in its Covid-19 treatment guidelines. At a population level the benefits demonstrated by the drug in trials will help to alleviate the burden on Russia's strained healthcare system. We expect more countries to approve the medicines in order to tackle their respective Covid-19 outbrea.

Source: Company Website

June 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: Healthcare System In Cuba Better Placed To Fight Covid-19 Pandemic

Cuba's government has taken a proactive approach to fight the Covid-19 pandemic. Cuba maintains a high level of healthcare coverage and a world-class medical service in terms of basic healthcare indicators. The Covid-19 outbreak will pose additional challenges for Cuba, the economy of which has been battered in recent quarters by US sanctions and this will weigh on.

Source: Company Website

June 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: EU's Contribution To Zimbabwe's Healthcare Fund Will Help Tackle The Covid-19 Pandemic

Zimbabwe continues to struggle to cope with the Covid-19 pandemic. The USD41mn contribution from the EU will help Zimbabwe reach its humanitarian appeal goal The lifting of the government freezing ban on healthcare will boost medical care available to the public.

Source: Company Website

June 18: Business Monitor International Inc.: Orange Africa Telecoms Expansion To Be Measured And Target High Value Markets

Orange is considering expanding its presence in Africa, tapping into the South Africa and Nigeria markets as potential near-term targets. A greenfield strategy is possible but Orange's desire for a more speedy entrance could see it acquire an outright, or significant, interest in established operators seeking investment. We do not expect a rapid, widespread expansio.

Source: Company Website

Over the long run, we expect growth in the Americas copper mine production will slow slightly but remain on a positive trajectory as favourable industry fundamentals continue to incentivise exploration and project approvals in the region. We expect Chile and Peru to remain regional outperformers, maintaining their status as the top two copper producers globally.

Source: Company Website

Multichoice is attempting to add value and stem declines in its South African pay-TV business by adding Netflix and Amazon Video streaming services to its premium bundles. For the over-the-top (OTT) players, greater exposure to a ready-made customer base and the opportunity to also tap demand for their standalone services will be the main appeal.

Source: Company Website

Thailand will remain a key pharmaceutical market for drugmakers. There is a strong will to incentivize the production of active pharmaceutical ingredients locally and boosting Thailand's appeal for foreign drugmaker investment. Risks in the form of medicine pricing and budgeting for healthcare threaten drugmakers' revenue-earning capabilities.

Source: Company Website

Demand for IT hardware, software and services products will be set back considerably in 2020, owing to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on supply chains and enterprise purchasing. The PC segment will be hit hardest, owing to restrictions on imports, although we had already expected sluggish growth as the market enjoyed a robust period of growth in 2019 due to upgrades driv.

Source: Company Website

June 12: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos: Key Markets Struggle With Covid-19 Impact

Asia will be one of the hardest hit regions globally in 2020 with a 16.1% decline in vehicle sales. Passenger vehicle sales will see the biggest decline of 16.8% compared with 13.5% for commercial vehicles as some countries turn to infrastructure spending as part of their recovery efforts, generating commercial vehicle demand. Covid-19 has created some upside poten

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Source: Company Website

Covid-19 has created some upside poten

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

Tanzania continues to shut down Covid-19 facilities as official numbers show a sharp decline in cases. Low healthcare spending per capita in Tanzania means healthcare facilities need to be used efficiently. Doubts about official Covid-19 figures remain. Zimbabwe continues to struggle to cope with the Covid-19 pandemic. The USD41mn contribution from the EU will help Zimbabwe reach its humanitarian appeal goal The lifting of the government freezing ban on healthcare will boost medical care available to the public.

Source: Company Website

June 18: Business Monitor International Inc.: Orange Africa Telecoms Expansion To Be Measured And Target High Value Markets

Orange is considering expanding its presence in Africa, tapping into the South Africa and Nigeria markets as potential near-term targets. A greenfield strategy is possible but Orange's desire for a more speedy entrance could see it acquire an outright, or significant, interest in established operators seeking investment. We do not expect a rapid, widespread expansio.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

Gregory Roth, Global Head-Communications

Lyndsey Anderson, Global Head-Research
